Even in my home office with relatively minimal noise, the sounds of fans, coil whine, mechanical clicking, etc from my computer and other electronics are highly grating on my senses. These headphones mostly block everything out and it is amazing. More often than not, I just keep them turned on without any music playing while I'm working or reading. Mind you, they don't grant complete auditory deprivation, but they do block out 70% of the noise that my brain can't seem to filter out on its own.

The added benefit of the "conversation mode" (palm over right ear cup) is great when my wife needs me to pay attention.

Autism aside, these are incredible sounding headphones for the price. I have planar magnetic Audeze cans that blow the crap out of anything I've ever heard in my life, but they don't cancel ambient noise and aren't wireless. I will always love my Audeze, but the M3's are my new favorites because they lower my stress levels dramatically AND still manage to sound great.

Now all I need are earbuds that grant this level of noise block that still let some vocals through, and I will never take them off!

author: DanteTheRocker
title: Recommended
content: Commi g from Audio Technica M40s, this is the most expensive headphones I've ever brought, but honestly it's worth every penny, the noise cancellation is magical, the sound quality is top notch, the battery is amazing and above all that it's light on the head. Amazing headphones.

author: Nicholas E. Jungman
title: Noise cancelling is amazing, battery life is great, sound quality is outstanding.
content: Noise cancelling is amazing, battery life is great, sound quality is outstanding.

author: gabriel
title: Great pair of headphones
content: Incredible pair of headphones! Noise canceling is phenomenal, sound is great, and I find myself charging it every 2 weeks or so, which is freaking crazy

author: s60maven
title: Noise be gone.
content: Best headphones I've ever had. I'm used to studio quality editing phones and have a decent audiophile ear. The sound is bass heavy but otherwise pretty clean. The noise canceling is magical in a household with kids playing loudly being reduced to nothing but a whisper.

author: Andrew D.
title: The silver in the photo is actually grey
content:
While the quality of these headphones is amazing and the noise canceling technology excellent, be advised that the silver color that is advertised is not the metallic silver color in the photos.

Only point of buyer’s remorse:  The color is more of a dull, matte grey color.  Had I known this I would have opted to get them in black.  I know this is a first world problem, but whether you spend $300 or $3 on something, it should meet your expectations.

author: Eric Gamez
title: Glad I went with Sony
content: I was going back and forth between the Bose qc ii and Mark 3 Sony's. I liked the better design on the Sony's so I went them. I have zero regrets. They sound great and are very comfortable. Cant go wrong with them.

author: N.Yakoby
title: Overall an upgrade over my QC35 (first gen)
content:
my review compares the M3 to QC35 (first gen).
-----------------------------------------------------------
Comfort: The head pad and ear cushions are soft but not too soft - as it should.
Fair disclosure, my ears has above average size.
I have more room in the earpiece of the QC35.
for me the QC35 takes this category - they are the more comfortable headset.
my wife who has smaller ears then mine says they are the same in terms of comfort.

build quality and materials:  good. overall the same as the QC35.

noise canceling:  impressive. a major improvement over the QC35.
they have excellent passive noise isolation as well.
compared to QC35 the M3 ANC is at another level.

Audio quality: The listening experience of everything I threw at them (except for classical music) was great with a warmer and more live sound than the QC35.

In the first 15 minutes of listening straight out of the box without changing the equalizer or setting they felt a little bit bassy - coming from QC35 good but flat listening experience.
the next day the bassy feeling was gone.
sounds of guitars, bass guitars, electric guitars, synths, drums sound great.
second sound/background sounds are clearly heard.
Even in familiar songs, I have heard sounds and layers that I have never heard before.
Some specific examples of my listening:
dire straits - sultans of swing sounds marvelous.
soundtrack of the TRON LEGACY movie by Daft Punk - impressive to the creeps.
In high notes classical music with violins and strings) the M3 are a bit lacking.
My listening has been partly of SPOTIFY and some lossless files, on a variety of styles.
some of my listening was comparative to see if I felt any difference between SPOTIFY's quality and LOSSLESS file quality.
I can unequivocally say that the difference is there.
Lossless files sound noticeably better on the M3. something I did not feel on the QC35.
I Always use my set to LDAC mode with "priority on Sound Quality" over "priority on Stable connection" - I did not come across any leaps or skips at all. my listening environment wasn't crowded with many Bluetooth devices.

Application: A bit of a mess, although there seem to be a lot of options, the features related to improving\altering sound properties are not available in the "priority on Sound Quality" mode (aptX or LDAC).
These features become active in the application only in the "priority on Stable connection" mode, which is actually SBC  - that is a bit disappointing.
Hopes SONY will remove this limitation in a future update.

Touch Control Interface - something that wasn't present on the QC35. it is comfortable not having to look for a knob, but you need straight and sharp movements on these, a small aberration left / right is enough to make the volume increase register as a next song.
The only touch gestures I have trouble with is a double tap (like double click) used for playback/stopping the music. It is also not the most pleasant one to use since the double tapping on the earpiece feels like "BOOM-BOOM" inside the earpiece.

Call quality / microphone - something I was afraid of in light of a number of reviews that came up on YouTube/Amazon.
I spoke to two people without saying I was using a special headset.
they did not complain about the call quality.
At the end of the call I asked if I sounded bad. the person on the other end said that I sounded fine and they didn't even hear the television that was working on a normal volume in the background.
I do not know the comparison point of bad reviews regarding the mic on the M3.
I'll keep track of whether there will be a change in upcoming calls I made using the M3's.
Relative to QC35 I can say that on my side of the calls I didn't feel a difference.

Video / Game Consumption - Watching videos from YouTube / Netflix a minor delay, non-issue. Action movie trailers feel just like in the movies (with deep bass). The delay on gaming was more noticeable a 1ms in rough estimation.

author: Macaccus Rhesus
title: Excellent noise cancelling phones
content:
Fantastic headphones. I am not a “Golden ear” (but still somewhat discerning with music): this thing is closing the gap on good/excellent wired solutions (such as Sennhieser 650 / And even more so Phillips Fidelio X2) while offering much more conveninence.

Easy setup and excellent battery life.

Overall well deserving of the stiff admission price.

(Compared this with the Senn 450BT and Bose and was most impressed with the Sony)

author: Russell Kelly
title: Great product
content:
Used for about a month now. Take some getting used to compare to my Bose wired headphones.
Love the compact design comfort and style. Noise cancellation is excellent!

author: D. Mossor
title: If you fly a lot, you deserve to buy these for yourself
content: ... I did, and I thank myself every time I get on a plane. The noise cancellation is second to none (according to popular website reviews), and works fabulously onboard a plane except when reverse thrust is used when landing. The noise gets so loud that you can hear the noise cancellation clipping while it is trying to negate the external noise. When connected to the app on my phone, I am able to tune the headphones with the equalizer and spatial positioning, but I am given no such control on the MacBook so I am left to listen to them au natural. While they sound relatively flat, I feel like the response drops quickly from about 250Hz. Mids are great. and highs can be a bit too bright depending on the music type, but with what I listen to (mostly instrumental) it rarely appears.

author: Jason V.
title: Worth it
content: Putting on these headphones I felt a great disturbance in the Force, as if millions of voices cried out in terror and were suddenly silenced

author: Edward
title: Love it!
content:
Great quality, great experience!

The only issue I've noticed is that sometimes when there phone is in my pocket with my hands it can abstruct the audio. Touch gestures can sometimes not work in some weather, but that was a known concern that didn't negatively deter me.

author: Brock Gibson
title: Amazing sound, noise cancellation
content: I bought some Corwin headphones for ~$80 and they would hurt my ears after some time as well as the sound wasn't all that impressive. These are pretty incredible. Sound, comfort, tech, everything is lined up great. Highly recommended.

author: M. Percy
title: Fantastic headphones
content: I can't say enough good things about these headphones. I take them with me on my train commute and wear them all day at the office. The noise canceling is incredibly effective and the ability to easily switch to "pass-through mode" to hear background sounds just by pressing a button on the headphones is appreciated. Great battery life. Also, the gestures to change songs and volume are useful and pretty cool, although I had to look up how to do that properly on YouTube.

author: Maurice Caton III
title: Battery life is amazing, and confort
content: Very comfortable to wear, took them on a trial run to spain. And they performed as advertised. Battery life is amazing, a little over 16 hours with out a problem. Only down side is i have to get use to the touchpad.

author: Eric Feuerstein
title: So far so good!
content:
I was in NYC last week on a biz trip and after a few drinks at dinner decided I had to have a pair of ANC headphones.....I walked into Best Buy and picked up the Sony 1000xM2 headphones as id heard great things about them apart from some of the well known build quality issues. I was able to use them for a few hours that night and on my flight home the next day. When I got home I saw in my newsfeed that the M3 was just announced with new features like USB C, new processor, better design etc. I returned the M2 and saw on amazon they already were selling the M3. I was shocked as nowhere else seemed to even have them listed on their site yet for sale. I ordered them assuming it was a mistake and they would not show up. Well, they did show up on time.....:) NIce surprise.

I will say by impressions after using them for a few days compared to the M2:

-WAY better design, more comfy, lighter weight, more padding on top, better larger earcups and overall quality seems better than the M2. The changes are subtle but if you look closely you will see them.

-Battery life is incredible on both M2 and M3 but now with USBC its even a better experience. I literally put them on the charger for like 15 or 20 minutes and they were at 90%. Sony states that a 10 min charge will get 5 hours of playback.

-Sony claims that the noise reduction is 4x better than before. This is where I think I disagree. the M2's had exceptional ANC and these are much the same. You can still hear things going on around you with ANC on and its certainly not 4x better than before. The one area I notice is better is when you cup your hand over the right ear to allow the external microphones to let in noise going on around you, its not as loud and hissy as it was on the M2. IT still lets in the external sound but in a MUCH cleaner way without all the blown out noise around it. Well Done.

-I constantly read on how the M2's and M3's are terrible for use making phone calls. Reviewers mentioned how people complained of echos, terrible mic quality etc,. I was expecting the worst. I called my wife yesterday while she was in her car to try this out for the first time on a call. We spoke for about 20 minutes. She said that my voice was loud and clear and she would not have known I wasn't speaking directly into my phone, but rather the headset. She was in her car which usually would make it even worse so I was nicely surprised. I could hear her well on my end via the M3s so was happy there. I wonder whether this was fixed in these new gen M3s as my call experience was fantastic. My wife usually hates when I call her from a speakerphone etc and often complains that I need to speak into the phone etc so for the M3 to pass her test was pretty incredible.

-I am Happy they finally made a carry case that fits the headphones AND the cables that come with it.....M2 was stupid that only the headphones fit in the case but none of the cords....lol.....really?

-The Sony App is the key here too in that is allows for great customization of the sound on the M3 so i highly recommend using it. THe strange thing is that it supports super high quality sound like LDAC but if you make any change via the app to the EQ settings etc it makes you default to lesser quality codec......weird.....not sure why.

-I have heard some people say they are a bit Bass heavy but really with the app you can tailor however you like. That said i like bass and man these things can put out in a clean way where the bass isnt distracting at all. THese are very clean headphones and the sound to me is better than Bose QC35.......

All in all, very happy with them and i presume over time Sony will keep pushing updates to them via the app. For instance now they allow Google Assistant and Siri. Ive been using Google assistant on them and its pretty great albeit with a bit of latency to the responses.

Let's not forget how great it is to have touch gestures built into the right earcup too. Man I can't imagine not being able to do this now on every headphone. It's kinda like when your on a buddy's PC and you go to swipe or pinch the screen only to find their PC isn't touchscreen. Lol. Yeah the m3 is that cool. Love using gestures for volume, play, pause, skip, activating Google assistant etc.

All in all these are a great experience. Hope this helps if you are on the fence.

author: Braden Whitten
title: Incredible sound, good connectivity with iPhone
content:
Edit: I've dropped this to a 4 star because the pairing comment I made below isn't quite right. It's still very frustrating that there isn't seamless support for multiple paired devices.

I was going to give this a 4 star for a single reason: it would not do dual-pairing with my Android phone. This would have the effect of me needing to remember to disconnect it from my Macbook before closing it, or it would actually persist that connection and not allow me to connect it automatically to my Android phone.

With iPhone, it's different. These headphones will hold a dual connection, but only allow music audio from one at a time. This has the effect of allowing my phone to take over, and giving me the ability to explicitly disconnect from my phone which yields music audio control back to my Macbook. The UX of this change cannot be understated. Seriously bothersome on Android, workable on iOS.

Still, the above issues could be improved by allowing dual connections with sound control from both. My $99 Plantronics had it. Why can't $350 Sonys?

I won't belabor the audio quality because I think other reviews cover it (it's absolutely phenomenal). The noise cancelling is magical. Can barely tell I work in a terribly noisy open-office plan, or that the old United 737 engines are loud as anything. It's just stellar noise reduction while keeping the aforementioned sound quality up. I tried Sennheiser's similarly priced models and their noise cancelling had a noticeable impact on sound quality (tin-y).

Battery life is great, and it charges super fast for a day's worth of battery (I'm talking ~10 mins to achieve that).

Overall, I won't let the connectivity issues bring down my 5 star, because I love these things.

author: Alice T.
title: It s worth
content: Good choice

author: Michael Gonzalez
title: Better than expected
content: These are seriously fantastic! I bought these for my wife for her birthday and I did not realize how amazingy these work. I'm jealous I didn't but them for myself. Ten out of ten, would recommend.

author: Leonid Naishtot
title: Good product, with great noise cancelling feature.
content: Great noise cancelling. Very comfortable. Padding is very soft and comfortable, I hope it will last for a long time. Battery life is very good. Sound is good, although I usually don't hear my music loud. Connects very easy to my PC, phone etc...Price is a little too high !

author: R.S.
title: You’ve been warned – SONY doesn’t stand behind their products
content:
Only one thing is important  for you to know before purchasing these headphones. SONY doesn’t stand behind their products. Before I purchased these I had Bose. Two different times Bose completely replaced my headphones when they came apart. The second time was almost 3 years after I bought them. I remember thinking that there’s no way they would do something with them because it had been so long but there was no harm in calling. I couldn’t believe it when they actually took care of it.

I was really reluctant to go away from Bose because of their unbelievable service but I let the reviews persuade me to buy these. I loved the headphones for the nine months they held together but after dropping them on the floor  they developed a crack in the plastic headband. After a week the whole left cup was hanging by a wire.  I just got off the phone with SONY and they said NO physical damage is covered, even in the first year. So if you’re never going to drop your headphones you should be good. But if you’re expecting Sony to stand behind their product (which shouldn’t have shattered to begin with) then you’re out of luck. You’ve been warned.

author: Stormie
title: Incredible, worth every penny!
content: These headphones are absolutely worth the money! I can sit in a noisy shared office and feel completely alone when I am using these. I was using regular earbuds previously but they were causing me pain in my ear drums after extended use. Switched over to these and it cleared the issue up right away.

author: Gill W.
title: Great battery life, integrates well with phone and the noise cancellation is second to none.
content: I would buy these headsets again in a heartbeat.

author: Alaa Mohammed
title: Touch control
content: The touch control aren’t practical

author: Laura J. Solomon
title: Noise canceling at its best
content: Loved everything about them and can’t imagine flying anywhere without having them. Highly recommend!

author: JoelBav
title: Outstanding!
content:
If there were ever a set of noise-cancelling headphones that are worth wetting your pants over, these are them! They are pricey, but you hear (and don't hear) every cent of their sticker price. Comfortable, very good sound over Bluetooth (and excellent over a wired connection using the 1/8" stereo connection) and noise cancelling that sets a new bar for the technology. In a work environment where I regularly measure crashing pallets and forklift backup alarms in excess of 85dB, the headphones rendered nearly TOTAL silence. It's so quiet, it's eerie!

Features abound. A one-button calibration process that quickly customizes the noise cancelling system for your specific environment really works. The ability to electronically allow SOME outside noise in allows you to know that co-workers have walked up to talk to you. Turn off the feature and you don't know they're there. The mix of outside noise can be controlled via a pretty decent smartphone app, which also offers other features (music EQ, power management, etc.)

Fit and finish are excellent. Honestly, I've come to expect much less from Sony compared to their heyday at the cutting edge of prosumer electronics back in the 1970's. These headphones seem to be a throwback to a quality and design standard that we haven't seen in a long, long time. What a fine product these things are...!

author: Ricardo D.
title: Good sound quality
content:
I got it about a week now so this is an early review.
Material quality: it looks sturdy if not a little heavy. Maybe I'm not used to a headphone. The overall quality s good. The feel of the minimal buttons is fantastic and spaced out so you don't have to look to find it.
I love the touch pad to control volume, skip or let ambient noise in.
Sound: when the equalizer in the companion app is set to my taste, this is one of the best sounding headphone I ever had. My daughter has Bose 35 and it's lacks a punch and presence. Out of the box bass is a little heavy but it can be adjusted.
ANC: compared to Bose 35, this is way better. Sony seems to isolate more higher frequency and background noise but the difference is small. You can't go wrong with both.
Overall what steered me to Sony is the music sound quality.

author: Logic
title: Worth every penny
content: I've only had this headset for a day so take this with a grain of salt but these are by far the most comfortable and best sounding headphones I've ever worn. Thank the sony gods for that because its not a cheap investment for most people. The bass is kicking, most audio is loud and in your face even on streaming sources like Youtube and Netflix. There's a slight delay between the audio and whats happening on screen but its really minimal most people won't be bothered. I can't really say anything bad about it I'm watching "Bumping Mics" in bed on Netflix and its super immersive and (hilarious) working great. Only thing I will mention that is a known issue with this headphone is that the headphones can become almost unusable in Cold temperatures without a wired connection. If the weather is below freezing 32F the Touch Pad on the ear cup won't work and it can even cause malfunctioning. So people who live in really cold climates this may not be the right headphone choice for you if you plan on using them outside. Well thats it 4 out of 5 I would give a 5 if they improved the build quality a little bit and fixed the malfunctioning in cold weather, Enjoy!!!

author: Vernell Jordan
title: Best sound ever
content: The sound is better than my beats.  Best noise cancelling head phones by far

author: An Pham
title: Best headphones
content: Usually it's hard to find great headphones for people who wear glasses, but these are perfect. The noise cancelling feature is the best. I've used it for flights and working at Starbucks.

author: Amazon Customer
title: ADD more equalizer control on higher frequency up to 22KHz?
content: Initially I'm very impressed on this noise cancellation. 1. able to calibrate. 2. able to select to hear people talking and cars passes by while still maintaining more quite surroundings. I only have this for 2 months so durability of this unit is unknown to me yet. Hopefully it last long as I would expect. 3. able to control without opening the app. 4. Fits well on my ear. 5. Long battery life. 6. Able to change sound thru equalizer that match my taste but lacks of higher frequency. 7. Pairs quickly with phone. 8. Doesn't get easily lost (like the on ear wireless Bluetooth). you will not noticed it when it fell off from your neck when not on your ears(not on use). 9. Great functional app.

author: Amazon Customer
title: perfect NC and sound quality.
content:
Hopefully, the headband won't crack.
UPDATE: the touch control responds slowly comparing to that of 1000x, and the touch control will malfunction when the temperature is low ( around 25F).
xm2 might be a better choice.

author: C Conroy
title: Best headphones
content: These are hands down the best over ear anc headphones in this price range. They can be worn comfortably for hours straight and will literally block out all of the surrounding sound. One of my best purchases of 2018.

author: mike
title: bosekiller
content: I live in new York city and it is very loud city.  with the constant people, car, buses and train this headphone is a must.  it effectively silence the "background noises" including voices.  However, if someone yells close range or honks a horn it will lessen the noise but NOT silence it.  I think sudden loud noises the ANC technology is unable to filter it.  However, for background chatters,  car noises, subway humming this is product does an amazing job.  The headphones hurt top of my head and ears in the beginning.  you have to break in these headphone just like buying a new pair of shoes.  it is getting more and more comfortable but at the same times I only tested it for ~ 10 hrs.  will write an update review in the future.  for the first 10 hrs it is a MUST buy.  worth every single dollar I paid for

author: tucker
title: great set of headphones
content: great set of headphones

author: Simon J Hornby
title: Best Noise Cancelling Headphones
content: Best headphones I’ve owned including a range from Bose, Stennheiser, etc. with great features via the app, long battery life and comfortable.

author: Brian in Dallas
title: Sound great, but Windows 7 FAIL
content:
First I have to say that I paired these with no problem with my S10, and they sounded AMAZING.  They are comfortable with my glasses.  I was thrilled!

But the reason I paid an arm and a leg for noise-canceling Bluetooth headphones was for work - I'm stuck in an open workplace with lots of distractions.  The Sennheiser HD 4.50 BTN headphones just weren't cutting.  Also unfortunately, we still have Windows 7 on our work laptops -- I know, don't laugh...  I know.

I spent at least 4 hours today futzing with these things trying to get them to work with Windows 7.  They supposedly paired, but Windows said a driver installation failed.  Looking at the device manager there were 3 instances of Bluetooth Peripheral Device with "!" next to them.  (I'm not positive that's the exact verbiage; I'm on my personal Linux laptop now)  I installed all the latest Dell drivers, and even went to Intel's website and used their driver update utility.  I'm a techie, in the IT field for over 20 years, so I know how to install drivers and troubleshoot.

I reached out to Sony support via chat and all they did was refer me to Dell - after trying to get me to reset the headphones.

I haven't given up yet, but I suspect I'll be returning these.  I suspect they would work much better on Windows 10, but we're not there yet.

author: Tim Mutta
title: works as advertised
content: Third Sony Pair I've had. Got the 950bt, they had insane bass, got the 1000mx2 , they worked like a charm. Picked up these Mx3 and the improvement on noise cancellation is evident.  The Bass grows on you over time, however its not as thumping as the 950BTs - which has the extra bass boost button .

author: Jeremy
title: Dont bother
content: Very poor sound quality outside of vocals. Almost any other product at this price point has better sound quality.

author: Patrick J O'Neill
title: So good
content: So good

author: Nicole
title: Perfect
content: Do the large firmware update once you get them. I believe this corrects the home call issue. Mine work great but I didn’t use them until I did the firmware update.

author: Tanner and Kenzie
title: Exactly what I didn’t know I needed!
content: WOW! I LOVE these headphones! I’ve had a pair of Bose noise cancelling headphones for about a year now and have liked them, but these are way better. They’re more comfortable on my head, feel better, and have a better sound quality. I love that I can either play via Bluetooth or an AUX cord. Anyone looking for a new pair of headphones, pay the higher price for these nice Sony headphones!

author: Cakeview LLC
title: Worth the $$$
content:
I will gladly eat Ramen for a month for you...
Worth it. The sound is beautiful and the noise canceling is above and beyond what expected. I am a baker and bought these to cancel out my loud mixers. They work even better than I expected! Very light weight too and comfort fit on my female head.

author: Asha Abraham
title: Best in segment
content:
Excellent headphones. I was waiting for this to go on sale for more than a month. Saw Sony’s keynote in ifa and ordered the same day it got listed on amazon . NC is excellent and sound quality is awesome . This wins the segment hands down.

Edit - headphones works great. Lowering a star because of crap app. Unable to connect. Its asking to update the app when no other update available

author: W. Passauer
title: Hurt eardrums after 5 minutes of use
content: Loved the headphones. They are everything you would want in noise canceling. Unfortunately, I can’t use them because after 5 minutes of use, the inside of my ear ( the eardrum area, NOT the earlobe outside) began hurting to a level 3 of 10. After removing the headphones it took more than 30 minutes for the pain to go away. Even the Sony instructions say, “If you experience discomfort...stop using it immediately “. I called Sony. They stated that there have been other complaints of the same issue. Sony case number 04419556. Amazon gave me no trouble in returning the unit. Amazon customer service is the greatest.

author: AlecHP
title: Great for office
content: Best office headphones I've ever owned

author: Jwalter
title: Expensive but really great perfromance
content: I haven't tested these against the Bose, but I have against some other models and this is the King. the noise cancelling features are almost worth it by itself on a long flight. The audio reproductions is great with a good source. very impressive. its also lighter weight than previous models and has a multi day battery life. Is the cost justified? For me it is.  My only con is I wish the volume level was a little higher.

author: Joe R.
title: Great materials and build quality, excellent, clear sound and noise canceling, comfortable fit
content: Headphones look premium and built with very good materials. Clean, elegant design that isn’t showy. Sound is incredible, active noise canceling is terrific. Earcups fit very well, even over glasses. Comfortable for hours of wear. Headphones deliver clean sound with strong bass in certain audio modes. Excellent for noisy offices or traveling on planes or trains.

author: Shannon D.
title: They are amazing!!
content: These headphones are absolutely amazing and make studying at school in the library so easy. I can use them on ambient sound or even noise  canceling depending on how much noise in the background I want to hear. I also use these when I travel on an airplane and in the airport terminals and they are so amazing at canceling out the sounds.

author: Amazon Customer
title: I like them
content: A+++ Great headphones

author: Richard
title: Amazing headphones
content: This is honestly the best set of headphones you’ll ever purchase. The comfort and sound quality are top notch. The Bluetooth capabilities are phenomenal

author: SenjuDUchiha
title: Go to Cans for all my needs
content:
I have used Bose QC 35 II. They were better than XM2. XM3 have totally blown the competition out of the park.
Enjoy them!

author: Zeke Medina
title: Airplane Use and general noise cancelling
content: Great sound for noise canceling bluetooth headphones. Coming from the Beats noise canceling pair I liked these more as the Beats are passive and these really cancel the sound. Especially on flights you can enjoy the music without having to turn it up too much. Or at the house if the AC is on or fridge buzzing, this cancels it right out.

author: G. Smart
title: Good Noise cancelling headphones
content:
I do like these headphones in this new wireless only smart phone world.  But sound quality for me is better when connecting to a source with the headphone jack.  Fortunately these headphones give you the option to do both.  The noise cancelling feature does well in blocking out low frequency background noise, but it replaces that with a slight hissing noise.  I guess that is just where the technology is at at this point.  Still good headphones and I do recommend them.

My first experience was without tweaking the headphones with the downloadable app on my iPod touch. After being able to tweak the EQ settings these headphones are so much more lively.  These headphones are definitely a great buy.

author: Michael
title: The absolute best over-the-ear noise cancelling headphones you can buy....period.
content: Incredible soundstage with flawless mids and highs  and superb bass. Warm, rich and supple sound reproduction.

author: Iniyavan
title: One of the best
content: These headphones are probably one of the best I have ever owned. Once it is on, I'm honestly disconnected from the world.

author: James A Stumbaugh Jr
title: Must Buy
content: Best product I’ve bought in years!

author: Psychiatrist87
title: Wow!!!
content: I NEVER leave reviews but this product is so amazing I had to. The noise canceling is surreal. You can literally be sitting in a busy cafe and feel like ur in a secluded nuclear bunker. Worth every penny.

author: DPB
title: Best purchase ever.
content: These are absolutely amazing. I love their functionality, ease of use and sound quality. My favorite hands down. You won’t be a single bit sorry.

author: Laynie
title: It makes for a great work day!
content: I did need a co worker to show me how to work it.  But since then it's perfect.

author: Dregoric
title: Finally great headphones!
content: I was waiting for this revision so long! Finally Sony produced very comfortable headphones! I can wear them for hours without any headache. Sound quality is amazing for Bluetooth device. It has the best sound among his competitors. Material quality is also excellent! Highly recommended!

author: Alvin
title: Best Sound than Bose QC35ii but not better Comfort
content: They sound great! (period). They have USB-C. Fast Charge. Better Noise Cancelling.But they are made of scratchy plastic, no Bluetooth 5.0, and they are uncomfortable.

author: Alberto Yu
title: I'm glad I purchased these
content: I have had quite a few different Bluetooth headphones, but these are my first real pair of noise cancelling headphones. On every aspect I feel it has delivered very good quality. The only issue I have found is if I'm too vigorous with my head motions it can trigger the adaptive noise and interrupt the song, but I guess you can turn that off if you're home alone dancing half naked. Ahem. Top quality product.

author: Deep Spaceus
title: Bose has been decisively dethroned (Update)
content:
I currently own about 30 headphones of various brands and types.  I have tried many Bluetooth headphones and own the Bose QC35 II and Bowers and Wilkins PX.  I bought both the Sony WH-1000x MKI & MKII but returned them after weighing the shortcomings vs the cost, my main complaints being comfort and sound (the ANC was always good).  My portable-everyday-beat-them-up headphones were the Bose QC 35 II.  I liked them primarily for the comfort and ANC.  The sound on the Bose can best be described as adequate but generally lifeless.  Always in search of something better I read a couple of “First Look” articles about the Sony WH-MX1000M3 and decided to pull the plug on the first day that they were available on Amazon.  When I received the Sony’s I was pleased to see that the case was similar to the Bose QC 35, a little bigger but shaped well enough to fit comfortably in my backpack.  When I removed the headphones and put them on my head I realized immediately that these would be as comfortable as the Bose.  Good job Sony.

After charging for a couple of hours I paired them to my phone and went to my headphone test playlist on Spotify.  My main complaint with the previous Sony model's sound was that they had very little soundstage (defined as perceived distance between your ears and the music) and little definition (defined as the clarity and separation of the various instruments in a piece of music).  The M3 sounded better than the previous Sony’s and better than the Bose, but the highs appeared to be quite subdued and overwhelmed by the bass.  This was disappointing.
But, Sony has a phone app that allows for EQ so I go download the app.  Frustration. The app did not recognize the MK3.  Patience.  I figure that Sony has not updated the app yet.  So I wait a day and see that the Sony app has automatically updated on my phone.  I open and hurray! It is recognizing the MK3 now.  Now I can play with EQ:  -1 on 400 Hz.  +1 on 1K.  +2 on 2.5K.  +3 on 6K.  +4 on 16K and “Clear Bass” remains at 0.  Play music and now were talking!  I’m not going to say that these sound nearly as good as most of my wired headphones, but for everyday-on-the-go-beat-them-up-with-ANC these are exciting.  They blow the Bose away.  The Bowers and Wilkins PX which weigh about three times more than the Sony’s have decent BT sound when the ANC is off but the sound changes considerably and not for the better when you apply one of three ANC modes.  They PX is OK for about an hour of no ANC listening while sitting at home, but after that my ears and the top of my head hurt.

The noise cancellation of the Sony is a generation ahead of Bose.  There, I said it.  Most reviewers crown the Bose as the best ANC you can get.  Well,  Sony has just showed Bose that they are the new big boy on the block.  I did some A/B comparisons with both headphones and realized that the Sony not only cancels steady noise like jet engines or the sound of the air conditioning intake in my condo, but it does a great job of virtually eliminating all other sounds, including television voices and even other people, as my wife can attest to when she had to stand in front of me and wave her hands to get my attention because I could not hear her talking (so, if you want to block out your wife’s talking… LOL!).  And this is without even messing with the settings in the app.  Others reviewer here have not had the same experience, stating that it does not cancel voices.  I frankly did not expect it to cancel voices, but I must say that the Sony comes as close as anything I have ever not heard.

So, if you want very comfortable headphones with the best sound and Active Noise Cancelling that you can expect with wireless Bluetooth in 2018 get these.  They will not sound as good as wired closed back or open back headphones, but “you can’t always get what you want”, “nothing is perfect”, and “everybody is different”.

In addition to the Sony WH-1000XM3 during this review period I used:
Bose QC 35 II
Bowers & Wilkins PX
Bang and Olufsen H6 (wired)
Sennheiser HD650 (wired)
AKG 7KXX (wired)
Spotify
Flac files on phone and desktop computer

UPDATE 2018-09-21:  I did experience an issue with phone calls where people at the other end were hearing an echo of their voice.  I tested the headphones with three different phones and the problem occurred with all three.  So I replaced them through Amazon.  I am glad to say that the new pair does not have the issue.  After some tests with phone calls I will say that Sony still needs to do some work on the call quality at the other end of the call (the call sounds fine in the Sony itself).  In this regard, the Bose QC 35 is better.  I think the call quality is really with the sound processing that Sony has implemented and not the hardware.  Hopefully this will be improved in future firmware upgrades.  Another minor con that the Bose handles better is the support for multiple BT sources.  But this is a minor annoyance and I only use the Sony's for my phone anyway, so I am not constantly switching sources.  Small price to pay for better ANC and musical sound.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Excelent sound
content: Excellent sound

author: Ethan
title: Great for travel. Sound quality not perfect.
content:
I had my eye on these forever and finally got them when the price dropped to $300. However it was little too late. While looking for cheaper alternatives I bought a pair of $150 Beyerdyamic 770 pros and he quality of sound changed my expectations of how headphones should sound. These don’t have a soundstage at all really in comparison and the vocals sound distant in comparison honestly. I guess wireless headphones try to compensate lack of hard data transfer with software and Sony does a pretty good job at this. The sound isn’t bad by any means but it just doesn’t have an accurate, balanced sound compared to any wired studio headset. If you’re commuting on public transportation often or spending time in noisy environments then you’ll love these but for my usage I didn’t need an “on the go” headset so I opted for the best sound quality for the money and ended up returning these.

I will note that I use the song wireless extra bass over the ear headset for my workouts on a virtually daily basis and I adore them as they have remained solid as ever after two years of abuse so I’m sure these headphones are just as durable.

author: Robert Collins
title: Sony WH-1000XM3 - AWESOME Noise reduction...Annoying mic issues...but I may have a solution
content: This headset is AWESOME when it comes to noise reduction.  I literally can't hear any voices or noises next to me when I have it turned on.  So i noticed one of the other Reddit forum folks mentioned turning OFF Noise Cancellation and the call improved. Well I began playing with the Sony Headphone app and discovered that by leaving Noise Cancellation on but dialing down the "Ambient Sound Control" slider bar more towards the right improves my mic response tremendously according to folks who have heard the before and after. I also set the "Focus on Voice" checkbox.  BUT I also noticed that upon playing with this further...it seems even when I slide the bar over to full noise cancelling - my voice quality is fine according to others when the Adaptive Sound Control is turned OFF!  I turned it back on and the call sound went to hell in a handbasket.  So I think if you can live with the the ASC turned off while on cell calls, this headset ROCKs even on cellphone calls.  Bluetooth has been flawless - doesn't drop or cut out.  I'm going to play with this some more over the next two weeks but so far I'm pretty impressed now that I got my cell calls fixed for now.  Wil report later if things change and I flip back to a Bose QC-35 II

author: Ronald Thompson
title: Don't let the looks fool you, BEST ANC wireless headphones on the market
content:
While the materials are as you'd expect for a lightweight headset - plastic and lacking the super premium look/feels at time, the tech in these headphones is top of the line and trumps any other ANC headphones out there in almost every category. Closest competitor Bose QC3 Series II at the same price, only keeps ahead in comfort, size, and headset capabilities. It falls short in everything else, as Sony's aggressive push has put them at the top of this mark.

The one knock I'll provide is the microphone for the sake of phone calls is not very good - so if you need to take calls frequently with your ANC headphones, not the greatest option for you. Otherwise, go ahead and get these - especially if you have an Android device running Oreo or later and can exploit the LDAC codec stream this headset (and Sony) support.

author: Quicha Patel

It's also perfect for the plane because it comes with the cable and the plane adapter! I take them everywhere.  They're great for the gym but I don't use them to run.

author: Jake
title: Where did the outside world go?
content:
I use these to watch TV and Movies outside while enjoying a cigar. I live next to a free way on ramp, and can normally hear tons of traffic and sirens. Since I purchased these, I don;t even hear them anymore. I mean I do if I am listening for them. However, for the most part the outside world gets drowned out when the audio is playing from whatever I am watching at the time.

I do wish they would automatically re-sync to my TV; but I am not sure if the headphones or the TV are to blame. I used to have a cheap pair of wireless earbuds that would auto sync to my TV, but these won't. I always have to go to the menu and select them manually every time.

Anyway, for the way they perform and the service they provide, drowning out all the distractions I am very happy overall.

But the low rating is for the bad microphone. The sounds around you are amplified when you are either on a call or using it for any application,like games. It also forms a feedback loop of your voice, you basically hear what you have spoken.
Sound quality is very good but when I use it with aux it sounded a little bassy. The 2 stars are for the sound quality and app. Some features are really good like touch controls, placing your palm to hear what other person is saying and the app makes your experience even better one but sadly I find the headphones uncomfortable after 30 min usage. They are not as comfortable as you would expect for a over ear headphones.

author: benjamin bannister
title: The Noise-Cancelling Headphones For New Yorkers
content:
I first saw these top-tier headphones when Sony introduced the 1000X. I wanted it then but the price and the complaints about a cracked band gave me pause. Now, on its third iteration, the 1000XM3 fixes many issues. It now has a battery life that competes with regular non-noise-canceling headphones; noise-canceling technology has gotten better; and the band-cracking issue is something I'm hoping Sony has fixed by now.

— UNBOXING —
The insides slide out and you are presented with a storage case. Inside are the headphones folded up, an airplane audio adapter (for those planes that have two 3.5 mm prongs), and a short (8.5") USB to USB-C cable. There is a manual and a quick guide pamphlet that provides instructions through pictures.

— BUTTONS AND INPUTS —
There are two buttons: power and noise-canceling (NC). The rest of the controls are hidden as touch controls on the flat surface of the right can (earpiece): move a finger up and down for volume; left and right for skipping/repeating tracks; double tap to pause/play. You can also palm the right can to lower the volume so you can hear anyone talking to you without taking the headphones off.

On the left can, there is a 3.5 mm input jack if you want to physically connect this to a phone for slightly better sound. On the right can, there is a USB-C input for charging.

— BATTERY LIFE —
Charging takes three hours to fully charge. If you don't have time, a 10-minute charge can give you five hours of playback. Playback time is 30 hours with NC, and up to 38 hours without.

— SOUND QUALITY —
As Sony's flagship Bluetooth headphones, the sound on this is terrific. It feels well-balanced, with clarity of voices, a good middle, and the comfortable booming of bass. It's also loud and I had to turn it down a couple notches; if you take the headphones off while music is playing, people around you will definitely hear it. For Bluetooth headphones, this is worth the money in terms of audio quality.

If you wanted to adjust the equalizer, you can do that through the Sony Headphones app.

— NOISE-CANCELING —
I live in New York City and I take the subway. Lemme tell ya: I don't hear babies screaming, or overly loud people, or the sound of the subway car itself with noise-canceling on. It's not 100% noise-canceling but enough to completely forget that anyone is making noise. I've tried these walking along Park Ave and I turned NC on and only NC (no music), and I can only describe the sound I hear as a quiet city with just a fan blowing in the background.

Obviously, it cannot remove the sounds of people talking completely but enough for them not to bother me. For me, NC is always on when I'm sitting on the subway. I let ambient sounds in when I have to walk around in traffic—because it's safer that way.

— HEADPHONES APP —
There is a supplementary app which gives you additional controls. I will address these in the order they appear. Some of these features are interconnected and I will try to explain as best as possible as to what they do.

● Adaptive Sound Control: detects your action, whether you're sitting, walking, running, or on public transportation.
● Ambient Sound Control: adjusts how much of the outside world to hear from 0 (Noise-Canceling on) to 20 (you can hear around you).
● Noise Canceling Optimizer: optimizes NC if you are in a new location. Example: you can optimize when you are at your office desk; when you get on a plane you can optimize it again. It checks atmospheric pressure and adjusts NC accordingly.
● Sound Position Control: you can change it so your audio sounds like it's coming from the front, left, right, back right, back left, or omnidirectional.
● Surround: changes audio to sound like an: arena, club, outdoor stage, concert hall, or off.
● Equalizer: multiple presets with two customizable settings.
● Audio control: you can control the current audio playing: play/pause, back/forward.
● Sound Quality Mode: choose between priority on sound quality or a stable connection.
● DSEE HX: Sony's way of upscaling your audio files to be higher resolution. You can turn this on or off.
● Change function of NC/Ambient button: changes the button to do ambient sound control, or Google Assistant.
● Automatic Power Off: have it auto turn off after 5/30 minutes to 1/3 hours, or not turn off at all.

— DESIGN —
Not much has changed in terms of the design of this flagship model, it feels like a refinement for me. The headband arch is more oval-shaped and conforms better to your head vs the old circular arch. The leather on the headband and ear cups are soft and comfortable. The fit feels just right (not tight). The Sony name is in a gold-ish color (and it would've look nice if there were more gold accents throughout the black (like Jurassic Park's Indoraptor). The overall look feels like a distillation of good design. Simple, but elegant, and future-forward.

— SUMMARY —
I've been waiting a few years for a Bluetooth, noise-canceling, stylish, long-lasting, headphone. It's finally here and I'm happy with this purchase. Recommended.

However, the microphones just don’t work for calls. People complain they pick up background noise and make me sound ‘far away.’ Maybe I’m doing something wrong? The only thing I really really don't like it that I can only connect to one device at a time.  I think this is pretty short sighted on Sony's part and hopefully can be fixed with a software update.

author: christian
title: Highly recommended
content: I highly recommend these if you’re looking for great sounding noise cancelling headphones. They’re cheaper than the new Bose headphones but they don’t sacrifice quality. The noise canceling is amazing and with the app you unlock the customizability of these headphones. The app gives you control of an equalizer with preset audio-styles as well as setting a Custom profile. You can adjust noise cancelling level from a full 12 ambient sound down to wind reduction or full noise cancelling. There’s also a neat adaptive ambient sound that will adjust the level of noise cancelling based on whether you’re sitting, walking, running or on transit. All of which are customizable to what ever level you want. Another amazing feature of the ambient sound setting is being able to filter out only voices so that background noise is cancelled but you’re still able to communicate with those around you. The headphones themselves are also very comfortable I wear them for about 6-7 hours a day with no discomfort or pain like my older over-the-ear headphones. My only complaint, which is less of a complaint and more of a small annoyance, is the touch controls. What I do like is the level of control you have, there is forward track back, play, pause, volume and Siri. My problem is it can be kind of finicky, it not horrible but it’s not perfect either. One wish I had would be wearer detection, in that removing the headphones would pause and putting them back on would play. All around I highly recommend these headphones other than some small personal complaints, these headphones are amazing and well worth the money

author: Nate
title: Best Headphones on the market - Hands down!
content: Haven't been a regular user of over the ear headphones, but needed something to keep out the noise so I could study as well as use them at work. I have been in search for some for months and tried them all. Bose, Beats, Skullcandy..everything. These were the solution. Noise cancelling is absolutely incredible. Cupping your hand to the right earphone is impressive technology and you can instantly hear everything around you, take it off and the noise is again gone. Sound quality is outstanding as well. Crystal clear with an app that lets you adjust the levels to your liking. If you like a lot of bass, these provide bass you can feel! Can't say enough about these headphones. Very pleased with my purchase. Bose aren't even a close 2nd, these are that good.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Amazing sound and noise cancelling ability.
content: So great!

author: Caleb
title: Ok
content: A bit spendy but for the best noise canceling it was sort of worth it.

author: Andy Wilson
title: Very long battery life and excellent noise reduction
content:
I took this on a trip where I had 15 hours of flight time plus a layover for another 6 hours.

The headphones battery lasted the entire time with no additional charging. I was playing music, videos and games with very good sound quality.

The noise canceling was amazing. You could hardly hear the plane engines, or even the people talking next to you. One flight had a toddler behind me and the kid was crying for most of the trip (poor kid and poor parents, they had a hard trip) but the headphones largely blocked it all out.

Simply amazing and surpassed my expectations!

author: Trevorjham
title: Music sound quality is extremely poor. Bass overwhelms these headphones.
content:
My rating is based on what I was looking for in a new pair of wireless over the ear noise cancelling headphones.

I had a pair of Dre Beats Studio for the past 2 years and was extremely happy with them.  My primary use for my headphones are for the gym.  Top quality sound, the ability to handle Hip Hop bass without distortion, and noise cancelling capabilities are my main priorities.  I had an unexpected freak accident and broke my Dre Beats last week.

So I was in the market for new pair of premium headphones.  I'm the polar opposite of a spontaneous buyer when it comes to larger than normal purchases.  I read and watched all reviews, and visited BestBuy to get a first hand experience of Bose, Sony, and other competitor headphones.  These Sony WH-1000 came in first in every 2019 review with Bose coming in a very close second.  I really couldn't get a true experience at BestBuy.  Taking in consideration Sony WH-1000 being undefeated in the forum of 2019 reviews, I made the purchase.  Also, I'm a Android guy and Dre Beats are designed for and most compatible with Apple platforms.

PROS: The headphones are very comfortable.  Synchronization functions were very user friendly, and these headphones come with a lot of features and, a phone app.

CONS: Noise cancelling functions were not overwhelming better than my Dre Beats.  I personally didn't notice a huge difference.  Sound quality was very disappointing.  When the volume was turned up to 70% or higher the bass became extremely distorted, to the point where it wasn't an enjoyable listening experience.  Sound frequency would go from high to low for no apparent reason.  I filtered through all the equalizer functions within the app, and I was unable to improve the sound quality.  When I tried to readjust the headphones on my head, I would accidentally pause or interrupt the music.

I feel these headphones are designed more for leisure activities, phone calls in public areas, and laptop functions.  These headphones are packed with a whole lot of features and I feel this greatly takes away from sound quality.  If premium sound quality is a major priority, I would not recommend these headphones.  I refunded these headphone for a new pair of Dre Beat Studio.

Again, my review is based on what I'm personally looking for in a premium pair of headphones.

author: tony
content: Product condition as described.  Very satisfied customer.

author: Jesse
title: Hurts my ears.
content: Excellent noise cancelation.  I am having a hard time getting use to charging it all the time.  After wearing it for a few hours my ears hurt.  I might be going back to my old headphones.  The noise cancelation is cool but it hurts my ears.  I think it will be great on planes but not every day at work.  I find that if i turn off noise can, i can get a lot more hours with good feedback. ....

author: Philip Cullen Fralix
title: So quite you’ll never hear them coming
content: In the military, out of country, and living in a dorm with paper-thin walls. Last night I put these headphones on before going to sleep to block outside noise. I woke up a few hours later, one friend crawling into my bed, another preparing to flip my mattress, and three others standing there giggling like little girls and then screaming to find out I was naked. 9/10 noise cancellation. If you’re career requires 24/7 situational awareness, Find something else.

author: SeparatriX
title: Great headphones
content: We got two sets of these after a lot of research in noise-canceling headphones. All reviews pointed to this model, so this is what we went with. The volume control and song skipping are easily done on the can on the right. You can also turn off the volume to listen to someone speaking by cupping the right can. We very much enjoy these. A slight word of caution though: make sure you unpair from each device if you wish to use it with a different device.

author: Brandon
title: Better that what I expected
content: I like everything so far.

author: Amazonaddict
title: Sony vs Bose by a regular guy
content:
I own both Bose QuietComfort 35 ii and Sony WH-1000XM3. So it’s only fair to do a brief comparison. But this is from an amateur/non-expert guy who just loves his music and will keep it simple.

Sound quality: Sony has a noticeably richer sound, better base. Better sound goes to Sony for me.

Comfort: Bose are more comfortable and can be worn for a longer period of time with comfort than Sony. Top of my head gets uncomfortable with Sony for long periods over 1-2 hours.

Noise cancellation: Surprisingly Sony is better. I had already owned Bose and when I put Sony on to try at Best Buy...I was well impressed! And decided to buy Sony too simply based on how good the noise cancellation was!

Ease of use/practicality: this is about volume buttons etc. Bose is more practical and easier to use -especially the volume buttons. Also Bose can connect to two machines at a time whereas Sony can only do one at a time.

Quality of material: I bought Sony when Bose was 10 months old but within 10 months the ear cushions of Bose had worn out so not the build quality one would expect from $350 headphones(I called Bose and it was under warranty so I got replacements for ear cushions). Verdict is still out for Sony as it’s only been a few months but to be honest the build quality of Sony just feels better than that of Bose.

Battery life: Sony is the winner here by 10 extra hours! Tested both with continuous music.

I’m sorry that I didn’t delve too much into the “quality of sound” subject more but I’m just a regular guy who enjoys his music with good headphones. They are both good headphones but for me Sony is ahead overall. I chose to buy Bose first based on my reading of what experts had said especially about “noise cancellation” but after trying both as a non-expert, my choice is Sony. Though having both can’t hurt :)

author: Josh Frechem
title: Very good headphones but not perfect
content:
After a few days of use I must admit that I have started to notice things that I would like to be better, but know there likely are no better headphones on the market that combine all of the things I wanted these to do. The noise cancelling is not what I expected it to be, but they are my first pair and I likely expected the technology to be somewhere more advanced than it is. Higher frequencies and non-periodic noise make it through much more than periodic noise and lower frequencies. The fact that it handles periodic noise so well makes me wonder if it is running an FFT to efficiently find frequencies to intelligently cancel, or that I just happen to be around periodic noises that are effectively cancelled by these headphones. Anyway, stuff like music at Starbucks makes its way through, but with significant attenuation, to the point I can't hear Starbucks-level music over my own music, but I can between songs (though it isn't annoying).

They are light and pretty comfortable for someone with pretty big ears, but I find myself taking them off a few times per hour to give my ears some air to cool down. When I am looking down at a book or something, they like to slide down unless they are tighter, which I accept because these cause a serious case of headphone hair if you have them on tight enough to prevent this (which isn't desirable when you are in public). But, they are pretty comfortable. I expected worse for closed back headphones.

The sound is quite nice and I deal with the extra bass to make sure the audio is coming in at high quality when I am listening to my FLAC files. When streaming, I would recommend just change the EQ to your liking because your music will NOT be anywhere near audiophile quality unless you pay specifically for it to be. Comparing them to my open back headphones, the difference is very clear. Not necessarily in quality, but in how it sounds. I personally prefer the sound of the open back, but they are awful to use in public and these are likely the best option to go for when you need to be in your own space in public, yet not bug people with your music (which is a really annoying issue these days, for some reason...).

I work in a physics lab and this is where I really appreciated these headphones. I have a bunch of fans on electronics running and vacuum pumps, large AC units, etc and the noise is annoying as can be. I put these on an even without music I entered a whole new world. I can't see myself working without these anymore. The lack of cable is why I got them for my lab (the ANC was for public), but the ANC became a really great aspect of these for my lab life. I was hesitant for a while about paying $350 for these, but being in the lab with them made up my mind-worth it (but now I don't hear my boss come in which can be awkward).

The case is amazing... though the storage pouch on the outside is on the bottom.... WHY? You made the interior separators so that you can't move them and then put the mesh pouch on the bottom... such a weird design choice. Otherwise, the case is amazing, despite the pathetically short USB-c cable that came with it. That was a really dumb way to save a few cents that did not go unnoticed. But, the entire package is worth it.

author: Kimberly W.
title: Breaks within six months of purchase after light use
content:
Bought these in June of this year. It’s October and they don’t work. The power button is unreliable. The noise canceling cycles on Off randomly. What a drag. Sony used to be a reliable manufacturer.
Stay away from this product.

author: Brian C.
title: Never used an ANC headphones before so this is a novice review.
content: Maybe it was because of my (unwarranted) high expectations, but I've never owned ANC headphones before and I totally expected to be blown away by these headphones because of all the great and positive reviews I've heard and seen over the past year on these headphones. They're pretty good, but I was not blown away by the active nose cancellation or the sound quality of these headphones. I never really really owned any decent headphones before so I didn't know what to expect but I've purchased quite a few flagships TWS earbuds this past year and in my mind, headphones should absolutely be better than wireless earbuds but the sound quality on these headphones is pretty much similar to the top end true wireless earbuds from my listening experience. The active noise cancellation is pretty good but I could still hear the outside world, and again maybe I expected a little too much, but I didn't know ANC can't block out all the noise from the outside world. The technology is not there yet. Overall I'm happy with the purchase even if I don't sound like it. I'm still on my first couple of days with these, so I'll give it some time to fully immerse myself with these headphones. I'll give an update once I get a little more usage on these cans.

author: Kid_George
title: Great product
content: excellent

author: Amelia Alameno
title: The best thing I've bought in 2019
content: Easily one of the best purchases of 2019. I love these headphones. I use them all the time, they work amazing and are super light to carry as I work remote.

author: Ian L
title: DONT DO IT
content:
Here's the short and sweet story:

I bought these 2 months ago, and I loved them initially. And to be clear, they are fantastic headphones. But after 2 months of REGULAR USE (aka, sitting at a desk and listening to music, not hiking through the Himalayas or something), the little plastic tab that holds together the headband broke.

So whatever, I'm a reasonable guy, and shit happens sometimes. So I contact Sony, and ask them to repair or replace it, because I shouldn't pay $350 for something that breaks after 2 months of normal use. Spoiler alert, they completely denied all responsibility and basically told me to go pound dirt, and hence I'm here, warning you not to make the same mistake as me.

Two quick details before I sign off: One, the part that broke on the left earphone, has now cracked on the right one. It's a design flaw, the part flexes more then it can handle in the motion of putting the headphones on & off your head, and hence it broke. They've had issues with this in their past generations of headphones (seriously, google "Sony Headphones cracking", its some pretty entertaining reading) and apparently these are no different.

Don't make the same mistake as me. I won't be buying another Sony product ever again.

author: Howard A Perkins
title: The noise cancellation is freaky awesome.
content: I work in a cube farm office environment.  These headphones make the noisy chatter disappear.  The only issue I have with these is that after maybe four hours of listening and then a break for lunch, the Bluetooth connection gets wired. It cuts in and out every half second.  Disconnecting and reconnecting corrects the issue.  Annoying but I can live with it

author: Isidoro Antonio
title: Great sound quality indeed!
content:
These headphones have a very good quality sound indeed, I would definitely buy it again!
Very heavy bass and nice treble in the background which makes your old musics sound new...

author: be7ery
title: It doesn't charge anymore
content: I bought it a month ago ,and now it doesn't charge anymore even tho I use the cable that came with it and an original samsung fast charger

author: Jack Maes
title: Sony is back
content: Simply the best

author: Ravi Kode
title: Makes plane rides more comfortable.
content:
- sounds great
- battery life is great
- convenient
- aux cable makes it more versatile

author: Jason Z Lin
title: Best headphone!
content: Very comfortable. Great sound. Best ANC.

author: SmithNP
title: Superb
content: I have the Bose ones and got these for my partner. You can tell the noise cancelation is better in the Sony headphones, music quality is the same, but the volume control on the Sony is was better. Being able to just put your hand on the side to turn music and noise cancellation off if someone talks to you is great.

author: mohamed s.
title: Not good for Me
content:
I've used this headphones for about 10 days and I really couldn't use it more.
For the sound quality ... this is not what I'm looking for, it's boomy and bass focused, so it destroys all other music details and background instruments and vocals (same like Beats).
On high volume, a cracking sound is noticeable which is very annoying.
Call quality ... I think it has the worst call quality in the world .. that my 10$ earbuds performs better.
Connectivity .. only pairs with one device at a time, and every time I've to manually disconnect the previous device to connect another one and it's a pain.
For ANC it's good if it works But after an hour or two of listening to it begins to produce a white noise on the left ear cup (so it actually brings me the noise instead of canceling it).
For comfort, yes I think it's good and comfortable, so no issues on this matter.
Finally, I've returned it, and I've ordered another brand which I hope it'll work better than this.

author: Christopher and Joseph
title: Sony Headset, The Best!
content: I like Sony!

author: JS
title: Good sound cancellation but bad microphone
content: The headset was great at cancelling noise but was horrible to use for phone calls which was the main reason I purchased it.  It can only answer a call and cannot be used to make a phone call.  And when I did use it for calls I could barely be heard by the caller.  I also did not like the touchless controls.  They were not easy to use and didn't seem to react the same time to movement.  And you need a smartphone to utilize all the features and settings.  For example, the default is to turn off noise cancellation after 5 min if its not synced to Bluetooth.  I had to get a friends phone to download the app and tweak the settings.  I ultimately returned it.

author: abdulaziz
title: Niceeeeee
content: The best headphones in the market

author: Audra Mitchell
title: Truly Noise Cancelling!!!!
content: I have worn these at work recently while there was construction going on one floor below.  I had previously had a problem with not being able to concentrate due to the level of noise, but with these headphones I heard none of the noise!  They have a great sound quality and the controls are easy to use.  I highly recommend these!

author: Keyopr
title: Amazing headphones!
content: These are amazing, much more than I anticipated!  The noise cancellation is wonderful and you can put at different levels if you want to hear some background noise.  The sound is terrific, and the battery last a very long time.  I would highly recommend these!

author: Yvonne Chen
title: Comfy effective headphones
content: Very comfortable headphones that go over your ear so your ear doesn’t ache. Pretty good noise cancellation as well! Doesn’t block everything out- just drowns it out quite a bit, which is safe in case you do need to hear something. Was great for the plane.

author: Zach
title: Best Noise-Cancelling Headphones
content: I bought a pair of these for work and ended up getting a second pair for my wife. Best headphones I have ever owned.

author: Joe
title: Great Headphones
content: Great buy and quick delivery

author: Hugh B Wooten
title: LOVE LOVE LOVE
content: I thought I was in love with Bose Noise cancellation--- Sony has got the extended battery life--and works well in outdoor environment-- When I am on the zero turn its like being in the quiet environment and enjoying the music while cutting the grass-- nice functions of up and down volume-- skipping tracks or songs

author: gnrlbzik
title: Love sound, battery life, looks and overall usefulness. With few caveats...
content:
Love sound, battery life, looks and overall usefulness.

Things i dislike and hope sony will fix next time around:
- Got to say, calling while commuting in train, have to always switch to phone, quality just horrible, half of time people can't hear you.
- Touch control, is 80% on point.
- Sound for music playback cuts off / lags occasionally when phone is in the pocket.
- Charging while listening none existent, this one bothers me occasionally.
- My ears sweat like crazy in these, but i upgraded pads, so that fixed it a bit.

author: Martin Karlsson
title: Best headphones I’ve ever had
content: so good! Makes airplane noise tolerable.

author: Saint Pepsi
title: Children of the damned
content: I got these after getting the Bose 400. The Bose 400 didn't block nearly as much noise and turned off after 10 min of non use with a loud digital alert. The purpose for these was to sleep because the kids that live above us were trained in military tactics of driving someone crazy through lack of sleep. They would litterly keep jumping up and down and off furniture. The reverberation of the dance of doom deprived my wife from the sleep she so desperately needs as she works the graveyard shift and sleeps days. Not only is the music fantastic, you can fall asleep in these without the digital alert that they haven't moved in 10 min. I haven't moved in ten min because I'm sleeping Bose... Come on. Their app is fantastic really allows for great control of the headphones. Most of all you can't hear the young hellions running amuck like cocaine covered drawves home from the mines and generously downing pints of ale. What sweet relief. I would give more stars if I could. All the collected stars from Mario 64 for the peace of mind these have afforded us. My wife was on edge. Don't think technology can help a relationship. Think again because Sony has allowed my wife to sleep, ergo I don't catch the absolutely malice she wishes upon the children of the damned that prance above us.

author: Sandra G.
title: awesome
content: burn these headphones in for best sound quality

author: Txgrana
title: FABULOUS HEADPHONES!
content: LOve the Sony headphones for music and audio books. I had tried Apple Airbuds first. Sound was ok but keeping them in my ears was annoying. So I tried a Bose headphone. It was bulky, difficult to feel for the control buttons so I returned it. Then I found the Sony headphone. Perfect. Fit well, light snd comfortable. Easy controls and fabulous sound quality!

author: akhil
title: Good one
content: Had to return it due to defect. Had an issue with the refund but later resolved.

author: June Barrow
title: Sound quality
content: Like the controls swipe. Hand over the ear to hear what in the room. Like the Sony app to use the equalizer. There in no cons for me

author: SteveinMA
title: Amazing sound, really makes the aircraft cabin noise disappear.
content: Very comfortable, easy to use, solid connection.  Not as good of sound as my Grado's in a home environment but when dealing with active cancellation of aircraft noise, these are exceptional!

author: Corvo
title: best
content: very nice

author: Francis Boucher
title: near perfect
content: great phones. use them daily. terrific sound.

author: S. Stewart
title: Ahhh-mazing quiet for commercial airline flights
content: So far, love them. Noise canceling is great on commercial airline flights and the feature that allows you to cover the right side with your hand to allow momentary stoppage of noise canceling works well to hear flight attendant or announcements. Comfortable and light-weight. I primarily use for watching downloaded content on my iPad.

author: AKfromVA
title: Best noise canceling
content: To be honest, thought they’d be louder.

author: Craig Brown
title: Best headphones to date
content: These are fantastic, I've had several other brands of overear and pods (Bose, Jaybird), these blow them away.  Crips sound and the swiping feature for stop, forward, play, volume work excellent!

author: Mike McHargue
title: Exceptional comfort and noise cancellation
content:
I was a loyal Bose QuietComfort user for years, but after reading a review of these new Sony headphones, I had to give them a shot. They're nearly perfect--easy to recharge, long battery life, comfortable on long flights, good-enough sound quality, and truly amazing noise cancellation. The bass is a bit loud and indistinct for my tastes, but that's popular these days.

My only complaint is the touch controls. The gestures are difficult to memorize, and the headphones don't offer much in the way of tactile feedback. I'd prefer actual buttons.

author: Telos
title: wow  Noise Cancelling to the extreme
content: great sound even better  Noise Cancelling. I do wish the cord were 1-2 feet longer.

author: Straitpaper
title: Hands down the best Bluetooth and noise canceling headphones out here period!
content: Worth every dime love the quality of sound and comfort fits great

author: Migs
title: Perfect for trips
content: Got these for my long trips and they far surpass other noise cancelling headphones I've had. Love the touch pad for volume control and track selection. Most headphones make my ears hurt after too long but these fit perfectly, and the sound quality is superb. I should note that there is in fact a bit of sound bleed at higher volumes.

author: Art Dude
title: Noice cancelling is amazing
content: I purchased and compared these to the Bose 700. Bose would be my next choice. I tested these on a construction site  with very loud sounds. The noise cancelling function works on about 90% of the frequencies. I think both headphones can't fully eliminate the high frequencies but at least lowers the amplitude. I've yet to test these on an airplane. The touch gestures on the right side are cool too. Highly recommended. I just wish Sony could achieve full noise cancelling ability or offer an in-app equalizer solution to customize it.

author: Justin
title: Great headphones if you're willing to pay
content:
Really comfy headphones. My first nice pair. Ears dont get too hot. Noise cancellation is insanely good. Bad parts, The earcup is made of the same material of other headphones I've had that starts to peel after a while. Hopefully these dont.

One other bad thing is it only can pair with one device. Didnt think this would be an issue but I would to be able to link to my phone and laptop.

author: robert
title: being a commercial driver this is a wonderful headset
content: Battery life is excellent

author: ramana sandi
title: best so far
content: tried and tested most of the headphones in this price range and found this one to to be the best.

author: Amazon Customer
title: GOOD SOUND
content: THE BEST

author: Mary
title: Works great on getting rid of the natural white noise and on a plane.
content: Very comfortable fit. Charges well with my same Google Pixel phone charger. Travel case was sleek and easy to pack. Worked really well in the airport and on the airplane. Could still hear chatter around me but not that bad and only when I didn't have music or an audio book playing. Really nice features for interacting with headphones vs having to pull out your device (i.e. changing songs, taking calls)

author: Colin F.
title: Headband Cracking Issues
content: I loved these headphones for the first 3 months, then the headband began cracking. The cracks, while small, impact the sound experience by introducing a scratching noise when I jostle my head. I would avoid these headphones until this issue is resolved.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Best overall
content: I've tried a few different brands and these are my favorite.
