I walked home that day with pair of these headphones. 2 months later and they look as good as new, despite my inclination to abuse electronics.

I've enjoyed these headphones immensely, so much in fact, that I ended up purchasing another pair for my dad's enjoyment. He's more of an audiophile than I am, and immediately, he noticed that the sound quality was excellent. He absolutely loves the headphones as well!

author: Veronique Demers
title: Top of line headphones
content: I previously owned the Bose QC 35 and these are even better!!

author: sara
title: Does the job. Best in market.
content:
Comparing with Bose

Music 10/10
Movies 10/10
Noise canceling 10/10
Comfort and fit 10/10
Phone calls 6/10
Ease of use 7/10

I am a frequent traveler and noise cancelation is what I care about the most. Phone calls afford to be better.

author: Ivan
title: Major Flaw - Unable to speak to converse with microphone and listen to other audio at the same time.
content: Noise cancellation and noise quality is superb as you can probably see from many reviews. The major flaw is lack of microphone support. The headset is unable to function both as a microphone/speaker as well as listen to background programs at the same time in a computer. Meaning, if you're program for the microphone/speaker (discord/skype) is separate from your other programs, such as games, then you won't hear your games! This is due to a bluetooth limitation, which you can read about online. If the program you want to listen to includes the voice co-op, then you won't have an issue. There's no separate auxiliary slot for the microphone also. Important limitation for something so pricey.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great noise canceler, very comfy on ears, sound quality just okay
content:
Very comfortable on ears over multiple hours of use, and very, very competent at canceling noise. In a noisy café, totally cancels out ventilation hum and other background noise, leaving only some faint remnants in the form of people's talk etc. At home, very effectively cancels out random baby noises, including crying. Haven't tried in a jet yet. Material quality top notch - and very lightweight. Battery life could not be batter.
Now to sound quality: kind of OK, at most. Nowhere close to my wired Sennheisers ($200 from Massdrop). Require equalizer to be applied immediately out of the box, to get the highs back - by default these headphones will totally muffle the music. But - I listen at low volume anyway, and so I don't really feel like it hurts me.
Some people report problems with microphone - I didn't have issues when talking both on Skype and over cellular. People didn't complain about me being quiet any more than they would with my wired AKG earplugs with microphone.

author: Mulch54
title: Amazing
content: These are downright amazing. They sound great, are really easy to use, and the noise canceling is unbelievable. The only Issue is that the microphones are not all that great in voice calls.  That might just be with the noise canceling working so well, I had no idea how loud the environment was.

author: dan
title: Old product in new product box!! Very sneaky.
content:
Swapped with old product in new box!!
Ordered the new Sony ...xm3. Spent the most on a set of head phones ever in my life. After waiting like a child for the ice cream truck they came in. The finish was sub par. The charging port was old micro usb not new type c fast charging. They looked very cheap, like I’d be semi-happy paying $39 if they would turn on.
After making myself ok with old charging port i tried them on. They wouldn’t power up. That was all i did to review them.

I have asked for money back and will return them.

author: AmazonCustomer
title: So so, no worth for $349
content: I don't really recommend these headphones. The sound quality is similar to the cheaper one.

author: Amazon Customer
title: My subjective experience
content: I thoroughly enjoy the sound cancelling, and the fun bells and whistles of the touch device. It’s great to go for walks and relax with them on. I like the fact that they cover the whole ear. The few negatives are that it’s really hard to consistently quickly pause music with the head piece touch device. Also if you have slightly bigger ears it will put some pressure on them causing discomfort. If you have multiple devices you have to sync them and it doesn’t automatically sync to both. It gets hot pretty quickly in my experience even when I am sitting at a desk and at this point I just let myself sweat on them. You have to wipe them down with a damp cloth if you want to maintain the padding. If you like slightly more bass than the Bose I would also get these headphones.

author: Kurt Schwind
title: Feels great, battery is incredible, noise canceling is amazing, sound is really good
content:
I think it's just part of how Sony profiles their headphones, but the sound for a wide variety of music is really good, but not really great.  Where as the noise canceling is like turning the world around  you off.  Just astounding.  The comfort is really nice.  I wear headphones for multiple hours a day (sometimes as much as 4 or 5 continuously) and these never strain my ears or feel uncomfortable.

Probably my largest "complaint" is the "clever" control surface on the outside of ear cup.  The two buttons are fine and easy to find, but the gestures methods are just 'ok'.  I've skipped songs I'm trying to change the volume on and I've tapped my headphones over and over to try and pause or unpause.

It's a minor complaint on what have become my favourite pair of headphones.

author: db
title: Better than Bose
content:
After weeks of research and comparison, I bought a pair of Sony WH1000XM3.  A week later, my wife surprised me with a pair of Bose QC 35s (forgetting that I had already purchased the Sony's).  I opened the Bose QC in order to test them, figuring I would keep the better of the two and sell the others.

The reviews I had read were pretty much even between the two.  Nothing really gave me confidence that one was better for my uses or my preferences than the other.  Now after having both, I can say that I strongly prefer and recommend the Sony over the Bose.

First and foremost - the sound out of the Sony WH1000XM3 is not only better, but you can customize it using the app.
 Tweak everything about the sound in the app.  This is, to me the biggest point because the Bose QC 35's are surprisingly lacking in bass.  I own a pair of Bose SoundSports which are great for working out, with great bass right out of the box - which is why I was so surprised that the QC would pack less of a punch than their in-ear buds.  The Sony WH1000XM3 out of the box sounds good, but the ability to customize the sound through the equalizer in the app is a huge advantage over the Bose QC 35s.

The touch controls on the Sony are great as well.  Intuitive and responsive.  The controls on the Bose are straight forward and work fine, but I do like the ability to just reach up and swipe, tap, or put my hand over the ear cup to hear the ambient sounds as opposed to finding the right button (first world problem, I know, but it is a great feature).

The noise canceling is indistinguishable to me.  Both work great.  I could not tell a difference as I switched between the two of them while watching TV, or observing the kids while arguing.  I wore the Sony for a 2.5 hour flight with no fatigue or discomfort at all.  Not sure about the Bose, but I don't think they would cause any issues or discomfort - they feel pretty much the same on the head/ears.

A couple additional small wins for Sony:
The fact that the case comes with small sectioned off areas separated by cloth for your 3.5mm jack and USB.  Bose does not have this, which means you can use the pocket on the cover (one inside and one outside) but if you use the one inside the cords are pressed into the ear cups.
Sony uses USB-C.  No guessing which side is up when plugging into the headphones to charge.
Sony comes with an Airplane jack adapter.  Even though most airlines use the single prong input now, it's nice to have, just in case.

If Bose had an equalizer, the sound could most likely be made to be equal, if not better than the Sony.  But the equalizer feature on the Sony WH1000XM3 enables me to really dial in the sound, leaving the Bose sounding flat in comparison.  That alone puts them over the top for me.  The additional features alone would not be enough for me to accept inferior quality, but I don't have to.  All of it together puts Sony way out ahead in my opinion.

author: Richard Hwang
title: Cumbersome process to switch between laptop and phone
content: The lack of multi device Bluetooth connection is a pain. Unlike the Bose you have to disconnect from your laptop to connect to your phone.

author: Victor Gonzalez
title: Excelente producto entrega antes de tiempo
content:
Muy buen nivel de NC. Es perfecto como se puede nivelar para escuchar ambiente, voces y música. 100% Nuevo.
Entrega por DHL estaba pensado en que llegaría el 7 de Diciembre, llegó el 22 de Noviembre.

author: KBR
title: I see they are on sale right now 6/6, buy it now!
content:
Excellent!!  Beautiful sound quality. Exposes old 320 kilobit mp3s for what they are!  Trash!!  Made for lossless digital audio.

Only con is with noise canceling on, any sudden head movement causes noticeable bass warble (ie head banging to your favorite metal tunes)

author: K in CA
title: Horrible echo when trying to use mic function
content: If you only use this when listing to music it is equal or maybe a little better than the Bose QC35. DO NOT BUY IF YOU WANT TO USE THE **MIC** Each time I made a call with the mic feature, over Bluetooth, the other side of the call complained about horrible echo from my end. I tried, over several different devices and calling different people, with each reporting the problem. It makes these headphones useless if you need to make/receive a call while wearing them. The QC35's had no problem being both a noise canceling headset and a headset for calls.

author: Dave
title: Great Headphones
content:
These are great, the sounds canceling is amazing, I force my coworkers to wear them who don't believe me when I say I can't hear them talking to me.  There is a nice walking feature where it will allow some sounds in and you can set how sensitive this is, so I set it to only play voices close to me.

Very happy, would buy again

author: Adolfo Haro
title: Bar has been raised!
content: Look no further if you need the best wireless noise cancelling headphone. Purchased these as office noise was beginning to get tiresome and boy am i glad i got these! Once you put them you will forget where you are. Was a bit concerned about build quality after reading the reviews of the 2nd generation versions, but i have not run into any of those issues. Happy customer.

author: Abdulrahman
title: it is not compatible with Sony TV
content: does not work with Sony TV.

author: yalaska
title: The best ..
content:
I had beats Studio 3 .. which my wife "borrowed"
so I thought I would get the sony ... and that was a good decision.. it is much more comfortable (like someone is hugging you ears) . sound is perfect and battery lasts forever  ..

worth every dollar

author: Meghan Snyder
title: Highly recommend
content: These headphones are amazing. I use them when my husband is watching TV and I want to listen to audiobooks, or when I’m walking the dogs, and they almost eliminate all background noise. They’re easy to navigate with the touch pad on the right headphone, and the noise optimization feature is amazing to change the level of noise canceling in various environments.

author: Tunde D
title: Absolute Block Out of Noise
content: This product immerses me in my own world, shut out from everything else. Quite an experience and very good value for the money.

author: Olly
title: Microphone is not great but noice cancelling feature and sound is fantastic!
content: The only reason I'm giving 4/5 is because of the microphone, I used it at work and almost everyone is reporting crackling sound issues from my end. When using any other headphones it works fine but the mic quality is very disappointing, especially when you use a soft phone on your computer for daily phone calls.

author: greattherapy
title: The best of the best
content: Absolutely the best headphones on the market not only are they very nice to look at but they sound amazing and the noise cancelling is the best out there.

author: DadMan
title: Great Headphones, Mostly
content:
Pros:  The headphones sound great.  Noise cancelling is superb.  They are comfy.  I use them as a phone headset a lot.  That is where battery life shines.  They run all day with plenty of charge to spare.  The phone audio is just what I needed.  Listening over a mediocre phone connection to a person who's English accent is way different than mine as always been a serious communication issue for both of us.  These headphones help that a lot on my end.  They won't clean up a bad signal but they will kill all the background noise and keep the pieces of the call transparent.  Of course, they work great for music or plugged into Roku for TV.

Meh:  They are called silver but most of the color is beige.  Not a fan of beige but they look OK.

Cons:  When using Sony's Adaptive Sound Control (on by default) in the Sony Android app, the geniuses @ Sony decided they needed to mute the incoming audio and chime in your ears for a second every time they adjust the headphones to adapt to ambient sound changes.  Most sound people I know would endure torture before introducing noise (the chime sound) and muting the audio signal on purpose.  For reference, this happens even when all I do is walk across a relatively quite house.  This renders Adaptive Sound Control completely useless.  For me, I leave Adaptive Sound Control off and only use Noise cancellation which does not do that.  It took me half an hour to figure out what it was.  What were they thinking???  It doesn't show up on the Android notification screen so it's hard to figure out what is causing it.  I can turn it off so I'm good.
The documentation is skimpy too.

Once I'm over the hurdles of learning the new product, Happy Camper!

author: Debra J. Olson Heintz
title: Love these
content: These were amazing on my last flight. It was like the plane went away

author: cvictor
title: Fantastic buy for music lovers
content: Solid buy! 12 hrs of battery life if not more. Sounds fantastic. Extremely comfortable. And sound cancelation is bar none to other headphones I've tried. Volume control and fastforward/backward is a bit finicky, and sometimes I have a little trouble opperating the app. Overall, best headphones I've ever bought, worth every penny

author: Xælias
title: Doesn't sound like $350 headphones. Not worth that price.
content:
I'll start by saying that I'm by no mean an aficionado of wireless headphones. I never really owned any. And I don't mind using my good old wired jack headphones.
Nevertheless, even I can't deny that something like ANC (Active Noise Cancelling) is useful when in a plane, or even outside.

Now, these cost $350 (+tax) at the time of this review. And I honestly have a hard time believing this is the finished product for that price and for the third iteration of that model.

The good:
• They're very light (see a cons to that below)
• They fold
• USB-C charging
• Good battery life (for the 2 days I tested them)
• In my opinion, rather good looking (although I really don't care that much)
• Actually really good touch controls.
• ANC is rather good also. But I don't have any point of comparison here...
And... that's it I'm afraid :-/

The bad:
• They're so light they feel really cheap
• Bassy is an understatement
• They sound... flat. No precision. No dynamics. Bass is overwhelming and everything ends up being a mellow that lacks any sort of clarity.
• Bluetooth is still not good enough. Maybe BT 5 will improve the situation (these are BT 4 if I'm not mistaking). But in the meantime, these still drop the connection every so often for half a second or something (I'm talking multiple times an hour)
• They added mics for the ANC on this version. So much so that you can hear the WIND as feedback when the ANC kicks in... I'm not buying ANC headphones to hear the wind ><
• Android app doesn't work (more details below)

All in all. These are $350 headphones that are bluetooth (which, in my opinion, brings more issues that is fixes, I don't care about the wire, and I have to charge these, and suffer the unreliability of BT. Also they are not even BT multipoint so... can't have them paired with multiple devices...). But they don't sound the part. And the ANC is faulty.

Also, at the time of release, the Android app is not updated. If you download whatever the current version was, it would complain that it's not compatible with this version, and prompt you to update it. Except there is no update available.

So all in all. Mostly a bad experience all around. The sound is not good enough. The app doesn't work. BT is still crappy. And ANC can't survive any medium amount of wind (which is a daily thing where I live).
I didn't own them long enough to really judge battery life and charging time I'm afraid.

PS:
I currently own and use (for different use-cases/places):
• Sennheiser HD8 DJ - ~$400 in 2014, ~$220 today) - Sennheiser HD 8 DJ Headphones
• Sennheiser HD 6xx - ~$200
• beyerdynamic DT 770 PRO (250Ω) - ~$170 - beyerdynamic DT 770 Pro 250 ohm Limited Edition Professional Studio Headphone

author: emmanuel
title: BEST NOICE CANCELLATION
content: I loved every single thing about these headphones incredible noice cancellation10/10

author: S. Mc
title: Nice headphones, with great software capabilities to tweak NC and audio.
content:
See below for update!

So far, my experienced is mixed.  The current version of the Sony Headphone Connect app on iOS doesn’t support these.  Talk about poorly planned release. So, none of the advance capabilities are available, and therefore are currently basic Bluetooth headphones with noise cancelling....that you can’t adjust.  Fortunately, the default NC profile is good, and they do sound good.  Also, they are lighter than the XM2s, but the headband feels more solidly built.  I think they also sound better (clarity, dynamics, bass) than the XM2 and QC35.  Comfort is very good, not quite as good as Bose QC35, but pretty close.

Update: about 12hrs after posting this, Sony has released the updated software to the iOS App Store.  Works great with the software.  Allows for tweaking and calibration of NC, eq, etc.  sweet.

author: Jake
title: Only for listening to music no calls
content: Okay so I originally bought the Microsoft surface headphones for the same price. The battery on those was only lasting about 12 hours vs the advertised 15 so I returned them and got these. Let me say the noise cancelling is slightly better however so huge key issues made me return these and go back to the surface headphones. The biggest issue was the mic on this. On calls I had to constantly hold my phone to my mouth otherwise people would say they couldn’t hear me. Another huge issue was whenever I was in a call the noise cancelling would stop. I bought these for cancelling noise during calls primarily as we are all in agile environment at work. Those two issues made this unusable for me and I feel if I am spending $350 for headphones I should not regret my purchase and miss features. If you just want these for litesning to music and cancelling noise these would be very good, however if you plan on using for calls at all, pass and go for the surface headphones.

author: Omar
title: Really impressive and worth every dollar
content:
Worth every dollar ( I got them for $298). I fly a lot and it made huge difference.  Some flights are 12+ hours and still not annoyed.
When I tried some of the cheaper ones, I knew that this one really worth the money,

author: Steven
title: Good Product!
content: Good Product!

author: Jose Tapia
title: If not accustomed to noise canceling don't be alarmed of the sensation.
content: I love how comfortable they are.

author: mohamed gamal
title: Powerful headphones
content: Very nice

author: Kris Carter
title: Amazing sound quality and noise canceling
content: Sony hit the nail on the head with these.  I was hesitant to spend so much on Sony but decided to give it a try. I own beats studio and Bose wired noise canceling headphones.  These are a perfect balance with great noise canceling. Sound quality is amazing. I have only had a couple days and don’t notice I’m wearing them. I was a little worried about using these when answering my phone based off others reviews, but the phone calls sound crystal clear and no problem with the mic picking up my voice.  The touchless panel took a min to get use to with swiping for sound and tapping for song changes. Not sure how well the touch panel will work if hands are sweaty. Overall I am super happy with what Sony has done.  I will update my review if anything changes in the future. Until then I will enjoy these as my go to headphones.

author: Jean Mark
title: Compra Perfecta
content: Despues de 1 mes de uso puedo afirmar que valió totalmente la pena.

author: tx
title: Great but with one drawback
content: Best in the class sound and noise cancelation. But it is painful to switch between devices like other BOSE product.

author: Amr El-Madah
title: Great product
content: Noice cancellation is great, no weak point till now

title: Calidad de sonido
content: Excelente sonido

author: Doctor.Generosity
title: Great sound, but won't Bluetooth
content: These have great sound - when they connect, which is almost never. Great difficulty getting Bluetooth connection to my iPads, computer, etc. Big waste of time.

author: Tabitha
title: Worth every penny!
content: These headphones are amazing and the features are awesome! More than what we were expecting!

author: Matthew
title: Great battery life
content: Great on the airplane.

author: Loving Life
title: Best headphones available on the market
content:
A Completely Honest Review on the Sony WH-1000XM3s

These headphones are easily one of the best headphones anyone should own because they are truly worth every penny.  I used to own a pair of Apple Beats Studio 3s which did have ANC but they were over $300 and the ANC quality was very poor.  I then went ahead and returned them and bought Airpods (2nd Gen).  They worked great with my iPhone and Macbook but it just didn’t fit well enough in my ear and it didn’t have ANC.  I began my research and found that many sources claim that the Sonys either met or exceeded the Noise Cancellation quality of the Bose NC700.  I also found that the Sonys have great sound quality, excellent bass, and an app that can allow you access to the headphones customization features.  After buying them, I went through all of the features and tested them out to see why these headphones had such great comments.  I setup my headphones for the first time which was a breeze (not as easy as setting up my airpods, but it was relatively easy).  As soon as I put the headphones on, they were extremely comfortable, all ambient noises and voices were minimized, and there was Google Assistant on the headphones.  I could control my lights, robot vacuum, and many other household items.  These headphones are amazing.  I tried using them for calls and voice recordings, but the mic on the headphones were really poor, but that is not what I bought them for.  I could charge these headphones with my Macbook charger and the battery life of these headphones were out of this world.  I actually look forward to putting these headphones on because of their quality and comfortability.  This is a great buy if you travel a lot (like if you are constantly on flights), in school, or just for anything really.  These headphones are truly a must buy and I recommend these headphones over any others on the market.

author: Travis
title: Uncomfortable
content: I came from the qc25’s. These are much heavier. They aren’t super comfortable. Maybe I’m just a pansy. The Bluetooth wouldn’t work right with my games and battle.net talking with friends. I had to wire them up and then they worked great. Sound is great. I liked the app functions, being able to turn certain things up or down. The noise cancellation is the best I’ve experienced. The biggest problem for me is they hurt my head. I use headphones for 10+ hours a day sometimes and the cool features don’t out weigh the comfort.  Returning and going back to the lightweight qc25s

author: EDL86
title: AMAZING sound and noise cancel
content: Great for travel, Lightweight. Pure noise cancellation

author: Michael Shapiro
title: Very good noise cancelling
content: Excellent noise cancelling, very good base . Google assistant  operates well.

author: Heather
title: Fantastic until you try to use it wired
content: Quality-wise, this is a really nice step up from the XB950N1 that I use primarily. I enjoy bassy music, and if you crank up the Clear Bass setting to +10 it gives you a really solid, tight resounding bass that is about 95% as strong as what the bass-focused XB950N1 produces (and which actually has better bass than the new XB900N which is also bass-focused) with the benefit of having noticeably clearer mids and trebles. It's more comfortable, and it has superior noise reduction. Why then would I rate it only 3 stars? IT IS UNUSABLE WIRED. Despite being able to plug in with the 3.5mm cable and despite keeping it powered on, all equalizer functionality is permanently and forcibly DISABLED while wired. The Clear Bass? Gone. And there's literally no way to turn it back on except to unplug the wire. I use my headset on multiple devices and I want it to sound identical without fidgeting with equalizers, and to be honest even with fidgeting I can't get it to sound quite the same as simply having the Clear Boost at +10. I shouldn't have to fight the headset just because I want to listen on a PC. The old XB950N1 saves the equalizer settings in the headset and keeps them active while plugged in, so why was this functionality removed? Makes no sense. It ruins an otherwise perfect upgrade for me. If Sony was to release an update to allow the EQ settings to operate while plugged in I would gladly change this to a 5-star rating and purchase two sets of headphones (one for my wife and one for me). But for now, it's returned. I need something which easily works on my phone as well as my PC. This isn't it.

author: David M. Syndergaard
title: Sound is great; not the best option for workouts
content: These headphones are easy to pair and have excellent sound, but they don't fit tight enough to be a safe alternative for active workouts.  The first time I wore them to the gym, I sat up after doing a set of dumbbell bench presses, and the headphones slipped off my head and onto the floor.  Luckily, I was able to pick them up before someone stepped on them.  They weren't sweaty, they just don't have a tight fit.  I'll update my review in the future if I have any other issues or comments.

author: Tiffany
title: Another cracked headset
content: I wear headphones while gardening and cleaning around the house. Nothing more. Received as a birthday gift in February. I was admittedly disappointed when I got them because I had my heart set on Bose QC. The first listen gave me comfort because the sound on the Sony headset was incredible. I loved the app and being able to customize my listening experience. My happiness was short-lived. Cracks developed in IDENTICAL places above the left and right ear where the adjustment slider moves in and out. The cracks were a problem because they pulled my hair a bit, but not really a deal breaker. Now the adjustment slider is useless and the housing for the wiring is no longer secure. According to Sony, this is not covered under the warranty, but they want me to send pictures. If they replace them, I will update but based on other reviews, I am not hopeful.

author: Amazon_Customer520
title: Worth the money if you commute publicly
content:
I fly quite a bit for work/personally (upwards of 6 flights per month) and so once my old Bose QC25's broke, I sat on the idea of getting these for longer than I should have.

I do think they're overpriced, but they are the best on the market right now and are the same price as the QC35s by Bose. I find these have better ANC, much better battery, and SIGNIFICANTLY better sound quality.

In terms of comfort, I did a 3 hour test in the house and while my ears sweated profusely, they didn't hurt like they would with the Bose. Doing a 14 hour flight next month, can update again next month. At least I know the battery will last!

My one wish was that they got a little louder.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Amazing headsets!
content: Awesome

author: Amazon Customer
title: The best headphones
content: They are great for noise cancelling but not for voice cancelling. If someone is talking normal and you have the music playing you can barely hear them. The touch system might be the best feature they have. If you're listening to music and want to switch to the next song, it's just a simple swipe of the finger on the headphone.

author: Landy
title: Gr8 product
content: Got mine used only thing I found wrong with it is the box had a little damage, also European plug and the charging cable is a bit short. All minor problems. No problem.

author: mlsw
title: Sony 1 Bose 0
content:
Bose has its work cut out for them.  I’m a fan of Bose and own many of their items, including their latest Sleep Buds and Sound Bars... etc. When it comes to ANC headphones, I’ve been with them from day 1, owner pretty much everything in their line up. From QC20’s to QC35(I). I never thought i’ll go another way but Sony, with the 1000MX3 did just that.

I skipped upgrading to the QC35(II) because most of the reviews share that ANC and sound did not change much and to be honest, I was perfectly happy with them. In fact, just used them on a 12 hour flight from Singapore to Germany.

However, after reading so many reviews on the Sony, I decided to give it a try. I took around 3 trips to the local Sony store, trying and playing around with it before I decided to buy it. Trying it at the store, I wasn’t really to tell the difference between the Bose. Probably because I wasn’t able to play my music and the demo set wasn’t set up with the Sony Headphones App. Despite of not being able tell a big difference, I decided to take the plunge anyway. This was a risk because in Singapore, returns are not allowed.

After testing the Sony and Bose side by side, at home with plenty of time, I’m happy to say that the MX3 was worth the upgrade.

I won’t go into details here but for me, the main difference is the Sony sounded better and had better ANC. With the EQ off, the Sony already sounded clearer, with more sound stage and the mids and bass are well balanced. After adjusting the EQ with the manual mode, it sounded even better. The bass was noticeably punchier compared to the Bose. As for ANC, my home is pretty quite aside from a bit of air con noise so I can’t say it’s a significant difference but I did notice a slight improvement. I’ll off to a another 12 flight next week so I’m looking to trying it on the plane, will probably bring my QC to compare just for fun.

This is exciting because I’m sure Bose is aware of what the competition is bringing to the table so I’m curious to see what they will launch to regain the throne! If it’s better, I’ll probably switch back to them because I like Bose for many years but till then, I’m my humble opinion, Sony just has a better product as of today.

Thanks for reading!

author: Kkillian71
title: Only Music. Nothing Else... All is Fixed
content:
Edit the seconding: I was able to get in contact with Sony. They replaced the headset within a week and the second pair works perfectly. The call quality issues were fixed and they perform just as well in all other regards. I am going to adjust my rating from 3 to 5 stars.

Edit: I have found that this issue is not repeatable when calling through Skype or Whatsapp. When using the built in phone dialer for IOS and Android the issue with the hallway/echo occurs. When using a VOIP service the calls come through crystal clear on both ends.

I received my headphones yesterday and I have been very impressed. The sound quality and noise cancellation is very well done. There is just one issue from making them great. It is impossible to make a phone call through them. It sounds like I am down a hallway when talking. I have been told that the person on the other end could hear an echo of themselves better than the they can hear me. So far the tagline seems to be right "Only Music. Nothing Else".

author: Ahsen Abro
title: Requires manual connecting and Add to sound devices every time out of range or charging.
content:
Required to manually Connect and then Add to my sound devices every time I fall out of range or charge the headphones.

Unlike Bose QC 35, Sony WH 1000XM3 does not automatically reconnect every time you lose the Bluetooth signal and then return back or when you put the headphones on a charge.

In both instances, you have to open the Windows 10 Settings window to re-connect the headphones as a Bluetooth device AND then connect the device by opening the Control Panel Sound devices and press Connect.

Oftentimes now, upon not using the headphones for a while, the sound gets jittery.

And yes,  have the latest firmware, drivers, Windows updates, and have re-started Windows many times.

There is no direct Sony support email address (another negative point), so I have learned as much as I can from Sony forums and many other sources, but have been unable to solve this issue.

I use Avantree Bluetooth 4.0 dongle.

I regret purchasing these and would never recommend these to a friend.

Sound quality and Noise-canceling is a bit better than Bose QC35's, but for the aforementioned huge negatives, the positives pale in comparison.

author: Tiancheng Liu
title: Pros & cons
content: Not so easy to adjust volume or pause/start music. Noise cancelling is amazing,  definitely worth the price.

author: RE
title: Poor volume control
content:
Sound quality and noise canceling are good, but the lack of good volume control is disappointing.
1.  The device has voice prompts.  The manual indicates that these can be turned off.  However, the off setting doesn't turn them all off.  There is no volume control of the voice prompts.  They're unpleasantly LOUD.
2.  The volume control increment is just the same as Android.  No finer.  My 65$ Jabra Move has a better, finer adjustment.

author: James H Berry
title: A quality product
content: Fit and comfort were great. I had Bose in the past and think these are superior in noise cancellation. Thus far these are more durable than the Bose as well.

author: Gatlin
title: Glad I got these over the Bose
content:
Sound quality is fantastic. With the app you can tune the eq to exactly how you like the music.

Battery life is fantastic. Didn't even charge them for over a week after I unboxed them at 40%. Used probably 12 hours, until charging.

Comfort is fantastic. I wore them on a 5 hour bus ride and never got tired of them. They can be a bit warm, but in the winter I prefer that.

5/5

author: Aditya Dhar
title: An almost perfect pair of headphones
content: These headphones are absolutely amazing. The noise cancelation is fantastic though with recent updates I feel that voices are far more distinct that they used to be. While the Bose series always has this strange pressure feel, I barely every noticed any of that on the Sony’s and if anything they actually have better noice canceling than them. That being said, I think that this pair of headphones are still the best that you can buy right now. The sound quality is amazing and the bass isn’t too overwhelming but it’s quite pronounced for an enjoyable experience. The fit in general is very good though the ear-cups could have been a little more spacious. Right now the inner padding can be a little bit annoying as it it touches my ears and warms up after long periods of time.

Wow!!!!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Good to go
content: Love these for traveling on planes. Cancels out all the surrounding people and air noise

author: lawrence smith
title: Thank you
content: Everything is great asept for phone calls

author: Amazon Customer
title: Exactly what I wanted
content: The headphones are comfortable and great sound quality.  Worth the big price!

author: Devaunte White
title: The battery life is good.
content: The battery life is awesome.

author: Charles Noren
title: Surprised I can use it with gas-powered yard equipment
content:
I bought these headphones to have a top-notch set of Bluetooth headphones. I wanted good sound for classical music. I use it an noisy office environment (lots of people on conference calls). My expectations for the active noise cancellation (ANC) was relatively low. I have an early set of wired ANC headphones and they are okay and I didn't expect much improvement. I was pleasantly surprised. Here are my observations:
1. In the office environment, almost all voice and computer equipment were cancelled out. If I listen carefully, I might hear my cubical neighbor as though his is in a quiet room, far, far away. With quiet classical music, I can't hear him at all.
2. I tired these headphones with my gas powered lawn mower. While I heard the lawn mower over the headphones, it was like it was several houses away in my neighborhood. I could play podcasts on low volume. I was very pleasantly surprised about this.
3. I can hear wind against my headphones. It doesn't prevent me from listening to podcasts, but I was surprised by the amount of wind sound given the headphone performance in other areas.
4. In default mode, the headphones does a good job of adjusting the noise cancellation in my environment. In the office, it did maximum mode. When walking outside, it adjusted so I could hear traffic (important, I was walking on a street without sidewalks). The only issue on automatic adjustment was mowing the lawn. I had to manually set it to maximum noise cancellation.
5. I love that I can cup the right headphone to hear someone talk to me. My only issue is that it turns the volume down instead of pausing the audio. Since I listen to a lot of podcasts, pausing would be a nice feature.
6. While the over-the-ear headphones are very comfortable, my ears are irritated after wearing for 90+ minutes. I have never found headphones that prevented this with my large ears -- but these are the most comfortable I ever tried.
7. The touch controls on the right headphone are okay. It is taking me a while to get used to them, especially the center pause area I find very tricky. I think in a few weeks they will become second nature to me, but it is taking a while.
8. I like the compact carrying case and how the headphones fold-up in it. Nice.
9. I like the wire earphone jack that comes with it. It goes into my PC and bypasses Bluetooth.
10. The phone microphone is only okay. It picks up the ambient noise around me more than like in phone conversations. In Skype calls, I have to be careful to mute my microphone when I am not talking, much more so than my cheap headphones. If I am in a shopping mall, it picks up a lots of the noise around me. Outside phone conversations in windy conditions are nearly impossible.
11. These headphones are not for all circumstances. I will not use them driving. I will not use them in sweaty exercise or workouts. I use AfterShotz Trekz Air in those situations, they don't block my ears and are sweat-proof.
12. I love the 30-hour battery life! -- and with quick charge feature.

Overall, I think these are the best for this kind of headphones on the market. They are expensive, and they are not for every situation. I believe that having several different kinds of headphones for the different situations and environments I'm in. Also, I have purchased through Amazon the 3 year extended warranty -- I have had enough problems with headphones in the past where this is useful. I would not purchase the extended warranty from Best Buy -- it is too expensive now. I think part of the problem is that too many people turn-in their headphones just before the warranty runs out to get the latest headphones. Unless there is a genuine problem with the headphones, I don't think that is ethically right to do.

author: Martin Zarza
title: This are very good headphones
content:
This headphones has a very good quality audio, its noice cancellation is very very amazing, despite sometimes you can hear a little bit the people that is near to you. It's comfortable, I wear it everyday at work for at least 6 hours.

A suggestion would be that the music doesn't stop when you take off your headphones, or when you put your hands over the right earcup.

But in general, I believe that you will get what you are paying for.

author: ShazaM
title: Surpasses BOSE in both noise cancelling and audio quality
content:
Bluetooth audio has come a long way since the olden days. With new codec technologies like aptx and ldac, audio transmission over Bluetooth is slowly reaching fidelity levels that are comparable to that of a wired connection. That's of course taking into consideration the source and quality of amplification on wired setups. But considering the fact that the trade off in having no cables comes at a sacrifice in sound quality, these Sony's do make that sacrifice a very small and one that is worthwhile.

Traveling with studio gear meant that I have to drown nosies by cranking up the volume which is not a good solution long term as it can potentially damage your hearing. One could argue that IEMs tend to solve that problem and that is true for those that are able to wear them comfortably for long periods of time. Unfortunately that had never been the case for me. My ear canals are rather small and I can only wear the smallest IEMs for less than an hour before itching and irritation occurs. Having custom IEMs built meant I would spend over $1000 for something worthwhile so I ditched them and moved on to cans early down the road.

I owned a pair of Bose quiet comforts for 5+ years and for the longest time they were my only option for noise cancelling. The only other option was the PXC550s that came down the road. I always knew that by taking my Bose with me it meant that I sacrifice sound quality for the sake of noise cancelling as my quiet comforts simply were no match to anything else studio level I listened to such as HD6xx, HD800s (granted both are open back) and the Fostex TH-X00's which are closed backs. I started shopping for an alternative and just as I was getting ready to pull the trigger on the PXC550s I saw the announcement that Sony was planning to release the XM3s. I had shyed away from the XM2s due to the scares of build quality and lack of USB-C support, the same reason I was reluctant to get the PXC500s. I decided to take a chance and get these and honestly I couldn't be any happier.

These headphones do two things very well. One is I find their noise cancelling ability much better than BOSE's. There's an odd feeling with BOSE that I don't get with the XM3s almost like a vacuum sensation. The second is their audio quality is not even comparable to the QCs by BOSE. BOSE's QC2.5 has a very muffled sound. Highs are very subdued, mids are grainy and lows are weak. The XM3s on the other hand provide a balanced but rather veiled sound. I find them a lot more enjoyable to listen to for long periods of time. Mids come off as a bit receded, highs are clear and lows are more refined. No these are not a bassheads dream but they hold their own fairly well for what they are aimed at. They are no match for the soundstage of something like the HD6xx or HD800s but those headphones also aren't closed back or noise cancelling so you are making a huge trade off. The strong noise cancelling more than makes up for that in my opinion. One key note for anyone considering getting these is that you want to be running Android 8.0 with LDAC support. I don't own any Apple devices so I can't speak to that as far as compatibility. But in order to get the most out of the sound codec you want to be running 32bit ~900k 96khz LDAC streaming over Bluetooth.

If you're in the market for Bluetooth noise cancelling headphones that utilize USB-C, these should be an insta-buy. You won't regret the premium investment.

author: TMohr
title: Poor quality for a high end ANC headphone from Sony.
content:
2-Sept update:  Since this review, I've learned that Sony sold a batch of headphones that are known to be problematic to 3rd-party resellers and has released Sony's warranty on my particular headphone.  This "dark ally deals" between Sony and 3rd party resellers are not transparent to their customers and both parties are washing their hands of this sub-par product.  This experience has been very disappointing.  I was a Sony fanboy in the 80s but have not purchased any premium products from Sony in favor of other premium consumer brands.  I was thrilled to give Sony another shot but I now regret my decision to do so.

I wanted to love this product but have to give it a 1 star because of its poor product quality.

I was a Bose QC fan before reading reviews about The Sony WH-1000XM3.  While I was happy with my wired Bose QC 25, I wanted a wireless ANC headphone and decided to buy this headphone 4 months ago.  At first, I was impressed with its audio quality and ANC (Active Noise Cancellation).  After two weeks of use, I started recommending this headphone to my friends and coworkers.  Since I work for a high tech company where the engineers work in an open space environment, my coworkers are always looking for ways to mute the ambient noises so that they can concentrate.  Three people bought this headphone based on my recommendation.  After using this product for four months, I am now regretting my decision to buy this product and for recommending it to others.  The headphone broke after 4 months of normal use, see photos.  I pulled out this headphone at work and learned that the left cup broke away from the headband with no way of reattaching the parts.  I find the hardware quality to be poor, especially for a high-end headphone that costs $350.  I was very disappointed with the product quality and thought that Sony's customer service could remedy the situation.  Similar to the product itself, the customer service experience is equally disappointing.  The service person gave me a web link to upload images of the broken headphone, which I did, and the web site said that Sony will get back to me in 24 hours.  I've not received any acknowledgement of my queries nor responses in 48 hours.  I find the entire experience to be unacceptable for a premium product.

I now need to replace this headphone with another premium wireless ANC headphone but I doubt I will replace it with another Sony product.

author: Amazon Customer
title: The best NC, but no the best for music listening
content:
The best noise cancelling, lightweight, touch control is OK, so better than QC35 in every aspect, maybe except call quality, I have not compared it yet.
I still prefer my old Sennheiser Momentum 2.0 wireless (aka OEBT) for music listening.

author: J. B.
title: Amazing
content: Amazing noise cancelling, sound, and battery life. Be sure to download the Sony app so you can play with the various sound stages and equalizer.

author: TP
title: You don't get what you pay for...
content:
As an avid gamer, streamer of various content and music listener I was really looking for an amazing pair of headphones. Sound quality was #1 on my focus and wireless was #2 as I liked the freedom that feature brought. Gone are the days of snagging my cord on something and snapping my neck b/c of it. All of the reviews I read pointed me to the Sony WH-1000XM3, so I bought it.

It hurt the heart to fork out $350 but the sound quality and wireless features should pay for itself in no time and as a bonus it has a "crystal-clear" mic. Sweet!

I first sync'd headset to my phone (LG G5) after downloading the app. Setup was simple and I was connected fairly quickly. Sound quality was good but it didn't blow my socks off. It's definitely heavy on the bass, which for games and most of my music, is good. The equalizer in the app allows for customization so you could tweak the sound however you like (e.g. turn down the bass).

Next, I connected the headset to my PC (which is where I spend most of my time) via the motherboard's on-board bluetooth connection. I fired up BF4 (and Destiny 2) and again, the sound was okay, but heavy on bass. Since there's no app on my PC, there's no EQ to use to adjust the sound. So that sucked. The touch controls also don't work very well on my PC. When using iTunes, I can turn the volume up and down, but the skip/next song (forward and back) controls don't work. I can hear a beep in the headset which means it recognizes the action, but nothing is happening. *sigh* Remember that "crystal-clear" mic, yeah that's a complete lie. It's bloody terrible. It cracks and fades in and out. I could actually hear background conversations better than the person who I was talking to.

The noise-cancellation feature works great! In fact, it's the best thing about this device. You can turn it off completely or have ambient sound on, which makes everything sound "tinny" or mechanical, so it's rather useless.

As others have said, the battery doesn't last 30 hours, but that could be due to it needing a break-in period. The cups also make your ears sweat after using them for a few hours. The material on the cups feels kind of thin and I don't think it will last very long even if I baby it. The platic construction helps keep the unit light but I expect that carrying it around for prolong periods will be a source of failure. So all-in-all, I just can't justifying keeping this device AND paying $350, but it's a name brand so of course that's an extra $100. O.o

author: Puppy
title: It is top of the line
content: This set is fantastic.  After paying extra for a Swiss Air flight from Europe, and listening to a 5 year old screaming the whole way, that was the end of my rope.  The parents were child babies also and just kept feeding the monster candy.  I wish airlines would ban children for 6 months if they misbehave, and parents if they can't control their children.  The controls on this are beautiful, they are light and comfortable, and my daughter grabs them for her commute.  Honestly, get the best and you will not regret it.

author: Chris J
title: Battery Issue is a huge dissapointment
content: This headphone will literally tell me that it is fully charged and 1 hour later it suddenly dropped to below 10%. charging it for 10 minutes and it will show me full charge again. frustrating as hell.

author: Rasalghoul
title: Far better sound than my Bose headphones.
content: Couldn't be happier. These are are 6 star worthy!

author: Russ Lowrey
title: Best headphones on the market
content: Worth the price for noise canceling.

author: Mack Huang
title: Good!!
content: Like it, and was the most excellent headphone ever use. Fashion and beautiful!

author: O. NeDroid
title: Can't seamlessly switch between two devices. Otherwise - brilliant
content:
These headphones have fantastic noise cancellation, are comfortable to wear, have great sound and a good Android and iOS apps for managing the device. The battery life is fantastic and charging via a USB-C port is fast. I can easily wear them for 1 1/2 days in the office and then quickly recharge during lunch.

I like it very much that it is possible to control how much sound comes from the outside (with an app). This works especially well when having a conversation over a phone or an IM. With simple noise-isolating phones you can't hear your own voice. With Sony phones, you can add a bit of your own voice (but not noise), which make a conversation more comfortable.

A fly in the ointment is that these headphones can't be easily connected to two devices. For example, it took me 5 minutes to connect the phones to iPad (they are usually connected to an Android phone). And then I had to go to the Sony app to help restore connection back to the phone next morning. Bose and Jabra devices do this with ease.

Overall, I like the quality, comfort and ease of use and would recommend these phones to those who don't care about frequent switches between devices.

author: Ryan T.
title: Nice set of headphones especially for travel
content: I use my headphones primarily for travel and have found them to be really comfortable for long flights.  The noise cancelling to me is most useful for cutting out the excessive 'white noise'  on the airplanes (most of the time not realizing how much there is until the noise cancelling is on).  I wouldn't go as far as others that say they can't hear anything around them or people speaking right near them, but if you have the noise cancelling on and sound at decent volume, it is certainly much harder to hear any outside noises.  I'm still trying to figure out if I feel these worth the price considering how much I use them, but I can't complain about the quality of the product so far.

author: Kenneth R. Nestle
title: A good  $50 headphone. $350, no way!
content:
Battery life - Nowhere near 30 hours.
Noise cancellation - I couldn't notice any.
Ergonomics - Buttons WAY too small / hard to find.
Documentation - None.
Setup instructions - None.

I'm trying to use these withh a PC. When I found documentation / instructions on-line, it's all for smartphone!?

author: A. Adams
title: not worth it
content: bluetooth gives out several times a session & the touch controls are unwieldy (they also don’t work in the cold) - should work better for the price

author: Customer 117
title: BOSE CQ35 VS SONY
content:
BOSE CQ35 VS SONY

I travel on planes a lot and workout even more so I need a headphone that can do both.

These have better sound quality and noise cancellation (plus more advanced optimization) than Bose cq35s.

However, the downfall is that the touch panel glitches on occasion.  The earpad material heats up quickly and gets hot compared to bose. The headband portion gets painful if slightly too tight. My biggest problem is i can't put these around my lower neck. The noise side only turns so your shoulders block the audio and your chin/cheek turn off/pause your music if you move your head with it around your neck.

Overall: better sound/customization than bose. Worse material.
Wear bose to gym. Wear these anywhere else.

author: jackifus
title: Great Sound, great isolation
content:
These headphones perform three functions for me:
- music listening
- audiobook listening
- digital piano sound isolation
- telephone meetings
They sound great - and bluetooth AAC sounds great from my Apple devices.
They stay connected with a clear signal about 40-ish feet away from the source device

My digital piano is next to the television, so when my wife watches TV - I practice piano.  I needed a headphone that could isolate my piano music from the TV... These do the job better than sound isolating headphones like DirectSound ex29 - which I also own... I *can* hear the TV, it's just so minimized so as to not be a bother.
I use these headphones wired with the digital piano.

The headphones work wired or bluetooth ... and in wired mode, can work passively.
The sound quality suffers radically when they are unpowered - I don't use them that way... I'd consider that an emergency feature, so you'll never be without sound.

They work fine as a telephone headset.  Not great, not bad.  I hear fine, and never have had a complaint about my voice, but I'd say apple AirPods make the person speaking sound clearer. But not bad.

I like that you can adjust the amount and kind of noise cancelation you'd like ... I usually use them with it 100% on, but if you want ambient sound to be let in, you can do that ...

I like the double-tap the right cup to pause/play music

I find the on/off button a bit more difficult to use than the Bose switch... you have to press and hold the button on these - and it's not that easy to find, because there are two buttons... (the other is for the ambient sound mode).

I'd rather have a physical on-off switch rather than a press-to-hold button

The performance of these phones are great - I'm enormously satisfied.

The comfort is better than okay - and worse than great.  I think my Bose QC-15's are a bit more comfortable - not because they are softer, these are similarly soft, but because these get a bit hot.  I thought they got too hot the first couple of times I used them, then I was no longer bothered ... I did buy cloth covers for the pads - (but since I got used to the phones, I stopped using the covers.). So... hot enough that I thought I needed covers, but good enough that I don't use them... if that makes sense.

Overall, I'm very very pleased

author: Owlsgone
title: Bass has no nuance.
content:
Disappointed.  The frequencies do not mesh at all.  There’s everything but the bass that sounds great and separated.  Then there’s the bass.  Turned up and distorted.  For the price, it’s a little bit meh given the lack of nuance in the bass.

Listening on an iPhone so maybe it gets better elsewhere.

author: Phyllis McFadden
title: Five Stars
content: Used recently in a noisy hospital while staying overnight with my daughter. It was a lifesaver....

author: Alexander Cheung
title: Great battery life and quality/nc
content: The app is ok: the headphones are great. They didn’t lie about the charging capacity, it’s huge.

author: Amazon Customer
title: excellent
content: Great noise cancellation, excellent for work, anywhere.  Sound quality is great.

author: BH
title: Unreliable after just 2 months
content: I travel extensively on planes and these have amazing sound.  However they randomly shut off the noise cancellation and it is jarring at best.  It’s gotten where it might do this every 10 minutes or so.  Unusable like this.  I am not touching them nor even changing my head position. Will try to return these

author: Liza Rovinsky
title: Great!
content: Great!

author: Drew Eldridge
title: Great Product
content: Great sound, good noise canceling and very comfortable to wear.

author: V
title: Quality Issue in first batch? Intermittent clicking in left ear
content: Test for a week but couldn't get over the random (every 3-10 second) clicks coming from left speaker. Everything else we solid, but this started to drive me crazy. Returning, and might try again after a few months and bugs are fixed.

author: David R.
title: Noise cancelling is excellent, sound quality is very good
content:
The active noise cancelling for this is excellent.  For those of you that live in the city and experience the occasional snow storm with accompanying loss of power, do you remember the silence that you heard the last time that this happened?  That's what the city sounds like outside of my home when ANC is active.  It's downright eerie.  It won't tune out voices completely, but for steady noises (vacuum cleaners, refrigerators, air compressors, and especially aircraft engines) it works extremely well.  When you're flying, it will make the plane very quiet, but unfortunately it will not tune out that screaming infant behind you.  Fortunately, it will dull said infant enough so that cranking the music a bit will mask things.

Sound quality is good but not great.  The bass is...well, it's not right.  It's over emphasized and there's something else wrong with it.  I don't think that most folks will notice.  If you're listening to podcasts or movies, it's fine.  If you're not used to critically listening on high end gear, it's also fine.  It sounds a bit off to me but it's not like I was offended by it, and again, movies and podcasts are fine.

The user's manual is Ikea-style crap and does not highlight the importance of installing Sony's app in order to get the most out of these.  While the active noise cancelling is great for aircraft, it can be counterproductive around the house when you want to hear what's going on around you.  In its stock mode, the "ambient noise" setting (where the headphones amplify outside noises instead of cancelling them out) is crap, but it's actually pretty good if you tune it to your liking in the app.

As you've probably already seen elsewhere on the internet, battery life is fantastic.  They're not kidding with those figures.  These things run for days.

My complaints are that the ear cups are just a hair small for my ears (I have large ears), the manual sucks, and the head phones don't work as well as they should unless you use the app.  The swiping volume control can also be fiddly, but that's normally not an issue for me; you can also control the volume on whatever device is transmitting to the headphones and that's not fiddly at all in my case, so I normally just set my volume on my phone or iPad and ignore this feature.

If you want to listen to stuff while hearing your surroundings, these headphones are great.  If you'd rather not hear your surroundings, they're also great.  When I lent these to my girlfriend, she immediately bought a pair.  I'm not an expert on ANC headphones but I'm extremely happy with these.  4 stars because 4.5 stars is not an option and while my complaints are minor, they're still complaints, and I don't give people five stars if I have something to complain about.

Well done, Sony.

author: Cliente Amazon
title: Super
content: Fantastic

author: Impatience
title: Excellent
content: Outstanding sound quality.

author: Kezin
title: Very powerful
content: Like the sound

author: Austin from Boston
title: Really good but not better in every way than the wireless Bose
content: Noise reduction is a bit better than my Bose QC25, but heavier and they don’t feel quite as solid. From an audio perspective, the sound without EQ is way too heavy on the bass. With EQ, they are a bit better than the Bose, but not without. Battery life is great and I like the fact that they can be on without needing to play music. I use exclusively at my desk at work but would likely take the Bose when traveling because they feel lighter when walking around and I wouldn’t worry about stuffing them in my bag quite as much. Would be nice if the Sony could remember your EQ preference!

author: Bryan Crowley
title: If you can look past the price, they're just about perfect.
content: I can't get over how perfect these headphones are.  Theres a free app you can download to play around with some settings and I had to adjust the bass a little because I like TONS of bass.  (I had 2,000 watts going to a single 12-inch subwoofer in my younger days).  The bass is powerful and well integrated, the highs are crystal clear without becoming tinny or piercing, great mids, everything is right where it should be.  I'm definitely no audiophile but this is my first pair of really nice headphones (I have roommates now) and I just cant believe how much better they sound than pretty much every other listening experience I've ever had.  Again, if you can get past the price, the performance of these headphones really commands hyperbole.

author: Geoff
title: What a set of headphones!
content: Would definitely recommend these headphones.  Only real negative is that you can be connected to multiple devices at one time.  I would think maybe just a firmware update would fix it but it’s probably hardware related.  Other than that the ear cups folding inward is somewhat counter-intuitive but that’s me being really picky.  Great set of headphones better than the QC35 IIs in my opinion.

author: Robert Paul Knotts Jr
title: Great design and sound, but stopped working after a month!
content:
Overall, the headphones are great. The sound is amazing, the battery life is superb (30hrs), and they have top tier noise canceling.

However, my pair conveniently broke 3 days after the return window closed. They didn’t slowly die, they just stopped working and wouldn’t turn on again.
I expect much more from a Sony product in terms of longevity, especially from a product that I was gentle on.

If you don’t get a lemon like me however, these headphones are great.

author: Peter Novotnak
title: Great for Music, Not so Great for Calls
content: This headset is great for music, and the ANC is amazing. However, for calls it falls a little short. Mic quality is just OK, and there is no mute button!

author: NoOne
title: Two main issues for me
content:
Overall I like the headphones but there are two glaring issues I've had to deal with so far.
-I live in New York and the weather has been cold this winter. Whenever I'm outside in the cold the headphones react to the cold by registering phantom touches. The cold will make the headphones activate the "Quick Attention Mode," as well as the google voice assistant. This issue is pretty annoying.
-The other issue is that the headphones can make my ears pretty hot. When i wear them for a while in room temperature my ear start to get hot and I'll have to take off the headphones to cool my ears off.
I really like the Active Noise Cancelling and audio quality. Outside of the two issues I mentioned I really like the headphones but I'm not sure if I can recommend them with those issues as they are.

author: Brayan soto
title: Worth the money
content: What I like about these headphones is that when u activate noise cancellation and play your music you really can’t hear anyone or anything make noise. Quality is amazing nice, audio quality is also great, I really have no complaints about these headphones. Would recommend to a friend

author: Joseph Aspinwall
title: Worth every penny
content: Absolutely brilliant at blocking out ambient noise, if only it blocked annoying voices so well

author: Max
title: Greatest noise canceling
content: I think Sony is better than Bose when it comes to noise canceling. I have both products and am today returning the Sony. I'm returning them because they will not connect to two devices: my smart TV and my laptop at the same time, which is mostly what I want them for. The ear cups are not as comfortable as they are for Bose. They do seem to be larger which more easily accommodates my ears. They do produce good sound.

author: Jacksonville019283
title: Incredible!
content: Incredible. I’ve always loved Sennheiser headphones and still do but the sound quality on these blows my HD-595s out of the water. Excellent product by Sony.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Having reconnect issues after upgrading the firmware.
content:
Pros:the headphones sound great, the noise cancellation is awesome.
Cons: after updating the firmware to 4.1.1, the headphones don't automatically reconnect to my computer when I turn them on.

author: Qais Shihadah
title: Don’t like that you can’t turn off the touch settings
content: Not bad

author: Saad A.
title: Ear pain and headache
content: This headphone in terms of noise cancelation is perfect.. THE PROBLEM IS in the side effect of uaing it just for ONE day !! I got an intense headache after using it for 30 minutes only !! After multiple use I started getting ear pain !! It was weired !! I really wanted to love this product I love its design,color and app but I would never recommend it to any one I love. Sadly!

author: Dennis Arevalo
title: Great buy!
content: Amazing sound quality, great noise cancellation, very comfy and product in pristine condition. Highly recommend!

author: Noah
title: Good sound quality, and incredible noise cancellation and comfort.
content: Very comfortable to wear but my battery life is less than advertised

author: Robert Mann
title: Fantastic Noise Cancellation
content: The noise cancellation is amazing. These head phones are comfortable to wear. I like that they provide a wired input for traveling on planes. Very versatile! Well worth the $

author: Brian Vanderhoff
title: Excellent noise control for travel on the plane.
content: Comfortable, easy to carry and or wear. Pairs easily with the Apple phone for music. Far better than the headphones offered on long business class flights by airlines, adapters provided hook up easily to watch on board movies. once fully charged battery will last that 10 hour international flight. Usually never sleep on flights due to the noise, but these headphones and their noise canceling ability will let you.

author: D Matthew Johnson
title: Great Headphones
content: The noise canceling on these are great. Silencing the ruble of jets on trips is great. Listen to music with limited background noise helps me to love music again. They don't filter out all noise, but what can. These do an excellent job though.

author: Laura D.
title: These are great
content: These are EXCELLENT. I've had Bose and I think these are better. My ONLY problem if you want them for phone calls, they have a weird echo. Otherwise they are great for noise cancellation and music or editing. They are expensive, but I'd say they are high quality and have a really nice case and charger that come with them.

author: Lisa Fiedler
title: Covers the full ear
content: The noticeable difference I found with this headset is that it covers my entire ear. Too many options out there push my ears flat to my head thereby causing ear pain and headache. These have the shape/space so my ears are fully inside and not being smooshed. The noise cancelling is superior. I have to wear them at work to drown out all the chatter and they work wonderfully in that respect. I haven't tried them on an airplane yet, but they exceeded the noise-cancelling capability of the Bose and the Boss that I tested in the store (both of which I heard the ambient noise of the store). Plus, they are both wireless and wired so they can be used by any device. A true five-star rating in my opinion.

author: Christopher
title: After using these for a couple months, A+ Sony good job you earned it this time
content:
What is not to like about these headphones?

The noise canceling is better than Bose. After listening to songs for 5 hours and I tap the power button to hear the battery percent, the lovely lady voice says "fully charged". The battery on this is insanely good.

They are light and yes mostly plastic, but it is plastic I trust to not break easily, assuming you don't sit on them or something.

The case is very high quality and small, it will easily fit in any small bag or backpack.

The sound quality is also very good, better than Bose in my experience. It is heavy bass tuned out of the box but that is easily fixed with the phone app. Once you do that you will have an AMAZING pair of headphones.

Did I mention it uses USB-C and it charges to full charge in like half an hour? That too.

The only bad thing I can think of is a faulty firmware update Sony pushed out right after they released these that made the sound quality and noise cancelling worse, but they have since fixed it. Word of advice, don't update the headphones if they are working fine.

author: Sam
title: Fantastic headphones that drown out the cacophonous world around you.
content:
I thoroughly enjoy these headphones. I am not an audiophile so I will not say they have warm treble or whatever; I will just say they have very deep bass and they sound fantastic. They are extremely well made, not feeling like some $50 cheapo over-the-ears headphones, which is what these replaced after said my previous cheapo headphones broke three separate times, all in the same way.

The audio canceling abilities of these headphones needs to be heard to be believed. I put these headphones on, play my music or Podcasts, and I can be next to people talking obnoxiously loudly to each other on the subway and I do not hear them. These are great for drowning out yammering on the subway, people at work coughing as if they belong in a tuberculosis ward, and so forth. They also work great as earmuffs, coincidentally enough, due to how tight the fit is in order for the noise cancellation to work.

Above the right ear pad, there is an easily visible red circle with the letter R carved out of it to denote that that is the right headphone. This is a fantastic little detail, proving once again that it's the little things that make up life.

The case they come with is also solidly built and, after some practice, you'll go from taking a few seconds to fold these headphones so they fit to being able to do the folding via muscle memory.

I one complaint and one "might bother some people" note. My only complaint about them right now is that the touch controls are *VERY* delicate. If you swipe up or down on the right (volume control) and your finger veers off, you will skip forward or backward to the respective song. My "might bother some people" note is that they are also are a bit warm; quite nice if it's cold, but if it's very hot outside, your ears might get a bit sweaty. This does't bother me but it apparently bothers some people, so just FYI.

author: Michael Scearce
title: Don’t hesitate
content: Worth every penny

author: Kaden J
title: You said what? These are noise canceling.
content: These Sony headphones are well worth the money. For travel, work, or even the gym - these headphones are unbeatable. The application makes them highly customizable. Would choose again over Bose any day.

author: Daniel S
title: Best noise cancelling headphones I've every tried
content:
As someone who owns Bose noise cancelling headphones, these new headphones have blown me away. The noise cancelling is a noticeable step up from the QC 35 I currently. It's light (a tad heavier than the Bose), comfortable (I usually can't stand having most headphones on for a long time as my ears tend to get sore - no issues 3 hours in with this pair), and have a sound quality that blows the Bose or any other noise cancelling headphones I've tried out of the water. Being able to cup the right headphone to pause the noise cancelling to listen to people talking to you without taking off the headphone is a pretty cool feature.

Aesthetically, I prefer how the Bose looks, but then again I purchased this for the audio and noise-cancelling properties, not how it looks. The touch controls on the right earpiece took a bit to get used to, but quickly became second nature.

Being able to charge via USB-C is a plus as someone who has a Galaxy S8 and a Nintendo Switch, as I can use the same cable. It also lets you charge the headphones via Quick Charge. While I can't speak to it's longevity, the headphones seem to be high quality, and I don't notice any discernible issue with the headband - something that I understand the previous models suffered from.

Overall, I am extremely impressed by the WH1000XM3, and it will easily become my every day carry headphones.

author: kaysvilleman
title: superb quality
content: unbelievable......love it

author: Hunter C
title: Pretty good but not for everyone
content: The build quality is amazing it fit almost perfectly on my head. If you hold it you might think it might feel heavy when wearing it but it feels wonderful. Pairing with a phone was a piece of cake just know that you NEED the Sony headphones application to use them properly. When pairing with a computer you lose sound quality and mic quality with it, which was a bummer because I wanted to be able to use it as a headset.

author: Jordan
title: Amazing headphones, but questionable quality materials
content:
These headphones have excellent battery life, amazing noise-canceling and I'd highly recommend them, if my pair hadn't broken. Purchased in september '18, and this month a tiny piece inside the headband popped out, and now the headband is permanently broken. I took good care of them, and this happened under normal use, which is concerning.

I got off the phone with Sony, who told me this wasn't covered under warranty because other people haven't reported this issue. Very disappointed, as I've purchased many Sony products in the past and haven't had an experience like this :(

author: Jeremy
title: Amazing sound quality and lightweight
content:
I own the model before this one which I use at my office. I purchased the new model for my home office and now I wish I had the same model at my office. I love the new rose gold trim on the headphones, it makes it feel more luxurious.

The new model is significantly lighter than the previous model and I'm very grateful for this. A surprising amount of changes are present in the new model, all of which I am happy with.

The sound quality is amazing and the noise cancellation is top notch for wireless headphones. Can't hear anything else while playing music. The headphones being wireless makes it hassle free.

The charge lasts a fairly long time and it charges back up to full very quickly. Charging is never an issue. If you run out of battery during a session, just plug it in for 10-15 minutes and you'll have plenty of battery life to last you a while longer.

I can't comment on the touch controls because I don't really use them since I typically connect these to my computer and use my computer to control the volume, skip songs, etc.

Great wireless headphones - highly recommended!

author: AK
title: Better sound than Bose, but loses on the design front
content:
I bought these to see if they could replace my Bose QC35s. After a week, I'm returning them, since they're just not enough of an upgrade.

Pros:
* The sound quality easily beats Bose. Music sounds more full and there's a much better soundstage.
* Noise cancellation is a noticeable step up from the QC35s. Optimizing for your hair/glasses makes a noticeable difference.

Now, the cons:
* My ears don't touch the inside of the headphones on the QC35s, but do on the XM3s. This ended up being a deal-breaker. I can wear the QC35s all day with minimal breaks, and my ears were hurting after even an hour with the XM3s. Even with the better sound quality of the XM3s, I'd buy the QC35 at the same price just because they fit my ears.
* The controls of the QC35s are just flat-out better than the XM3s'. At their best, the touch controls are finicky, and no match for the buttons on the QC35s. At their worst, if you're wearing them under a jacket in the rain, they'll skip tracks for you and make the headphones unusable. I also have to call out the power button: The switch on the QC35s works perfectly with no fuss every time, and having to switch to holding down a button for three seconds on the XM3s was just an exercise in frustration when I wanted to quickly take them off or put them on.
* This is likely due to the LDAC codec, but I noticed far more interference and skipping while walking around in the streets of NYC. The QC35s pretty much never skipped, but it was a daily occurrence with the XM3s. I expect switching back to SBC would solve this, but that'd negate a big benefit of the XM3s.
* This is a smaller issue, but the earpads on the XM3s don't seem to be replaceable. On the QC35s, replacements take less than ten minutes, and cost $10-20. I've seen enough earpads wear out over a few years that I'm worried about the long-term longevity here. (Although given the sealed non-replaceable battery, longevity was probably never a focus here to begin with.)

And after going back to the QC35s... I don't feel like I'm missing _very much_ from the sound. If you're a serious audiophile and willing to put up with the compromises, this is easily the best sound you'll get from ANC headphones, and also the best ANC out there, but there are definitely tradeoffs.

author: George Landau
