I have an iPhone XS and they paired quickly and the Sony app allows you to actively adjust the sound without using the Apple EQ which is nice since a lot of the reviews state they are too bass heavy, a quick adjustment fixes that.  They also come with a nice case very similar to the one my Bose QC35 II's came in, but seems slightly thinner, which is nice.

I listen to a lot of different music from hip hop to punk rock and most things in between and they sound great with everything I have tried them with.  I don't think you will go wrong with these if this is the type and style of headphone you are looking for.

author: EAU
title: Easily Surpasses the Bose QC
content: Highly recommend it! Sound quality is excellent, noise cancellation is the best I’ve experienced.  Easily beats Bose QC on all measures.  Sony is the new king of the realm.  Long live the king.

author: Wang
title: Volume out of sync, not great
content:
What’s weird about the headphones so far is the volume. The headphones volume seems to be completely out if sync with my phones vollune. Playing way louder than it should proportionally at all levels. What’s weird is that even if I turn the vollume all the way down and it says muted I can still hear my music. Maybe the headphones are so loud that the “muted” (apperently no, apple) is perceivable. Either way, if you use the bad volume control on the side it can eventually hit useable volume levels. It even does this weird incremental volume adjustment, so I can’t even use the displayed volume meter as a representative gage. Basically I can’t EVER adjust vollume using my phone on these things

However, the fact it tracks your location at all times, for a function that terrible and misleading, is grotesque. One can theoretically turn this off, but it seems in setting up “personal optimizing” it grabs your location anyway so they seem to not care

Update: volume for what ever reasons seems to be slowly getting in sync with my phone controls, which is good!

author: Two Virginians
title: The Smart Phone App is FULL of controls
content:
Yes I have had the Bose noise cancelling headsets, they were fine.  The Sony WH1000 is the next generation and they are amazing.  The noise cancelling feature is what I look for and it works very well but now that I have had them and understand how to better use the Smart Phone app they are amazing.  You can control any sound you need to make them fit your need.
I am very impressed with this headset.

author: EB511
title: Effortless Comfortable, Great Sound, Tons of App features.
content:
I use NC headphone mostly during travel and commute, and I have always been the loyal Bose QC user.....till now....

I actually purchase both the Sony WH-1000 XM3 and the new Boss NC700, and I have to say maybe teh Boss NC700'
s new aesthetic and headband design looks more sleek and modern, but when I wear it over an extended period of time, the pressure will build up and I feel my ear and the area above of my ear are getting fatigue feeling.  Normally, if I don't own the previous Bose headphone or I don't have the Sony XM3 for comparison, I might look over this, but....the Sony XM3 just feel so comfortable and so right when it fits on to my head and ear.  It might look in odd shape when you not wearing it, but it sure makes you feel good and able to wear over an extensive period of time.

The sound is great for wireless NC headphone at this price point, and the noise cancellation is just superb...  Unlike Bose and most other NC headphone that allows the user to adjust the level of NC, Sony XM3 will base on your preference or occasion of use, and listening environment to auto adjust the degree and condition of the NC.  I have not tested out in all different situation and environment yet, but the result of listening with the Sony at indoor office, while driving and riding a bike are all excellent.

Also, there are tons of features like sound position, preset or customize EQ, environment effect, etc... which I have not tried all yet, but it is already way better than most other NC wireless headphone's app.

If you are looking for top-grade NC wireless headphone that is turley bang on the buck, this is the one!.

author: NIK ALMIRAKIS
title: SMH touch buttons are the most annoying thing ever and dont work with gloves.
content: Great sound but HUGE flaws.  1st the touch buttons dont work with gloves on.  Walking the dog in the winter?  Tough luck, take off your mitts and change the track.  Want to wear a hood with these? HA! the sound will get so distorted cause of the technology that blocks ambient sound.  for $350 this thing should work how i want it to work.  With that said the noise cancelling is really good, better than Bose in my opinion.  but the touch controls are trash.  even without gloves it takes me 4 or 5 times to skip a song sometimes.  why would people want or care about touch controls on headphones is beyond me.  I returned these for a refund.  Not for my needs.  if you never wear gloves or hoods then these might be perfect for you.  sound is great, noise cancelling is great, battery life is amazing.  but to each their own.

author: VoodooMagnetman
title: Sound quality and great noise canceling
content: I have had quite a few Bose noise canceling headphones including the QC35 and the QC 35II's. I have to say that the Sony 1000M3's surpass the Bose in noise canceling and sound quality. The app is very customizable for sound, but all things considered these are just great headphones. I got these for Xmas and I can't take them off.

author: Adrian Perez
title: Awesome headphones
content: Excellent headphones. Worth every $. This was a complete upgrade from my Bose QuietComfort 25.

author: M. Harmon
title: Great headphones!
content: I like everything about these headphones. I could not be happier!

author: C. Win
title: The noise cancelling is amazing!
content: Worth every penny for the noise cancelling feature! The sound quality is also excellent, but the noise cancelling is the best.  It's comfortable on my ears for hours and I love the long charge.  When I have them on, I can't hear outside noise or my neighbors! Great for studying. Best purchase in headphones I have ever made. Highly Recommend.

author: Fabio Correa
title: Best noise cancellation
content: Noise cancellation is surreal. Also, a recent software update disables the touch panel which prevents bad behavior in winter weather. Excellent sound and battery life.

author: Ryan Weiss
title: Honest review, compared to Bose QuietComfort 35 II, and Sony WH-H900N
content:
The sound in these is a little better than the Bose, but some of it feels a little artificial, ie. not a true reproduction of the sound, but somehow enhanced (not that the Bose are so much better). Note that in wired mode, while turned off/charging (ie. passive mode), the sound quality is pretty bad! Also, they let you listen to them while charging, but they give you a 6" charging cable... thanks Sony.

The Bose are a little more comfortable, about half the weight as these, and I could wear them all day, but I need a break with these after a couple of hours here and there. These stick out from the head more than the Bose. I could sleep with the Bose on cause they were flatter, but not so much with these. They also fall off a little easier than the Bose.

The noise cancelling in these is about the same as the Bose (I did a side-by-side comparison), but the Bose put you in more a vacuum/isolated environment, which is sometimes preferable.

The bluetooth connection in these is a little better than the Bose, doesn't really skip much (sometimes does even when Bluetooth device is close), whereas the Bose seemed to skip a little more whenever there was some interference or strong brain waves. Also it should be known that these will only connect to one device at a time, and when doing so (switching devices), sometimes you have to power them on and off and reconnect, as it will say connected, but audio won't actually play through them, which is a small annoyance, whereas the Bose didn't do this, and could connect to multiple devices at a time, and could use a custom device name.

The touch controls on these are cool, but also not perfect (ie. changing volume might accidentally change song, vice versa, or won't respond and have to try twice, not common but it happens), and also with a slight response delay. Sometimes I feel like I would prefer haptic/buttons more. Also, when powering on or off, you have to hold the power button for a full 3 seconds or so. I don't know why they couldn't make it a little shorter. Just being picky there. The Bose turn on and off right away with a switch.

Overall they're nice headphones, maybe only worth about $250 imho. I would probably return them and go back to the Bose if the Bose didn't have it's known Bluetooth issues, and supported hi-fi bluetooth streaming like these do.

I should also add... if you run these in the highest-quality mode (ie. 990kbps), it will interfere with your wifi! Even on your phone, you'll notice the wifi become very much interfered with when using the phone while wearing the headphones. If you drop the quality down to 660kbps, it doesn't really affect it so much (330kbps is the lowest setting).

Update with WH-H900N h.Ear 2:
I recently sent the XM3's back and bought the WH-H900N h.ear 2 model, as I found them for much cheaper on eBay and the features are nearly identical. The WH-H900N is about the same as the WH-1000XM3, in all aspects (including high-quality streaming and touch controls), with these differences:
-The 900N's are a little tighter around the head, but can wear them about the same length of time as the XM3's.
-The 900N's noise cancelling and isolation is just as good as the XM3's, sufficient enough and well worth the price I paid for them.
-The 900N's touch-sensitive controls are more responsive, and react immediately when you touch them. Surprisingly, the XM3's are less so, with a slight delay, so I prefer the 900N's in this regard.
-The 900N's quick charge (10 mins) only gives you about an hour, while the XM3's give you 5 hours in 10 minutes.

Hope it helps.

author: amazon customer
title: buy with confidence, great product SONY!
content: best noise canceling headphones

author: Victor Silva
title: Absolutely amazing! Put Bose to the ground
content: Awesome piece of headphones, good sound quality, perfect noise cancelling, very comfortable to use and it does not look like a crappy plastic thing like Bose....very good finish.

author: Tashi
title: Great noise cancellation
content: I bought a refurbished one and so far so good. It’s a life saver during my commute and don’t have much bad to say about it

author: Swordwright the majic user
title: ADHD tool of the year
content: Great to block out noise, I have ADHD my desk is on a noisy corner in a busy office. I can super focus on projects for hours with these baby's on.

author: AMC Supreme
title: Are they really worth the upgrade?
content:
So preordered these because I figured I'd break them in for awhile before posting. Then compare them side by side to the WH1000xm2. I will list the advantage this has over the m2 then finding out if you need to upgrade to help with your purchase decision. I use the Sony pretty religiously so no nitpicking here.

1. Sound quality: The Wh1000xm3 sound better than the wh1000xm2 for obvious reason but not blow out the water better. You hear more separation in your music. Also if you ever use the surround modes (dont hate me for this mx2 owners) but there is a very faint but slightly annoying static that occurs when you use the surround modes. Especially on arena mode. The wh1000xm3 erased this totally and that static is no longer there. This may be a big reason of Sony adding the QN1 chip as the wh1000xm2 may have tried to process the music and noise cancelling but since there was no medium, both went throughthe same channels which causes static that you hear. It made my listening experience far more enjoyable.

2. Noise cancelling: Noise cancelling is not noise proof. It does block out more sound than its predecessor however with noise cancelling I felt that the m2 cancelled more sound. Although with noise cancelling on, the m3 do a much better job. I no longer had to put music up to 50 percent to block out sound from very moist environments. Just 20-25 does the trick. Although by itself it already cancels noise out exceptionally better.
Now to clarify the reason the reason why noise cancelling headphones have a hard time cancelling voices. It's really because your voice is not a constant sound wave. It constantly oscillates and to produce counter sound waves to that requires a lot. Despite this, these are the best noise cancelling headphones on the market right now. Now are they 4x better in noise cancelling? I would say 40%better but not 4x which seems like a stretch. But getting rid of the static may have been something.

Build quality: To cut down on costs since you already have the QN1 chip and for a smoother design. Sony added the plastic over the brush aluminum. Also to appeal to their female market as well, they tried to make headphones that appealedto both genders. If you notice, not many girls really wanted to try the wh1000xm2. I did a test of and I got a positive response for men about wearing the wh1000xm2 about 82% while only 18%of females really wanted to try the wh1000xm2. However for the xm3 with the same even 100 amount. I got a higher positive response from females about 42% to 56% men. Plus the lighter xm3 adds to longer hours of listening. The wh1000xm3 is still built well, although you had a leather cup to create a better noise cancelling seal. The wh1000xm3 does not need that so it can afford a sleek appearance. Plus it cuts down on the weight. There is added padding at the top of the wh1000xm3 so when you bump your head, you are protected from most of the shock whereas with the m2 they get scratched at the top fairly easily.

USB: USB-C instead of micro is a vast improvement. Do keep in mind your charger is also a prominent factor on how well it stays. I recommend using anker products for their cables and wall charger. The Sony cable is pretty short. The audio cable us really not THAT bad and it seems most people are overreacting about this and I'm not sure why.

Case: the case is definitely sturdier and has more room inside. Although I do miss the snap on and snap off case of the m2.

What I pointed out where key points as most other things can be looked up on the Sony page and reading the features of the headphones. Although please note neither have multipoint connecting abilities. Although this never bothered as my phone my main source so that's never bothered me.

But is it worth the upgrade? If it really isnt in your budget, I would sell your XM2 first then get the XM3. If the xm2 has been working well for you then you are fine. Save yourself another $350. If it is in your budget just measure against other items you could get, if this is it, go for it. I can say you will not be disappointed.

author: Autumnchild
title: High quality product
content: These earphones cancel noise so well, I didn't know my husband was speaking to me in our own home when I was wearing them.  So they worked very well at the walking track in the Y, so I could listen to my music while walking & exercising.  One drawback: I'd hoped to be able to exercise with them, but directions say don't get them wet.  I did get mildly sweaty, but took them off when I got on the exercise bike, where I sweat more.  I haven't yet taken them on bus or airplane trips, but am sure to like them.  Love the carrying case they come with, part of the quality of them.  However, they're not small -- portable but not "fit-in-the-pocket" size.

author: Maggie S
title: An upgrade.
content: Switched from various Bose incarnations after 15 years. There have better sound insulation, noise reduction and sound quality.  Build seems ok.  I took these on a marathon 5 week 100,000 mile series of flights and had no issues sleeping with them on.  The ability to tap off noise cancellation for brief conversations is actually handy.  Case is compact and includes a sorta-compartment for components (they are still easy to lose).  My only gripe is the the included charger cord is way too short.

author: Samson
title: Excellent
content: I dont know how I travelled in the past without these headphones. Great styling, excellent sound

author: Rogelio Toledo Davalos
title: Best Heaphones all around
content: Bose has slept and Sony is king now...

author: Brettonwoods
title: Great ANC! Better than earmuffs. Mic is defective.
content:
These headphones have great active noise canceling for blocking low to mid-range frequencies. The passive noise canceling (insulation) works OK for blocking the higher frequencies. Before getting these headphones I used to study while wearing industrial-grade NRR 33 earmuffs. Those were a bit better at blocking high and mid-range frequencies, and they only cost like $20, but they were much worse at blocking the low frequencies and a bit less comfortable. I prefer these headphones and I've started wearing them all the time.

My only issue with them is that the microphone doesn't work for phone calls. Other people say it sounds like I'm calling from inside a tin can. I thought maybe updating the firmware to version 2.0 would help but it didn't. Many other people seem to be reporting the same problem.

Update (Nov 14, 2018): I talked to Sony support and they basically confirmed that the microphones are defective for many of the WH-1000XM3 headphones. Supposedly they've fixed the production problem now, but they are still selling the defective units through Amazon. If you receive a defective unit, they are willing to exchange it. That's kind of a hassle though, so I'd suggest that if you're planning to use the microphone, you might wait a couple of months until Amazon has finished selling the batch of headphones with defective microphones.

author: Stu
title: Awesome
content: Best headphones I’ve ever owned

author: John
title: MAGIC or SCIENCE???  YES.
content:
The noise cancellation on these is absolutely amazing.  Truly second to nobody.  Proof is in the scientific measurements, which I checked out after purchase.  They can be found online at the rtings review website.  They offer a full cancellation frequency response charts, and you can plot any two headsets on a single graph.  Clear winner: this new headset.

Sound is amazing.  Few tips and tricks as an Android user:

I very much like having HI DEFINITION BLUETOOTH.  *EXCEPT*... you have to use with caution.  Notice the bass is a tad heavy on these, and the treble is a tad lacking.  I prefer rather flat response to perfectly reproduce the recording.  Now... if someone takes just a touch off bass and adds a tad on treble in the headphone app by Sony, then Hi-Def Bluetooth gets disabled, and you are stuck with standard def.  HOWEVER, if you do that same little tweak to the audio BEFOREHAND, say in the Google Music app, then hi-def bluetooth remains active.

One common complaint I have seen on reviews here that I have made to Sony directly, and will make again, until they fix it.  (You listening, Sony???  I'm waiting for the Firmware Update.  I'll check tonight.  Honestly haven't checked in a couple of months.)  - - - When on a call, the background noise comes through.  The epic noise cancelling present when listening to music is 100% disabled.  Now, specifically, the feedback I gave Sony:  I can see this as being a valid design decision.  I can see some folks passionately arguing for them the way they are.  I can also see folks passionately arguing for the way I prefer.  Personally... I'm a rather mercurial fellow.  I passionately want it the way they are some days.  Other days I passionately want them the other way.  THUS, I wrote Sony product support, and repeat hear (hoping they are reading/listening)... SONY... Please enable the functionality of "Ambient Sound Control" during calls AS WELL.  Right now that is only available during playback or silence.  That would take this headset from "epic" to "legendary".  Not that there is anything wrong with "epic"... but really... don't you want to be "legendary"???  ;-) ;-)

(Oh, and for those that do not have a set yet, get one, but what "Ambient Sound Control" does?  It is a slider bar in the phone app that one one side is 100% noise cancellation, the other side 0%.  Let's you allow some outside noise in.  Also, it has an option to "Focus on Voice", to just let in the "most common" vocal pitches.  Uncle Jerry's vacuum cleaner bass tone might still get blocked, and your mother in law's shrill tones might still get silenced, but the latter wouldn't be a loss. :-P)

author: Jacob
title: Audio and quality is great for ANC headphones, but I needed a little better quality with Mic
content: The headphones are great! ANC is awesome and the functionality is good, but I was going to use them with my computer/taking calls wirelessly.  It kind of lacked the quality I needed in that aspect.

author: OmiTheAussie
title: Cant make phone calls properly
content: Good sound, good noise cancellation. Only and the big reason for giving one star is that as soon as I get a phone call or make a phone call, I start hearing EVERYTHING (including a fly breathing a mile away) from outside. The person on the other end also hears it. Called the Sony tech support. They sent me a replacement as they thought it was a hardware issue. But the replacement (brand new) also does the exact same thing. For such an expensive device, it seems to be totally useless in making phone calls. I might be missing something in software setting, but no one has been able to tell me what I am missing.

author: Roberto RIbeiro Schor
title: It is what you paid for.
content:
Great headphone, at excellent condition.

The case is really good for transportation and the headphones are what you paid for.

author: Faith
title: Ridiculous that it only connects to 1 device at a time
content:
A $300-350 "high end" pair of headphones that only connects to ONE, I repeat, ONE SINGLE DEVICE at a time. Good luck switching from your computer to your phone. No matter what, it won't "release" it's connection from one device. For example, if I PAIR it with my computer, then turn bluetooth on it off, then pair with my phone, I am now paired with 2 devices.

HOWEVER, It will Always try to reconnect to the last device you used. If that was your computer, then even if you go into your phone and select the headphones from the pre-paired list... it refused to switch!!! You literally have to go to your computer and turn bluetooth OFF to get it to switch.

The only other way is to turn the headphones off, unpair the device from your phone,turn them back on and go straight into pairing mode, then repair the headphones with your phone.

This is a LUNATIC procedure to use headphones. Absolutely returned. I wouldn't even consider using any headphones with such a pitiful design. This is pure software and Sony could easily fix this, but I'm sure they're saving that "feature" for some new "upgraded" model in a couple years, to make us waste more money.

This feature is basic and appears even on $20 headphones from no-name brands. GOODBYE SONY.

author: sami casey
title: AMAZING! AMAZING! AMAZING!
content:
Great sound quality. Love the app! Perfect for seeing battery life and sound style. Love the bluetooth adpect. I always hated dealing with a cord.  The noise canceling aspect is much better than my previous pair of headphones which were audio technical. I like that you can optimize the noise cancellation for your surroundings.  The fact that I can hold my hand on the right side and the noise cancellation will turn off so I can talk to someone is also helpful.
 My one complaint would be when you pull out the cord if you’re using it that the headphones turn off noise cancellation automatically.

author: Joel Varner
title: Headphones do not work in cold weather
content:
Touch controls go nuts when stepping out into cold weather - sometimes music will fast forward, sometimes it skips tracks, sometimes it activates quiet attention mode and decreases the sound for several minutes, sometimes it activates Siri/Alexa.

It was very deceiving that this information was not disclosed by Sony and/or Amazon because Sony is fully aware of the issue.  When speaking with Sony customer support (both over chat and the phone), I was told that this is normal operation for these headphones.  I was also told that, each time I go outside into cold weather, I would need to re-calibrate the touch sensor by restarting the headphones repeatedly until ambient outside temperature is reached.  As I live in the Midwest, I experience cold temperatures on my commute every single day, so essentially to "resolve" this problem, I need to re-calibrate the headphones every single day.  I'm not sure what Sony considers a "resolution," but certainly I do not consider re-calibrating the headphones every single day to be a reasonable resolution.

This is a design flaw in this model (from what I've read in other reviews, the 1000XM2's did not have a similar flaw) that Sony is fully aware of, and as such, it is highly deceiving of Sony (and Amazon) to not disclose these issues as I'm sure there are others that would have purchased a different model had they been aware of these issues from the start.  Sony either needs to issue a recall or push through some type of update to correct this problem - in my opinion, it's absolutely absurd for Sony to sell $350 headphones with these types of issues and then not taking any responsibility or remedial action, but rather expect the consumer to manually calibrate the headphones daily just to allow them to function properly.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Great Product, a little pricey but worth it
content: I bought the headphones because I was taking a trip to Europe and had  a couple of long flights to deal with. I had a Bose set before but after many years it fell apart. The Sony's headphones were in the cost range of the higher end Bose headphones  and had terrific ratings so I gave it a shot. The 2 main features I really like was the noise cancellation feature and the ability for me to listen to my wife sitting next to me by just putting my hand on the ear cup without taking the headphones off. I found the volume control a little tricky and at times didn't appear to respond.

author: R.E. Baker
title: Battery life needs improvement
content: These headphones replaced my latest Bose wireless earbuds.  Sound quality with the Sony is outstanding.

author: BuckeyeKev
title: Great sound and nice noise reduction
content: These are great for music and noise cancellation.  Just enough lag on watching movies that I had to get another pair brand  for home theater.

author: Andrew
title: Bass
content: The sound quality on these headphones are suberb and the bass I get from these XM3s blow me away.

author: Kerry Martin
title: Love running with them
content: Love everything

author: Alexander T.
title: It will annoy you every time you go outside.
content:
The touchpad starts randomly pressing buttons when you go outside on temperatures less than 35 degree.
Sony states that you need 'simply restart the headphones'. But it is nothing like simple:
First of all you need to wait until the freezing random pressing occurs and only then restart. You can restart right after you went outside - it won't help.
Second, you need to disable noise cancelling(you don't want to be hit by a car you didn't hear coming) by making two long presses on a hard button(but not too long, or it will run another sound calibration feature and you'll spend extra 10 seconds on it).
Third, you need to continue playing your songs, but even major music apps like spotify not always will continue to play from where you stopped, sometimes it playes next song or doesn't play anything. (Tested on Iphone, Pixel 2 and Pixel 3).

And now imagine your commute is like mine: walk to a bus(restart), from the bus to a metra train station(restart), from metra station into actual train(restart), get out of train(restart), walk into the station and walk-out back to winter street(restart).
5 (FIVE) restarts just before you get to work. 350 buck to keep yourself annoyed every time you go outside.
Perfect, Sony!

author: Greg Yeutter
title: Serious downsides over the WH-1000XM2
content:
I've owned all three generations of Sony's high-end noise-canceling headset (MDR-1000X, WH-1000XM2, and this set). I also have a set of MDR-7506 wired studio monitors. Sony makes great high-end cans, and I vastly prefer their (relatively) flat and natural sound signature compared to Bose.

The 1st gen MDR-1000X was a great set of headphones, but like many, my pair had a cracking issue on the headband. Sony replaced the first gen with the second gen, which still has an intact headband for me.

The 2nd gen WH-1000XM2 was a minor improvement over the first gen and a really impressive package overall. The sound and noise canceling are superb to my non-audiophile but discerning ears, and they are very comfortable, even when worn on some of the longest flights in the world (e.g. EWR-HKG).

I had one major gripe with the first and 2nd gen, which I found was not resolved in the third gen (XM3). When riding buses, the headphones would rattle and make an annoying sound in the earcups. I thought Sony would have addressed this by the third generation, but there is really not much improvement from what I can tell after 2 bus trips yesterday.

But the dealbreaker on this third-gen set is the absolute unusability of the headphones in cold weather. I walk and commute in the city, which has me outdoors often. The touch controls DO NOT work outdoors in cold temperatures. Worse, the headphones will randomly pause, lower the volume, or go into the ambient noise mode when outdoors in the cold. You have to restart the headphones and reconnect to get things back to normal, and it's only a temporary fix.

I was really excited about this pair due to the slightly smaller size, USB-C charging, and improved NC. But I'm bummed Sony has not fixed the rattling issue, and the lack of touch controls in cold weather is an absolute dealbreaker for me. If you only use them indoors, this would be fine, but these are not headphones for commuters.

Until the next-gen set comes out or these issues are resolved, I would say the WH-1000XM2 is an overall better set of headphones and a better buy.

author: m b
title: Good? Yeah. Great? Meh.
content:
I bought these, unsurprisingly enough, for travel. I'm a frequent long distance flyer, and like to while away my time in the air wrapped in music.

They are well made, as you would expect from Sony, and they look smart in a rather dull, modern way. They are a little tight on my head, but otherwise comfortable. They have various Bluetooth and remote functions, which work, are whizzy; and are only utilized in my case when I'm really bored.

The noise cancelling is stellar, the best I've heard. Engine sound is gone, external voices are gone (and in my personal experience, noise cancelling cans that do one well, do not do the other so well). What I really appreciate about it, in contra-distinction to Bose noise-cancelling headphones, is that it doesn't seem to compromise the sound quality. Bose noise cancelling simply sucks all the life and enjoyment out of music for me, whereas here it does not.

But I do think the sound quality of these headphones is good in much the same way that wireless speakers can be good. Which is to say, there is no discernable distortion at more than reasonable volumes, there is plenty of life, clarity and detail; and the sound spectrum is fully represented from top to bottom (though not to extremes in either direction). But not, I think, the naturalness air or rhythm that makes music come alive for me. The sound quality is more than adequate for films or games, mind you.

Now you get what you pay for, and I guess I would expect to pay quite a few more bucks for headphones that gave me my desired level of sound quality, and excellent noise cancelling. But when I've finished watching the film and I want to lie back, zone out and lose myself in some well crafted music, these headphones go back in their (very tidy) case; and my earphones, costing about the same, go into my ears. Background engine noise and all.

author: Berdia Muradashvili
title: Beyond amazing
content: These are my first expensive (100$+) over ear headphones and I consider them totally worth it. They are worth every cent. Super clean sound with great bass and ANC is just phenomenal. I have normal-sized ears and they are very comfortable as well, I can wear them for hours at work.

author: D. HOFFMAN
title: Excellent Earphones
content: Expensive, but that's the way it is with the best. These earphones are extremely comfortable, and have sound quality nearing the best corded earphones.  They are certainly superior to any priced less.  Highly recommended.

author: Cosmikk
title: Useless w/ Macbook Pro. Doesn't cancel voices.
content:
Connected to my 2012 macbook pro, the sound cuts in and out constantly, like every second or so, with loud static crackling. Don't have the same issue when using with my samsung s9 but i need these to work with my laptop. Extremely disappointing. I know it's because the macbook bluetooth isn't as good but I didn't have any issues w/ other bluetooth headphones i've used with this laptop over the years.

Also, this does a great job of canceling out ambient white noise (air conditioner humming for example) but not so good a job canceling out the higher tones of voices. I can still hear the voices of women talking near me, sounds tinny as the lower tones are canceled out. It certainly cancels a lot of sound but it seems there's a limit to the range it can cancel, which is also disappointing.

author: Randall J Oliver
title: Sweet!
content: Comfortable, Noise canceling goodness!!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Excellent!
content: I’m college student and I really, really loved it! It helped to concentrate on my studies and eradicate unnecessary sounds from my neighborhood (car traffic, loud music, etc.). The noise cancellation and sound quality are incredible. (There’s only one little issue: by realizing a call (or answering it), the sound quality reduce, but still good).

author: LENS julien
title: Noise cancelation not work when calling!
content:
Noise cancelation is not working when calling!! Even worst exterior noise are amplify, so crazy to sell a product with this defect at this price.
Look on internet, noise cancelling was much better on 1st firmware 4.1.1 is not so good.
Sony lost a customer for long time!

author: REDFOXXX
title: What a great NC headphone! Sony nailed it this time!
content: Got mine yesterday and love it so much. Built quality is great, NC is great! Bose is finally lost the crown to sony. Wayyy better than ws35’s. App is great too. No connection problems with iphonexs max. Highly recommended. I feel like i am at a concert hall while working at noisy office. Microphone problems seem tobe resolved since i have no problem with phone calls.

author: John A.
title: Awesome noise canceling!
content: Phones sound great and to me the noise canceling is awesome.

author: R. L. Sun
title: Great sound, noise cancelation and battery life.
content: These headphones sound great and the noise cancelling is excellent. Coming from the old Bose noise cancelling product with removable batteries, I was concerned that the I would lose the convenience of always having a spare battery, but the battery life on these cans are awesome. What particularly impressed me is there is no battery drain when the unit is turned off, so if you let themselves sit for awhile there is no worry about that the battery will be dead. I like the fuller bass as compared to my old Bose product and I like the ability to adjust the levels on the app. I wish that when you turned them on it would automatically tell you the battery level without having to go to the app. I used the headphones for a telephone call the other other day with no complaints... But I didn't think to ask if the other person felt I sounded clear or not. I am very happy with my purchase.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Ears ring after using
content:
My ears ring after using them. This has happened on more than one occasion and I am generally protective of my hearing (e.g. I wear earplugs in a movie theater) so I believe that the noise-cancelling feature is flawed and causing hearing loss. While using them there is a perceptible feeling of pressure (which has been noted by online reviewers as well) which might be related. I cannot be certain but I only get one pair of ears in my lifetime and this is not something to mess around with.
Also, the user interface sucks - the volume control is not connected to the Mac/iPhone's own volume control, it's operated by a touch interface that is finicky to use and it doesn't remember settings between power on and off.

author: Chris C
title: Call quality is terrible; please allow option to disable touch controls
content:
So when I first got these headphones, I quite liked them. They fit comfortably; I actually prefer this model's build to the previous model as I find it lighter and my ears don't get overheated. The noise cancellation is fine, although I think Bose still has an edge. But the sound quality when listening to music was great, so I gave away my Bose headphones in favor of these.

However, I really wanted to use these while traveling to both listen to music and take calls in airports, cafes, etc. I didn't really test run this for calls until a couple of months after purchasing (so outside of my return window). Sound quality on calls is absolutely terrible. Call quality is bad on both ends - for me and the person that I'm talking to. There is a weird echo when I speak. On multiple calls, the person on the other end told me they couldn't hear me because either a) the sound of my voice coming through the mic was too quiet (despite talking loudly into the headphones) or b) the background noise was drowning out my voice. Usually for calls, I had to disconnect and just switch to speaking on my mobile device or to significantly cheaper Bluetooth earbuds. Rather than cancelling out ambient noise during the call, the headphones actually seem to amplify all of the background noise. I don't understand why the noise cancelling seems to act differently for music vs. calls.

Additionally the gesture/touch controls are absolute sh*t. Any slight brush of my jacket hood, collar, hair, tilting my head activates the controls. It is infuriating. I would need to keep my head totally still in order to effectively use these.

Given the price point, I would have expected significantly better call quality from these headphones. I had given my old Bose QC 35 headphones to my mother once I bought the Sony WH1000XM3 but I'll probably try to resell these and purchase another pair of Bose QC 35. Really disappointing. I would give 3 stars because the sound quality for music is great, but overall the headphones are pretty much a paperweight now especially give that Sony doesn't provide an option to disable touch controls so I can't rate any higher than 2 stars.

author: Evan R
title: incredible
content: best bluetooth headphones i've ever used. the noise cancellation is unparalleled.

author: JGB
title: I fell in love with these headphones, until....
content:
Coming from two generations of Bose QC headphones, these were amazing at first. Super comfortable for extended use, great noise cancellation, very good sound quality (music, movies on plane). Alas, after a couple of weeks of use, popping/crackling noises appeared in the right ear. Common problem apparently, just Google it. My headphones were firmware 4.1.1 which I believe is the latest. And no, slapping (gently) or tapping the defective ear didn't fix it.

Sony, you've broken my heart. When you fix the well-known and publicized defect, LMK and I'll consider coming back to you.

author: william s.
title: Very impressed
content:
I was curious about all the positive things I was reading about Sony's M3 headphones.
Now I know, yes these could be the best NC headphones I ever tried.
I was expecting to send them back, no way I'm keeping them no question about it.

author: Don AZ
title: These are the best BT NC headphones you can buy
content: To be right up front I bought these from another site because Amazon couldn't get them to me before next week or beyond.  I buy most of my stuff here but I am going on a 15 hour flight to Australia and wanted them now.  Another problem i have is I am hard of hearing and wear hearing aids.  So if you put the headphones over the hearing aids think of buying the most expensive music player you can buy and plugging in a 98 cent speaker, sounds like crap.  Most BT headphones are not loud enough to compensate for my hearing loss.  Sony fixed it!! I can listen without my hearing aids and actually have to turn them down from full volume.  I have got to listen to music and heard it like I used to know it,  The highs,  the lows, the voice, it almost brought tears to my eyes to be able to hear music like it was meant to be.  The ability to adjust so many parameters thru the Sony app is truly amazing for me.  For you folks that have no hearing difficulties be ready to be blown away.  The noise cancellation is also amazing.  Sony has brought Music back into my life.  And to them I say thank you!  Buy these!

author: Sharri Peck
title: Best headphones ever
content: Hands down the most amazing headphones I've ever owned. Very comfortable and easy to set up. Sound quality is outstanding.

author: Amr Abouelkhair
title: Great headphones over all with a few catches
content:
Great build quality
Very comfortable
Great sound quality for bluetooth headphones
noise cancelation is great specially on flights
2 catches tho:
Touch controls go on the fritz when it's less than 0 degrees C. Living in canada and having negative degree weather 6 months a year I can't go out with it. Tbf turning it off and on again usually fixes that.
second catch you can connect more than one device at a time if it's connected to your laptop you can't connect your phone you have to disconnect it from laptop before you connect phone and vice versa

author: Tim Budden
title: Great sound and noise cancellation
content: bought these for my son, he loves them !

author: Shaun Ruffell
title: I should have bought these earlier
content:
I recently switched jobs and now work in an open office where I'm having trouble adjusting to the noise and distractions. I purchased these headphones to help mask out the sound when my coworkers are discussing projects that I'm not working on and, along with a speech masking white noise sound track, do the job wonderfully.  I especially love the long battery life and how quickly they charge up. I'm not much of an audiophile so I'm probably not the best person to rate the sound quality but I have no complaint.

My only complaint is that I have to adjust them more often than I would like to keep the top of my head from hurting while wearing them most of the day.

author: Ahmed abbas
title: One problem the cold
content: Every thing about is well done the sound the bass and noise cancellation however the pause skip and other gestures dont work well in the cold, i read an article about this saying this i thought maybe mine will “surpass” the cold but it did not and went bad but as soon you get into a good climate area it fine other then that its all green lit.

author: Adil Ahmad
title: Better than the hype!
content:
Wow, these are fantastic. I've been flying quite a lot because of work and decided to pick up a pair of these instead of the Bose. I usually sit near the wing of the airplane by the window (where it's usually the loudest) because nobody else wants to sit there and MAN! Do these things drown out the noise. I don't hear anything. At first I was bothered because hearing nothing gives me major fomo and I want to be able to hear at least what's going on around me or if the pilot makes an announcement. Within the app, I can select the setting that 'Focuses on voice' and that clears it right up. You can even change the amount of ambient noise - I set it to like 13-16 so I can hear what's happening around me and that's perfect.

As for sound - these sound great! I'm by no means an audiophile but I enjoy listening to good music/podcasts and these are up there with the best pair of headphones I've ever listened to. Voices are clear out the box. Sound is nice and full with Bass which I like. Battery life is really good. Easily lasts me around 10 flights without having to worry about charging it. I also love how sleek the design is. Don't have to worry about it getting stolen or broken because the quality is top notch and they are minimalistic enough that people don't think I'm wearing something super fancy on my head or with a giant logo like Beats do.

Overall really great pair for the money, def plan on using these for the foreseeable future. if something does change, you guys will be the first to hear of it.

author: Bill
title: Can't recommended for people with multiple devices
content:
As others have said, the sound quality is great.  I also find them pretty comfortable.  And batter life hasn't been a problem.

Why 2 stars?

They're _really_ hard to use for multiple devices.  When I travel, I have my iPhone, my iPad and laptop.  For long flights, I'll typically vary which devices I'm listening to.  It could be a movie on my laptop, later a game on my iPad and later a podcast on my iPhone.

With most bluetooth devices, including AirPods, you simply open the new device, connect to the headphones & that's it.

With these headphones, it's a 3 step process:

1. on the old device turn off bluetooth for the devices.
2. on the new device, connect & wait for the headphones to connect
3. reenable bluetooth on the old device

Needless to say, it become really annoying.  I wouldn't have purchased these only because of this, and I'd advise you to avoid them.

author: Amazon Customer

content: Good headphones but isn’t absolutely noise canceling and too expensive.

author: david fluty

author: Dante E Tomassoni
title: Great product, Great sound - just slightly not perfect
content: Sound and operational is excellent so far. I just got it and am still using them. The only reason I did not give them 5 stars is the functionality of the charging hardware.  For a premium price, Sony could include a charging block and room in the case. Also, the charging cable is so short that its almost non-functional. I see noise canceling headphones almost 99% of the time in airports and on airplanes, if someone needed a charge the length of the cable in an airport is almost useless. I'm not suggesting an 8 foot cord, but 6 inches too short. I charge my headphones on my kitchen counter top and the length of the cord is still too short to lay the headphones down while I charge them, they have to lean up against the wall with tension on the cable.

author: Amazon Customer
title: BEST $300 ever spent
content:
For months I went through all sorts of reviews, ratings and comparisons to find the best headphones on the market. You can definitely go cheap and get yourself some skullcandy or Mpow headphones that'll surely do the trick. You can get some airpods and look like a full blown douche. However, spend the extra money and experience a world you didn't know existed.

Have you ever heard silence? I mean actual silence. I work in a restaurant and between the hood, customers and fridges all making noise, I rarely get peace of mind. That all changed after these bad boys though. The whole digital noise cancellation is worth the money by itself. Throw in the touch controls and quality of sound and I feel like a fool for not buying these months ago. Beats are overpriced and overrated. Skullycandy and Mpow provide you with a get what you pay for  type of headset. The only other company that can truly compete with elite sound performance is Bose and I still don't believe they have a headset this good for this price. Believe me, buy these headphones and I promise you it will be one of the best decisions you've ever made. 10000% recommend to any and everyone.

Maaaaaan, what a game changer.

author: Jordon Gerber
title: Surprising shortcomings from a flagship
content:
The battery life is incredible. The fit and feel of these headphones is everything I could ask for! The active noise cancelling is on par with what I have experienced from Bose, however only at lower levels. I upgraded from a $50 pair of TaoTronics active noise cancelling headphones to these and found that when exposed to high levels of ambient noise (like while driving, especially with the windows cracked causing low frequency rumbling) these fell short of my cheap headphones!! There was audible distortion in the headphones as either the speakers ran out of travel or the amp reached it's power limit, not sure which.

The companion app is nice however I am disappointed in the lack of true parametric equalization - this is something that I expect from a pair of headphones costing $350. The built-in 5 band eq is okay but doesn't offer enough control to really make these headphones shine. The bass boost makes the headphones sound muddy and not enjoyable to listen to (100-140hz boost, not bass).

The headphones do sound good but they are not refined, and they lack deep bass. More design work could have gone in to optimizing their sound quality, but they are not fatiguing and will do for most customers.

I think the hype surrounding these comes from the fact that Bose has dominated this space for so long, people want to be excited about a competitor being able to match Bose's performance. I don't think Sony has revolutionized anything or even made substantial progress forward in the Bluetooth anc market, but it is a good quality product overall. Just not on par with what I expect from a flagship.

content:

I'm seriously considering returning this. What good is sound quality if you cannot connect to the sound source?

author: mad fugue
title: I feel like I'm in a dystopian futuristic novel- and I'm lovin' it!
content:
As an indy audio producer, I value sound quality and typically use my studio earphones for everything from daily commutes on the metro to long walks.  However after losing my Sh*t too many times after becoming tangled up  in cables/bag straps/coats, I decided to go wireless.  Of course, even for my day-to-day activities, I wouldn't be happy with tinny sounding low-quality audio, so I had to go big- and I'm glad I invested in these.

Pros:
* The sound quality is supreme,
* easy instructions for syncing with phones/devices;
* Extremely customizable with via phone:  EQ & Ambiance filter.  I really value the ability to adjust the ambient filter via the phone- this will be great for those days when walking down the street and I can choose the level of street sounds to allow in.

Cons:  All the options, especially, the "optimization" setting kinda freaks out this old school headphones girl / dystopian novel nerd- to hear the voice "You've now been optimized" as if it's coming from within my brain. Have they implanted a chip?  Will these earphones turn Black Mirrore-sque on us?  That's yet to be seen. I'll update if that happens.

author: Brady
title: Big improvements over Bose QC25, QC35, QC35II
content:
I've had several Bose and Sennheiser noise cancelling headphones over the years including the Bose QC15, QC25, QC35 and QC35II and these are a big improvement.  I think that the Bose QC35 and 35II are slight more comfortable because they have barely deeper and wider cups, but otherwise the fit and finish is superb on the Sony's.  I wish the Silver was a real silver color instead of a tope/tan/silver color.  I originally purchased those to replace my Bose QC35's and returned them for the black model because the color wasn't really silver.

As far as performance, battery life, sound quality etc. just stop reading reviews and buy these.  They're not audiophile headphones, but none that are noise cancelling really are.  These are by far the best overall noise cancelling headphones out there.  Audio quality is fantastic, noise cancelling is amazing and they're very comfortable.  The biggest complaint I have is switching between different devices because you can only be connected to one at a time.  Sometimes I can get two to try to connect, but the headphones wont switch back and forth from unless one of the others is disconnected.  Frustrating coming from the Bose.

author: Ben
title: Great Performer with Few Shortcomings
content:
Quick Summary: (4/5)

The Sony WH-1000XM3 is a great pair of headphones that hold their own against the tenured Bose. The Sony's provide a fun and full listening experience to a wide array of music genres that will make most perfectly content with their purchase. Bose's QC headphones will provde a more refined and pleasent listening experience especially for the discerning listener and will provide a stronger noise cancelling performance in a home or office setting. The stronger sound signature of the Sony will hold out better in a lounder atmosphere such as a plane, train, or automobile with its stronger bass performance. The Sony's lack the grace and balance of the QCs, but will provide a more familiar experience to the majority of listeners and will appeal more to someone who likes the sound of Apple's Beats, but is looking for a more professional or subtle design.

Full Review:

For the Sony WH-1000XM3 ($350), I will primarily compare it to the Bose Quiet Comfort (QC)($350) since even though they are all in the same relative price range, they are technically closer in price and age. I will also provide a little comparison to Bose's NC700 ($400) and Sennheiser's Momentum ($400) in the summary. Also, I will primarily discuss the pair of headphones in question and how it relates feature-wise to the Bose's Quiet Comfort (not QCII) headphones while refraining from giving too many details about the others, since you can read more specifically about those pairs individually in the review posted under their respective products. The reason for that is mainly to keep the review from becoming a master's thesis in subjective preferences. :)

Initial Impression:

Starting with the packaging. Simple and straight forward. The outer shell has a nice texture to it, but sliding out the insert with the headphones in it reveals a very simple package structure made up of just the case holding the headphones inside a box. However, the case itself feels really nice and has a sleek color palette. Very appealing to feel and look at in my opinion. Although the case is a touch bigger than the one for Bose's QC, it does a better job of holding its headphones. The QC's case always feels uncomfortably tight when putting them away. Sony's case neatly holds everything comfortably (without having to squish them in to zip it closed). The case is stiff, but not really hard. The inside is the same as the QCs with a soft microfiber feel to it. The headphones fold up inside with three little slots to the right for (inside to outside) the airplane adapter, 3.5mm aux cord, and USB Type-C charger cable.

The Headphones:

When I first picked them up out of the case, they felt nice. Soft plastic with a good feel to them. The plastic has a sparkle to it with a matte finish that resists fingerprinting decently. The band of leatherette on top is soft and has good cushion. Similarly around the ear cups. Very soft and nice to the touch. Not as stiff as the QCs. The click of the band when expanding it is satisfyingly stiff. At the top of both ear cups, you can see one of the microphones in a rose gold finish. Some other smaller holes are hidden around more subtly for the NC array. I feel this is a minor plus for the Sonys. The QC's microphones are a little more prominent and pick up wind a lot more outside. The USB Type-C port is at the bottom of the right cup with an indicator light. The left cup has the power button along the bottom back with the button for toggling the noise cancelling level just above it. Inside the ear cups, there is microfiber layer covering the drivers over a layer of foam. Overall the Sony's feel a little lighter than the QC's but also feel just slightly more flimsy when handling them. But the design is also more appealing and fluid and frankly more premium.

When comparing the headphones while putting them on, the QC again feel more snug and naturally isolating before turning them on. The cups feel like they form a better seal given the stiffer covers and the QC also have angled drivers that leave natural room for your ears inside the cup, making the headphones not feel like they are sitting on your ears, but rather around them. The Sony are by no means uncomfortable, but may tend to be less comfortable for longer wear times and might make your ears prone to getting hotter.

Sound Quality:

For starters in this section, I will compare the noise cancelling. Upon turning the Sonys on, you are greeted by a woman's voice that sounds like it is in a tin can or cave when she speaks. When the NC kicks in, it does a darn good job of removing ambient sound and muffling people talking somewhat. It feels very close to the NC of the QCs, but I would still give them a leg up because the Sonys have a much more noticeable white noise factor playing whereas the QC feel more like they just sucked the sound out of the atmosphere around you. For the traveling folk (I primarily wear them in a typical office setting which any of these work plenty well for), I would say given the more aggressive, forward, pronounced sound stage with the Sonys, you will find them blocking sound better in a car or plane without the sound (especially on the lower, bass end) being washed out. The QCs have better NC, but the sound is softer in general so the sound still gets overwhelmed in a car/plane. I am not saying the NC is not doing its job, just that what you are left with is weaker with the QCs because the sound itself is subtler and more refined so you have to turn them up louder to make up for this.

Now, it is difficult to judge sound since it is so subjective, but I will try to give my own impression of what each headphone may be better for. I listen to a wide range of genres, so I can appreciate many styles of music and how they are represented by different types of headphones and speakers. First, the Sonys bring a more forward sound. The sound stage isn't as wide as the QCs. Instruments get mixed together and lost in the fray. The sound of the Sonys feels more akin to that of Beats Studio. The bass is more pronounced and punchy which may be more appealing to some. If you prefer a balanced and clean representation, the QCs will serve you better. As you turn the volume up, the Sonys also lose more of their balance and can become muddy. The QCs give more of an impression that the music is playing around you, while the Sonys just feel like they're playing music. (if you really want to feel like you are on stage with the music, Sennheiser's HD800S is king. The HD700 or HD660S do a good job too at a better price, but these are all studio headphones, so totally different use case to begin with.)

Where I really felt more of the performance shining through came in the Rap, R&B, or even some EDM/House area. I can definitely appreciate Sony more for some 2pac, Destiny's Child, Infected Mushroom, or Daft Punk. They are little too aggressive for music you may want a finer touch with such as jazz or opera. When listening to some Kenny G, David Benoit, or Keiko Matsui, you get that groove, but the fine details and intricacies of the instruments are sacrificed. Also, the sharp trills of the piano keys and saxophone are a bit much at higher volumes. The visceral in-your-face nature of the sound also makes them pretty fun for bands in the vein of Disturbed, Five Finger Death Punch, Pantera, and Metallica. Going a bit further that direction, with the likes of Eluveitie and Slayer it will be more likely to give you a headache from the unsubdued highs and thrashing sounds. Taking a couple steps back and going for some more classic rock like the Eagles, Journey, Gerry Rafferty, etc., the QC will perform better, but they are fine with Sony's headphones. Finally, when listening to music with a gentler atmosphere like Norah Jones, Ray LaMontagne, Ludovico Einaudi, or Celtic Woman, I would have to give it to Bose's QCs again but the Sony did liven them up a bit in a way.

Features:

Both Sony and QC have three levels of NC. High, Ambient sounds, and off. The QC handle this a lot better. The mid level for the Sony feels worthless and clumsy without audio playing. It almost sounds better being turned off. On the QC, the mid level provides a good balance and allows you to wear them outside on a windy day with reduced noise from the wind in the NC microphone. However, in the case of the QC (instead of the QCII), you need the app to change the NC level.

The QC claim 20 hours of battery, which I have thoroughly proven to be true in the years I have owned them. Sony's claim 30 hours, which I have also found to be true, but I haven't had them nearly as long to see how they hold up over time. Also having had the QCs for longer, I have had to replace the ear pads after about 2 years. This process was easy and made them feel and sound new again with the better seal of fresh pads. The process for both headphones appears to be the same.

Call quality is great for both headphones. I also use them for Skype calls from my laptop at work where they work great. However, this is one of those places the Sony completely dropped the ball. Bose's QCs allow two devices connected at the same time, and you can switch seamlessly between them which makes them great for the office. I have them on the laptop and my phone at the same time. I can listen to music while working. When its meeting time, I just join the Skype call and it immediately picks up. If I get a call on my phone, it switches back over. When I am done, music is ready to go. I don't have to touch anything. Next time I turn them on, it picks backup to the laptop and my phone immediately.

Both charge fast. Just a few minutes will give me a couple hours of use in a pinch. Both also have apps. The Bose app is laid out better and more useful, but neither are really great or even necessary except in the case of the Bose being able to sync two pairs of Bose headphones to play the same music or audio through both. This may be a good deal for a couple seeking to both watch a movie on a plane or something. I have done this a couple times and it works well once setup. It is a nice feature in favor of Bose, but I haven't really found a lot of use for it in reality.

For the Sonys, you have the features with the right cup having touch controls. This is fairly slick and works better than I expected. It only took a couple attempts to get the hang of it and it is responsive. Swipe up and down for volume. Swipe left and right for skipping tracks. Double tap to play and pause. And finally, if you hold your fingers on the right ear cup, it will turn the volume down and turn on the external microphone to catch ambient sound if you need to talk to someone really quick without stopping your music. A nice feature, but I personally haven't found much use for it. Might be useful for people in a bigger city like NYC walking around with the headphones constantly and you don't want to take them off every time you need to listen for a moment.

Conclusion:

Sony's WH-1000XM3 are no slouch and stand up for themselves at this price range. For someone looking for a pair of headphones with solid noise cancelling, flexible and diverse performance across genres and premium features, you won't go wrong with these. I dock them to 4/5 stars simply because in my own opinion, they fall short of Bose's QC series at the same price range in the overall quality and balance of the sound, noise cancellation ability, and the ability to connect to two devices at once and seamlessly hand off between them which is extremely handy for business people in today's multi-device world. Now, for my brief mention of the slightly more expensive options in the Bose NC700 and Sennheiser Momentum. If you are willing to step just a bit further up to the $400 mark, you will get even better quality, better noise cancelation, more premium feel and just overall better devices. However, I will propose that with the Sony or Bose QCs, you would not go wrong. For the majority of people, I would not say the extra money is worth it for the marginal increase over these headphones. It will mostly come down to your preference in sound.

I will try to keep these reviews updated as time goes on and if anything comes up. Feel free to ask any questions and I will give a response when I can.

author: acefspradez
title: Expensive...but worth it.
content: Great product if you're willing to pay for it.  I know these are a lot of money, but if you are looking for great sound, comfortable fit, and outside noise cancellation all with wireless technology then these headphones are what you want.  If you can afford the price...I recommend.

author: Lincoln
title: Better than Bose!
content: This is a great product. Everyone loves Bose but truth is these are better.

author: Christopher S. Cornette
title: Significant improvement over the Bose QC35 II
content:
I bought these to replace the Bose QC35 II, which I found to be a major step down from the QC35's.  I seem to be alone in this, but the active noise cancelation in the QC35 II actually hurts my ears after less than an hour.
However, I still have my QC35 II and after receiving Sony WH1000XM3, I decided to do some side by side comparison.

Out of the box (default settings):
Sound quality - QC 35II wins, being noticeably less bass heavy.
Noise canceling - The WH1000XM3 wins hands down.  Virtually eliminates all but very loud ambient noise (HVAC, engine noise, fans, etc) and significantly reduces incident noise (finger snaps, voices, tapping, knocks, etc.). I found the QC35 II to be somewhat less effective against ambient noise and almost useless against incident noise.  That said, when you are playing music or a video, both headphones eliminate enough sound to make all but the loudest ambient and incident sound negligible.
App features - The WH1000XM3 wins hands down again on this.  It is far more feature rich than the Bose companion app.  The EQ is much more usable, the noise cancellation is adjustable, and the soundstage can be customized to make the source seem to be in one of six different locations.  It also has a mode that uses the microphones and some reference tones to adjust the noise cancellation to compensate for your head shape and whether or not you wear glasses, etc.  I did notice some difference, but not an overwhelming difference, after applying this feature.
Headphone controls - The WH1000XM3 wins hands down again.  The buttons on the QC35 II are minimal and not easy to remember if you don't use the headphones often.  The WH1000XM3 has only two buttons, which are different sizes to make them easy to differentiate.  The rest of the controls are done by a touchpad on the right ear piece.  I found this to be extremely intuitive, and was grateful that a single tap on the touchpad does nothing, so it's difficult to accidentally trigger an action.
Other features:  The WH1000XM3 wins again, narrowly.  Both headphones have a complete set of features you'd expect on high-end phones in the smartphone era.  The WH1000XM3 have one added feature that is nice, but not a must have by any means.  If you cup your hand over the right ear piece, the volume of the music/video lowers down to just audible, the noise canceling turns off, and the headphones port outside noise into your ears.  This is nice if you're listening and your wife starts talking to you.  But at the end of the day, it's only slightly better than taking the headphones partly or completely off.
Comfort:  I'll give these a tie.  Both are lightweight and ergonomically designed with rotating ear cups.  Both have good padding in both headband and ear cup.  Any difference between the two will be minimal and totally personal.  As I mentioned earlier, I find the noise cancellation in the Bose very uncomfortable after a relatively short time, but this seems to be unique to me, so I wouldn't consider that if you're trying to choose between the two.
Accessories:  This is a complete tie.  Both come with the same set of cables (1/8" cable, airplane two-prong adapter, micro-USB for charging) and both come with very similar flat, semi-rigid travel cases of about the same size, with a stretchy pocket on the outside.

After making adjustments:
The WH1000XM3 comes out of the box very bass heavy.  After making some easy adjustments in the companion app, it's easy to balance them out.  Personally, I found that reducing the bass boost to -7, and adjusting the EQ to increase treble frequencies and reduce the lower mids, I got vast improvement.  In fact, although it's fairly close and pretty subjective, I found the adjusted sound in the WH1000XM3 to be better than anything I could achieve adjusting the QC35 II.  Better balance, more spacious sounding, much clearer bass, less edge in the treble.

The WH1000XM3's were purchased to replace my QC35 II for travel use (primarily).  However, by the time I'd finished getting used to them and making the adjustments to solve the heavy bass, I had really come to love them, and they are have replaced my daily wear cans.  About the only thing I won't wear them for now is high-end reference listening where I need absolute fidelity.  No bluetooth headset can match good wired reference headphones for that.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Honest review
content: I use this product for two things. My phone via Bluetooth, and my PC via aux. I do wish that the volume controls work better, as I found myself swiping multiple times to adjust the volume. I also wish that they could connect to two devices at the same time. All cons aside, they sound amazing, they're comfortable, the noise canceling is superb, and despite what I've heard from other people, the build quality is great. USB C is a nice touch! (some people reported their headband cracking)

author: John Dyson
title: You Get What You Pay For
content: The overall build and sound quality have met my expectations. I've taken them across the world once (12+ hour fights), so after a few more trips, I'll see how well they stand up to the wear and tear of travel. I have purchased two other lower quality noise cancelling headphones to try and save money, only to be disappointed. So far, I have not been disappointed.

author: Kyle Schenk
title: The bees knees
content: Best investment I’ve made in awhile. I tried a few other “noise cancelling” headphones and these completely blow these out of the water. I had my headphones on in SEATAC airport and started dancing like a mad man. These truly take you out of the element and put you in your own world.

author: JBJ
title: tuoch controls
content: left touch controls don't work. i cant find anyone else talking about this issue.

author: Carlos Henrique
title: Top
content: Top

author: Aaron Olsen
title: Touch controls defective in cold weather
content: I like these headphones, but they have a significant issue: the touch controls are defective in cold weather. When worn outside in the cold the controls will go haywire and turn on Siri, change noise cancelling mode, etc. Be aware of this problem and google this issue to see others' complaints about this before purchasing these. Very disappointing in an otherwise good product. Thankfully I caught this in time to return them.

author: Michael Knaus
title: Great quality
content: Great quality but pricey, only downside is that you can’t use them while charging but they make up for this with long battery life

author: Bolivar Morales
title: Not worth the money
content: This is a bad product if you love music or enjoy it because it does not give you a great sound Quality. I been in the music business a while and I hear better with other headphones with a less price.

author: Rohit Atwal
title: Bass and battery life
content: Battery life is really bad, i just use it while going to gym. It lasts a couple of days, that’s it. Songs stop on their own detecting outside sound and noise.

author: BC
title: Great sound andnoise canceling
content: Love the sound and ease of use.

author: Chip
title: Expensive but worth every penny
content: I have had this for about 3 months now and i absolutely love it. I use it for travel and it eliminates noise especially on airplanes. Expensive but worth it

author: Efe Shipman
title: If you need noise cancelling this is the one
content: Best noise cancelling out there!

author: FloRidaSailor
title: Unbelievably good
content: Unbelievably good

author: Amazon Customer
title: Extremely Unhappy 😔
content: I paid alot of money for these only to find out the right side does not work! Sound only comes out of the left side. Very unhappy!!!

author: BJ
title: Stylish
content: Great

author: Anthony Frank Vorell
title: Stellar performance!
content: Very flexible as far as shaping the sound that you prefer.  Great noise cancellation and very convenient touch controls.  Don't waste your time on brands that you have never heard of.  These are the best all around noise cancelling bluetooth cans for your hard earned money!

author: Don Menard
title: Works Great!
content: I really enjoy using the headphones while mowing grass and fishing, excellent sound quality and outside noise is practically zero!

author: marlene monico
title: Recommend!
content: These headphones are amazing! Highly Recommend. It has transformed my entire flight experience.

author: William S. Dalton
title: Beware of the cold!
content: So here’s the thing noise cancelling is okay but still can hear a lot around you. The worst thing is that when it’s cold The touchpad fails and when it’s really could the sound turns down to almost nothing.

author: Elizabeth
title: Hurts my ears and doesn't connect to computer
content: I was specifically looking for a more comfortable over the ear headphones which also will connect with my work computer for online meetings. These begin to hurt my ears after only 5 minutes and I have a "normal" sized head. My cheapo ones from Target don't hurt until about 30 minutes of wear.  Also, these will not connect appropriately to my work computer through Bluetooth or with the cord, in order for me to use it for the near-constant online meetings I have. The sound and noise-canceling is awesome but since they are so uncomfortable to wear, that doesn't really matter for me. Sadly, I am returning.

author: Mryc
title: Good at blocking out the white noise
content: I use these for traveling as the airplane noise creates a stress that is not noticeable until it is gone. These headphones are great for doing that plus the sound quality is excellent. I can still hear when someone is trying to speak to me but it is the background noise that is removed. When listning to my music I hear tones and sounds that I have not heard before due to the poor quality of my other headsets. I love these headphones.

author: Liberum
content: All is great, but only after a month the headphone sliding mechanism broke. Just from adjusting the size. I was rather gentle too but the plastic just snapped. Still works, but now taped.

author: Andrei G
title: Great noise cancellation, bad OS
content:
I’ll make it simple:

Pros:
- great noise cancellation
- descent sound quality
- touch controls
- adaptive modes for noise cancellation
- adapters for plane

Cons:
- when connecting to an iPhone, if you put your volume to 0 you will still hear the sound in the headphones.
- THIS IS A BIG ONE: If you’d to make/answer a call in these, the person on the other side will hear absolutely everything that’s going on around you.

author: Zahrac29
title: Awesome Investment
content: I love these headphones. I have had them for almost a year so this review is based on a significant testing period. The noise-canceling is very effective. When I have them on I literally can not hear someone sitting next to me talking. It's great to meditate with them. Also, the music quality is very good. I can hear all of the instruments when listening including those that I can not when not listening with them. I also use them wired to DJ a radio show. I should mention that I bought these reluctantly after returning TWO pairs of the competing Bose class. There was no comparison in range, noise canceling, and comfort. All good. I strongly recommend.

author: ayush
content: Noise cancelling is awesome

author: Prince Solomon
title: Great headphone with a glitch AND NOW AN UPDATE
content:
Purchased this item with the confidence - one, it's Sony - two, its from Amazon.  sounds incredible, enjoyed the low basses and the highs (when listen to the wired mode), the bt is great, but in about 2-3 weeks time, make rattling sound everytime any vehicle passes by - rattling sound that hurt my ears.  Amazon was awesome, understand my frustration were able to help resolved the issue connecting me with Sony tech.  Sony has recognized that there's a problem, Amazon stepped up to swap the device.  Again, it's an awesome gear, when its wired, sounds great, but with BT its ok, for the money $348.99, optimistically cautious...

Update:  Finally, I got the same but a Japanese domestic product...felt the difference right at the first.  No rattling sound, rather firm...More than Sony, my thanks to AMAZON...customer service was absolutely amazing.  Here and there one or two representatives gave run around, but few good folks, nailed it and stayed with me until every process get completed.  Truly appreciate Amazon.

WITHOUT AMAZON'S GREAT CUSTOMER SERVICE I would not be able to post this.  After a swap of the headphone AGAIN, this time, a japanese domestic use product was purchased, and what a difference...a headphone as it should be.  No more rattling sound...sounds crystal clear, spectrum of frequencies spills out of the headphone.  Don't know why the difference...but surely thank Amazon for their patience and excellent customer service.  I AM A SATISFIED CUSTOMER for the 16th year!!!

author: Ritesh Patel
title: does not work with Mac
content: These are not discoverable on my mac book running macOS Mojave!

author: C. Dean
title: AMAZING noise cancellation!!
content: OH MY GOODNESS!!  We originally bought one pair for my wife who had suffered a severe concussion and was having difficulty with doing her job with all the background noise. We were almost to the point that she would have to quit her job. I chose Sony as they were rated #1 in noise cancellation on a couple of websites.  Sony completely solved the problem for her.  They were so good that she insisted that I get a pair for myself to help with distraction in my office.  I don't even have to turn on any music, the noise cancellation gets rid of the most annoying background noise without it.  There is a phone app that has a noise cancelling "optimizer" that I run every time I put it on so that it accounts for any little differences in the background, things like atmospheric pressure.
