content: 30 minutes charge for 30 hour lifetime. Ambiance is so good. Easy to use and so light! I can use it for the whole day without taking it out at all.

author: Mike
title: Good if all you care about is marketing!
content:
Poor quality sound (compared to good headphones like Bose), terrible multiple device support, worthless on a computer, annoying touch interface, buggy firmware, and just poor quality all around. When did Sony become such crap?!?
So disappointed I listened to all the reviews saying these are as good as the Bose, not at all! It's a totally diffent class of headphones. Don't waste your money on these POS headphones, spend the few dollars extra and get the Bose - you'll be glad you did!!
Honestly the only good thing about these headphones is the marketing.

author: Brian R
title: Lots of uses
content: I bought these after my earbuds just wouldn't cut it on an airplane.  I am amazed by how effective they are.  I use them on airplanes, watching tv at night so I don't wake the family and even cutting the grass.

author: ricky
title: Amazing noise cancelation!
content: Great upgrade from my QC25.

author: Wang Chongyu
title: Great product
content: Great product

author: Shopper
title: Great sound plagued by really horrible build materials
content: I had to have the first pair replaced by amazon due to a constant rattle in the left ear speaker.  The replacement pair had a loud pop that occured any time I moved my head or placed the headphones on.  I do not recommend these to anyone.  My experience was bad and I really did not enjoy my purchase or experience with amazon support.  The battery life lives up to what it claims but the build material issues left me not ever wanting to buy sony noise cancelling headphones.

author: ELAINIA
title: Great Headphones
content: I did a lot of research and Sony rated the best. Money well spent.

author: Nuclear Veteran
title: Great noise cancelling
content: My Bose QC35 set was stolen. Got these on a whim. I like these much better. Sound is fine but I’m 62 and probably can’t hear for crap any more. Noise cancelling is super. Very comfy. Setup is easy and intuitive. For me, these are the new benchmark.

author: Andrew Z
title: Uncomfortable and complicated - but good ANC
content: I found these headphones to be very uncomfortable compared to the Bose QC-25.  They are very tight on the head and the material against the ears gets hot and is uncomfortable.  The controls are also complex and annoying.  Maybe I am getting old, but  I just want simple, decent-sounding, comfortable headphones with good ANC for plane travel and at the office when it is noisy.  These are not that.  I do agree the ANC is better than the Bose.  If the only criterion is ANC, these win.  But they fail on the other criteria that are important, at least to me.

author: AC
title: Best noise cancelling
content: Only thing that I don't like is the touch controls, they don't always respond (especially double tap to pause) and are awkward to use.

author: Lidia Aguilar
title: Son y wh 1000  m 3
content: Excelente😊😊😊

author: James S. Yelverton
title: Great headphones...but not "silver"
content: These are great. Fit great, sound Great, incredible noise cancelation. But the color is not what youd think from the pictures (or description). These are more tan than anything. Not my cup of tea, so I returned them for the black color. Now I'm happy :)

author: lowell seymour
title: Sony WH1000XM3
content: Very soft ear pads. Can wear for long periods of time. The sound quality is very good

author: David
title: Best Noise Canceling Earphones
content: The best pair of noise canceling headphones I have ever owned. I have tried the Bose Q35ii and I have to give it to Sony this time.

author: D. Neu
title: Great, lightweight, wear anywhere headphones
content: Super light, easy to wear for long periods, great noise cancelling, Google Assistant integration works well, battery life is amazing, connected app is useful. Would definitely recommend

author: Harry S.(Wilmington, DE)
title: Great headphones!
content: There headphones are AWESOME! I had a pair from another company. They were 15 years oldand the fabric ear covers had fallen apart. I teally enjoy the ability to answer phone calls when they come in.

author: Jim Reynolds
title: Skip others and buy there. No question.
content: Damn near magical. If you fly frequently and you need a pair of headphones, buy these. I replaced a older paid of Sony noise cancelling headphones and I'm really impressed by the improvements of these over Sony's previous generation. Love them.

author: jose a. velez
title: happy
content: was return

author: Carlos Joseph
title: Review
content:
Honestly before buying them, I compare them with the best headphones of the market, including bose quiet comfort 35 (Which is a brand dedicated to headphones with good sound quality)

If you are looking for:

-Isolate yourself with the sound
- Premium sound quality
- Extended hours of battery (30hrs) and super fast charge
-Very high comfort when using them (Since they are very tight and comfortable for human skull)
-Esthetically elegant and not exaggerated in terms of aspects (Like others)
-Quick access to controls (Pause, volume, music change etc)

The price worth it 100%

author: SF Atty
title: Bluetooth audio made tolerable
content: Noise cancellation work for yard work, gas blower, loud mower.  good for treadmill walking.  preserves your hearing

author: Elizabeth A. Douglass
title: For me: a music teacher/musician? Worth the price!
content: I have traveled on four flights with these headphones now. While they didn’t block 100% of the outside sounds they certainly blocked most and I really enjoyed the excellent sound quality and comfort of these headphones!

author: Paul King
title: Great headphones
content: Very happy. Comfy, great noise cancelling. Sound quality seems great too

author: Coach Alisa
title: The headphones work great
content: I originally bought the headphones to use during my workouts. I love the noise cancelling effect. I can't even hear the machines next to me at the gym. I then decided to use them to record my podcasts on my phone. WOW! What a game changer. The audio was clear and no background noise. I would highly recommend these headphones for a variety of uses.

author: Patricia Leu
title: good
content: good

author: Diego
title: Solid
content: This was a good investment

author: Iain Hill
title: $350 ear pads degrade with lengthy use, painful, not covered by warranty
content: Perfect headset except unwearable after a year.  I'm a law student, only wear them to study, and took perfect care. My usage was about 4 hours/day over the course of a year.  $350 head cans should hold up to that usage. As the ear pads degraded (slowly, they were great for 7 months) the metal audio parts increasingly pushed on my inner ears to the point of being painful.  I was SoL because ear foam pads are considered cosmetic per the warranty.  To be transparent I bought the XM2, the predecessor, and the ear cavity in the xm3 version has been increased, slightly, (in theory it would take longer for degradation to cause ear pain) but when the foam degrades, plastic and metal will be on your ear. I raved about these headphones for months, until my ear pain began.  Look to Bose for better build quality, the sound and noise cancelling are basically the same but with a more premium build-or apple, because their customer service is amazing and probably would have replaced the headphones without questions asked.

author: Kay Gee
title: Why do these cost $350???
content: First of all, completely not worth $350. I know everyone is ranting on about these new headphones, but I just don't think they're worth this price. Why don't these pair with Sony Bravia TV's that are 2017 models or later? Both of these are Sony technologies. Second of all, the headphones feel cheapy, the material, the flimsiness do not justify the cost. Yes the noise cancelling is very nice, but thats really the only thing you're paying $350 for. Sound quality is very decent, but other headphones do match it. I personally think these headphones are worth $150 for the sound and build quality. The comfort is nice too. But no, doesn't pair with a Bluetooth the made by the same company. Have your headphones back. Thanks.

author: Fernando Rios
title: Exelent comfort!
content: Incredibly comfortable, even more then the Bose that I got my wife. Incredible noise cancelling and sound. I love the appointment that comes with it that you can control sound, noise cancelling and other cool Specs. The only thing I would critic on is that I use them at the gym a lot and since they are so comfortable and don't squeeze your head, they sometimes fall of when doing a high intensity complex movement. Other then that they are great at the gym. Also note that I have a small head for my size 6'1" narrow face. Maybe that's why they fall of. But I would totally recommend these head phones.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Excellent
content: Excellent!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great Value
content: I have the qc35 2s from Bose as well and these are a clear winner. They include a 3.5 auxiliary cable while the Bose uses different sizes on each end. Sometimes I forget to turn them off for a whole day and they still have plenty of battery life left when I pick them back up. wish they had different colors

author: qifeichen
title: good
content: good

author: I. Faygenbaum
title: Earmuffs with music
content:
So, I bought these to compare them to the QC35 II which I already own - and I DEFINITELY cannot live with these. I'll highlight some important points starting with pro's:

Audio Quality:  Decent sound, volume goes higher than the bose, pretty clear even though some distortion with music.

Materials:  Durable feel and premium materials, but unlikely to age well.

Battery life:  Incredibly good, way better than bose. Easier to charge with USB C.

Weight: Not substantially heavier than the bose, but still very light.

- now for the negatives -

Heat:  My biggest and most outstanding gripe, as you may be able to tell from the headline,  is the material and feel on the ear. Simply put, these are full-on earmuffs. The leather quality is clearly synthetic and the cups are less recessed. They make my head sweat and are incredibly uncomfortable for extended periods of time. Bose wins hands down here.

NC controls/quality:  These are inferior in noise cancellation consistency. They are not quieter or more dynamic than the bose in that sense. The settings are far too time consuming to switch from ambient to nc settings. They take roughtly 5 button presses to get to where you want to be.

Call quality: In short, don't use any NC headset for calls. They aren't made for it, its an awful experience for both ends of the call and are absolutely not good for this purpose. Buy a Jabra UC headset and thank me later.

Case: These are much less portable and easy to stow away in the case because they only fold flat in one direction. This means they can only be put in the case in 1 configuration and its annoying to do that on the go.

Device connection: This is purely awful. They connect to literally 1 device, and do not connect or play sound from another unless you manually disconnect the bluetooth settings every time. Impractical and basic for a $400 headset.
--

Bottom line: These are completely inferior in comfort, convenience, and quality to the Bose. I'm not sure why people would think otherwise, but in my opinion, they don't even touch the QC 35's.

author: James Lovett
title: Great headphones - almost perfect
content: Would be 5 stars if I could connect more than one device via Bluetooth.

author: Zackery Ammar
title: I hate touch sensors
content: Maybe I'm just old fashioned, but give me a button over a touch sensor any day of the week. I constantly have issues when I go to pause whatever I have playing. Whether that's it not actually stopping, or it skipping ahead to the next thing it irritates me. The sound quality, and noise cancellation are quite good. If you're not listing to something you will still hear noise, but man if you have some music going on medium volume you won't hear someone talking right in front of you. The battery life is superb; it will last for about 24 hours worth of work for me. When it does get low it gives you a few warnings that are few and far between. The distance that I can travel from my phone and still be connected is amazing. Iv'e been able to go well over 100ft away and still remain connected.

author: Sergiu
title: 5 star
content: 5 star

author: Amazon Customer
title: The microphone still doesn’t work for calls
content:
I have an MDR-1000X (the first version of these headphones), and purchased the mk3 given finally Sony fixed the faulty microphones for voice in calls. So here I’ll compare both for those who are thinking of upgrading it (spoiler: it’s not the time to do so)
-build quality: the fine leather cups were replaced by plastic
-tactile feedback: older model is quick/responsive to the taps to play/pause/next... the mk3 has a serious 2/3 of second delay... annoying
+sound: quality of bass improved, but not bizarrely better, no need to upgrade
+battery life: its better, but mk1 was good too.
+tilted speakers inside earcups: adds comfort as ears don’t touch the speakers; but TBH, not a big reason to upgrade
+app integration with options such as having the annoying auto-off feature turned off
-The microphone still doesn’t work for calls. Repeating: The microphone still doesn’t work for calls. It works much better than before, yes... but people still can’t hear clearly, making it impossible to use it, especially in “noisy” environments such as a train.

Waiting for the mk4.... please do something REAL about these microphones Sony... and also, get a flush 3.5mm jack for us to at least be able to use external accessories such as a mic-in-cable that fits... not this thin jack that you make us use.

author: Ryan C.
title: You pay for what you get!
content:
As someone who is easily distracted, these do an excellent job of shutting off the outside world whether you’re jamming out or not.  A huge bonus is no more wires — I was always used to launching my phone or having to take them off if working on my laptop.  Not anymore!!

The carrying case is a nice addition to protect your investment.  My brothers both upgraded from the 2000 and say these are far superior in comfort.  If you’re on the fence, I’d say to splurge on yourself and buy nice, not twice!

author: Bkbrown5881
title: By far the best....
content: As of this review there is nothing better at this price point. Very comfortable and the sound is excellent. Plenty of ways to adjust the listening experience through the app according to your music preference.

author: Justin
title: Excellent noise canceling and sound quality, along with a very good mobile application.
content:
The noise canceling on these is noticeably improved over the previous generation.  The sound quality is excellent, and if you use the Headphones app you can change the base and other EQ settings.  The base is good and strong, especially when you turn it up.  When you enable noise canceling and run the optimizer, it is phenomenal!  Voices are not completely canceled, but in most cases they will be muffled and hard to understand. Play music on top of noise canceling, and you won’t really hear anything at all.  I attempted to use these in the dining room which was very loud, and I would say about 90% of the sound was canceled out without playing any music.  I’m not sure how these will handle in the car, but I suspect they should be fine. Wind noise might be the only issue, which isn’t that big of a deal.  They are extremely comfortable as well. Maybe not quite as good as the QC 35 headphones, but very close.  They are a clear step up from last year‘s noise canceling headphones!
 Update.
 The headband is covered in leather and has more Patty. I have not heard of any cracking issues, and the headband feels slightly stronger to me. Also, the swivel pointst feel stronger as well.

author: Sophon
title: Sony vs Bose
content: The bass sounds good even better than the Bose Quietcomfort II. But the upper frequencies was missing a sparkle that the Bose headphones had. The motion touch controls were amazing.  I think depending on the music you listen to will determine if you should buy this Sony headphones or the Bose.

author: John
title: Turns off constantly
content: Unless the audio cable is plugged in, it turns off on it's own after about 5 minutes.  This is not because of low battery (happens even at 90% battery).  Basically, these headphones cannot be used unless you're actually listening to something or are willing to have the audio cable dangling down from them awkwardly.

author: Erik Camacho  SR
title: If it worked like it said
content: Great ear phones had problem In stalling Alexa for voice assistance  nice  feature when it works sometimes does sometimes doesn’t anyway all in all not bad pair of your phones

author: Shooz
title: Great for Traveling
content: Great headphone. Did a good job canceling engine noise and blurring our baby crying through my long haul flight (14 hours).

author: NYC Best-Selling Author
title: Ugly Silver Color Should Be Called “WET CEMENT”
content:
Great headphones, however, the silver color should be renamed “wet cement.” What a shame! Real silver or Ivory with gold would have looked SO MUCH better... Anyways, I hate black so I am keeping these. Really important to know is that the new ALEXA update takes 20 minutes and will NOT work for another 30 minutes!!! I thought my headphones were broken and them gave it one last try before shipping them back and boom! They work perfectly. 5 stars for quality, 1 star removed for horrible color on a $350 luxury item.

UPDATE: Changing 4 stars to 5 stars after a month of daily use. WHO CARES ABOUT THE COLOR??!! I literally can't live without these things as a professional writer.

author: fordhpfan
title: Noise cancellation
content: I dont leave reviews but do depend on them. These headphones are the best purchase I have made for private audio listening. The bluetooth has excellent range for what I do. I highly recommend them.

author: Andy V.
title: Overall great
content: These are one of if not the best sounding noise canceling headphones. Bouse canceling is close to or on par with bose but what sets them apart is the sound quality. Bose sound more flat and quiet where full volume on Bose is 60% on these. The touch controls take some time getting used to. Mic for calls is not great as it picks up on background noises. NFC pairing is easy to use and the quick charge with usb C is perfect for heavy users. Not as comfortable as Bose but sitll good and get a little sweaty but nothing intolerable.

author: Shawk
title: Worth the money
content: Best sound quality

author: Richard Carranza
title: Best headphones in the market
content: Best headphones I've ever used

author: Kunal C.
title: EQ them, and then they are fantastic!!
content:
First things first: you have to equalize them. The default sound signature is too bassy. You can reduce the bass by 4-5dB either in their app or your device equalizer settings. After that these are fantastic!!

- awesome noise cancellation
- excellent sound
- very comfortable
- excellent build quality and wireless performance
- great battery life

I would call them the best wireless headphones on the market right now. They don't sound as good as Audio Technica DSR9BT, aren't as comfortable as Bose QC35 and don't have the looks of a B&W PX, but as an overall package they are better than all of them!

author: Kelly S. Heimlich
title: Great
content: Husband loves them. I had to hit him to get his attention on the plane. lol

author: Normyiris
title: Very Good Headphones
content: Excellent product

author: Jetmech
title: They sound and look great but...
content: I received these headphones about two weeks ago, but just got to try them out this past weekend. They sound fantastic, the noise cancelling is like nothing I've ever heard (get it?) They really are great overall, but I noticed that on the inside of the left earcup, the fabric that covers the speakers has 2 dark red stains which appear to be blood. It's obviously not from me and I'm not comfortable with it being in there if in fact it is blood. I just got off the phone with Amazon support and they are sending out a new pair. Hopefully the second pair shows up stain free.

author: I. Cortes
title: A great set of headphones
content:
I was a previous owner of a pair of Bose Quiet Comfort 2 over the ears and they were a great set of headphones. after about 3 years of ownership they started to develop some sort of static. I am not sure if it was the battery not having a good connection to the terminals or what.
I have had these Sony Headphones for about 30 days now and I love them. Quiet, over the ears and the noise canceling is great.
However they have started to develop static noise. They were fine and clear as a bell until after 30 days. I am going to call Sony or amazon to see if I can get a replacement. I love these headphones.

author: Rohan
title: Best ANC Headphones going into 2019!
content:
Well worth the buy! The tactile gesture function makes it very easy to use as opposed to multiple buttons. Sound is amazing - works amazing with high end phones from the last 2 years. Doesn't weigh much. Noice cancelling on another level. Very efficient app to go with it. Oh, and wonderful battery life!

Issues: People with bigger ears might struggle with the comfort of the cups over long durations of use (for me it was quite comfortable and working wonders on a 9 hour flight). My ears did experience heating up, but i dont see this being a major issue in colder climates. Only connects to one device.

The issues are minimal/insignificant compared to the positives. Overall an amazing experience. Definitely beats the bose QC35-II in my opinion. Sony loses out on comfort only by a hair, but Sony simply trumps everything else

author: Realistic Reviewer
title: You've Never Heard True Silence Until You've Worn These!
content:
When they said these were the best noise cancelling headphones available, I thought "yeah right, that's what they all say", but these are different, because too my absolute astonishment IT'S ABSOLUTELY 100% TRUE!!! I honestly figured it was just marketing hype, but it's not! I've never experienced anything like it. No joke, you have NOT experienced true silence until you've worn these! You hear absolutely nothing! It was so calming & peacefully quiet, that I actually fell asleep after about 10 minutes of first having them on & I had just unboxed them!

The audio is smooth, clear & completely distortion free.  I'm using it with a OnePlus 7 Pro via Bluetooth 5.0 & LDAC which is at 32 bit 96Khz & quality of 990kbps / 909kbps. Of course it sounds even better through a wired connection.

I've seen people say that these headphones are useless with an external DAC. I am by no means an expert, but I can tell you from first hand experience, that although these sound absolutely incredible by themselves, a DAC makes a very noticeable difference as well. Some believe that ANC (Active Noise Cancelling) ruins the DAC experience. To me it adds too it noticeably! Just like with regular music, the ANC eliminates all ambient noise, so the only thing you are hearing is the music being played. Same thing happens with a DAC, it makes everything that much more detailed. Honestly, I was amazed at what the xDuoo DSD XD-05 DAC did with the Beats Studio 2 I was using, but after hooking up these new Sony's OMG! I wasn't expecting it too be that overwhelming!

Bottom line, these things are awesome! I was seriously on the fence about buying them, but now that I've actually used them, I am extremely pleased I got them!

They're light weight, very well made, extremely comfortable too wear for long durations. They're loaded with features & even support Quick Charge! (15 mins of charging gets you 5 hours of playback! A full charge will get 30 hours!)

Yes, they're kinda expensive (which is why I got them on the 0% interest, 5 payment installment option. Thank you Amazon!!!), But honestly they are worth every penny! These are a definite no regret purchase!!!

author: FJ_Hiker
title: Well made and noise cancelling really works
content: Pretty happy with these so far. A little heavy on the bass, but that's a well-known behavior and easily tweaked using the iPhone app. Very comfortable and, so far, worth the extra money.

author: Steve Allen
title: Disappointing sound quality
content: I wanted to like these headphones.  I really did.  The reviews all went on and on about the stellar sound.  Actually, I found the sound to be quite muddy, like it's coming from behind a wall or something; it makes me wonder if we're listening to the same headphones that people go on about.  I've got a pair of Bose Comfort 25s, and the sound quality blow these out of the water at half the price!  Very disappointed.  i would have given it one star, but the ANC *is* quite good.  But not good enough to live with the shoddy sound quality.  Also, I'm not a big fan of the swipe touch volume control; it's very easy to accidentally  forward to the next track.  Also, it doesn't pair to multiple devices.  You have to unpair from one device, and pair to another device.  Very annoying.  Hopefully the next generation M4's will address these issues.

author: Jimmy Eldridge jr
title: I will always buy new
content: Very comfortable  And sound quality is great this is my 3rd pair I originally bought refurbish and I was very disappointed so I decided to buy new

author: Sam Granieri
title: Noise cancellation, audio quality and battery life are superb! This is a great investment.
content:
I work in an open office as a computer programmer, and sometimes it gets noisy at work (which has an open office floor plan). I can get my work done the best by listening to music, not distracting conversations, and these headphones do an amazing job keeping me focused by blocking out other noise.

These headphones can cancel out noise from a noisy bar (while listening to music). I haven't taken these on an airplane yet, but I imaging they'll do well there.

Another massive plus: USB-C charging. I listen to these headphones _all day_, and I have to recharge them like every three days. And they recharge quickly!.

author: G Funk
title: Noise Cancel = Awesome.  Sound = OK
content:
Background
I have tried so many headphones, I can hardly count.  Sony 1000XM3, BW PX, BW P7 (which I owned for a year and LOVE), Senheiser Momentum, etc etc.  For the last few days I have been comparing my 4 moth old Sony 1000XM3 with the H9i.  I am keeping the H9i and give the Sony’s to my wife.  But read on.  These are great headphones.

Volume
Plenty loud.  No question.

Comfort
Very comfortable but my ears warm up.  But is fine.

Sound
Overall these sound quite good, and will make most people very happy.  But I made the mistake of hearing the B&O H9i, and the Sony’s are going to my wife.
Bass:  The Sony has strong bass (adjustable) that never gives in.  In fact if you LOVE strong bass all the time, get the Sony’s.  However in comparison to the H9i, the Sony is sloppy or muddy.  But you won’t notice unless you get the H9i, so you might not care.
Treble:  Lacking presence and mainly clarity.  You will lose subtly in many songs, but I think a lot of people don’t care so much.

Noise Isolation
Pretty good.  Those around will only hear your music if you have it somewhat loud and the room is quiet.

Touch Controls
I was looking forward to these but even after 4 months of use, I am constantly skipping tracks backward when I meant to lower the volume.  Very frustrating when you are mid-track (starts song over).

Noise Cancelling
Creepy how good these are at noise cancelling.  The best.  Seems like no compromise in sound quality with NC turned on.  No air pressure sensation whatsoever.  Amazing.

author: John
title: Great
content: Noise cancellation works very well – – a great upgrade versus mine less expensive headphones with less sophisticated cancellation ability.

author: Stuff Lover
title: Ignore the audiophiles out there
content:
Well, I waited to review these after using them for about a month. I didn't buy there on Amazon because of delivery delay/out of stock situation. But I got them and very happy I did. No, they are not $1,500 wired so-called audiophile headphones. And some of my less expensive sets sound almost as good (like under $100).  But with a bit bass taming EQ (I used the Sony App, but my iPhone apps, Kaiser Tone and Onkyo HF, also work) they can become a fantastic balanced listening experience. Some on other sites say they are congested. Not to my ears. Apart from that, the comfort and convenience factor just makes them a fantastic value. Never owned the M1 or M2, but a friend owned the latter and he return them for the M3. Says he prefers the form factor on the M3s.

After years of chasing my tail, aka the price to performance Holy Grail, I am content with the Sonys and the Jabra Elite t65, which I did buy on Amazon, as the only two pair of phones I need with my IP8+. Yes, I do on occasion use my old iPod/headphone amp setup with a pair on Thinksound On1 phones, and that sounds very good too (and no, not in the audiophile category either). And sometimes I do pull out the customer JH5 I bought a decade ago or so, and they sound very good too (but the custom fit is not as comfy as it used to be. Must be age). But day to day, the Sonys and the Jabras have hit the sweet spot of sound, comfort and BT usability.

author: Benz
title: Very comfortable and fantastic sound
content: You cannot go wrong here. I do wish they were smaller in size, but, all else is perfection.

author: Knitting Hands
title: Exceptional Sound. Exceptional Noise Cancelling.
content: I bought this head set for my son’s birthday. After he opened the package and synced the headset with his devices, I asked him to let me experience the headset sound.  Wow! I was truly blown away by the sound quality.  I felt immersed in the listening experience. The noise cancelling was amazing. Parents beware, the sound quality and noise cancelling features are so exceptional that you will find your teenager completely oblivious to other sounds.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Amazing
content: Amazing headphones

author: Jessica
title: LOVE THEM.
content:
As an undergraduate student, I need all the help I get with studying. These have been a major game changer.

There are three sound canceling options. I use the lowest setting when I do need to be slightly aware of what is around me. The second one I honestly hardly use but I could see it used if you're in a quiet setting and don't need the FULL noise canceling (save some battery although it lasts forever). The final option is the noise canceling. I use this option all the time to drown out white noise machines at work, loud students on campus, and any noises at home (TV/dog/laundry/etc). They sound like you stepped into a black hole and all the excess noise is sucked out.

Every single person I have let use them and try the three variations all have a shocked face. You don't understand the level of noise cancelation until you try them.

I do love the features of controlling everything on the side, but I'm not that picky. I will say as a person who wears glasses, they never hurt my face. They're never too tight. I have had two other friends who wear glasses say the same thing.

For me - the price is worth it because I need the concentration.

author: Mich Y
title: uncomfortable earcups
content: I see many people say the earcup comfort is an upgrade from Xm2. I own the Xm2 and can attest that's the most comfortable earcups I ever experienced -- no discomfort even if I wear the headphones all day. So I thought to myself: wow, that must be a minor miracle if they can make it more comfortable than xm2! So I bought an xm3. I'm disappointed to report that my ears (the outer part) hurt within half an hour of wearing them. And after two hours it becomes absolutely unbearable. I never experienced that kind of problem with xm2. In addition, the Sony headset app seems to have a problem such that it turns on and off the noise cancelling seemingly randomly. I returned the xm3. Happy with the older model!

author: Mauricio Jesus Palma Atilano
title: Awesome noise cancellation!
content: These feel really soft and light, but deliver powerful sound without being overwhelming.

author: Ray
title: Awesome
content: Amazing!!

author: Tilton Anderson
title: Noise canceling and sound quality are both excellent.
content: The noise canceling is absolutely amazing and sound quality is outstanding. Also, if you like bass these are perfect for you. 95% of what I listen is EDM and Hip-Hop and the bass is excellent without being overwhelming. I'm not even close to an audiophile, but I will say that everything sounds a lot more clear and punchy compared to pretty much all headphones I've owned before these. I can hear things in my favorite songs that I can't on much cheaper headphones so that's also pretty interesting. These were definitely worth the steep price tag in my opinion.

author: Robert V
title: Better than Bose
content: Returned the Bose QC35’s for these. They sound better, have USB-C, and don’t feel as cheap.

author: Jerry79
title: Best sq for the price
content: Got these for mowing the lawn. Wanted a set of cans that had noise canceling and bt. I have a loud mower (exmark lazer). These don’t disappoint. Sound is definitely solid for this price. The 3m wire is cheap and flimsy but it doesn’t matter since I’m only using bt. A long way away from my grados for lossless but these were 1/3 of the price, has Bluetooth, and noice cancellation. I had a set of Bose bt I was using prior but can’t find them so I bought these. The Bose had less sound quality than these and the noice cancellation wasn’t as good. I think I paid more for the Bose as well in 16. If you’re on the fence about these or the Bose I’d get these hands down. Being I just got these I might be honeymooning so if they start to have issues I’ll post more info. Only negative I will say is the flashing led when you turn them on. Not a biggie but the wife doesn’t like it when she’s trying to fall asleep. It did go off after about a minute though. 1st world problems are great.

author: Thomas
title: The best
content:
This is amazing. If you just want science without any artificial noise, this one would be the best.

I'm not an audio enthusiast. This looked obviously too pricey. Before landing this, I have tried three pairs of noise cancelling headphones less than $80: quite old Audio-Technica, relatively new MPoW, and the latest TaoTronics. I thought that those cheaper ones should work to my ordinary ears. But they didn't. One of the problems was hissing noise clearly heard when NC is turns on, which was really disappointing. On WH-1000XM3, the level of background noise is hardly heard.

My favorite usage is to listen to podcasts when driving. NC gets rid of most of noise. It sounds like ice-skating. I don't have to increase the volume. I use the same volume level as that in a quite office.

Regarding sound quality, to me WH-1000XM3 sounds way better than any other I have tried before.

author: Kats
title: What an Investment!
content:
Yes.  They are expensive.
I debated making this purchase for about 4 months.
I read tons of reviews.  Not just from tech reviewers, but from people who actually purchased them.
These headphones fit great.  They are snug enough to be secure, but not so much so to cause discomfort.
The sound quality is stunning.  The music is clear, defined, crisp...gorgeous.
The noise canceling quality is staggering. When I first enabled the functionality, I had to keep taking them off and putting them back on because I could not believe the difference.
I travel a lot and I was giddy to try them.  Wow!  What am amazing difference in the quality of my flight.
There was a crying baby and I only realized it when I saw the parent of said crying child walking them up and down the aisle.
It was kind of cool to see the infant shrieking, but not hearing a sound!
It comes with a plug that allows you to listen to the movies, etc. on the plane.
Whenever I decided to sleep, I did so with no issues. I didn't worry about twisting or breaking the headset because it is sturdy...yet flexible.
The case these come in are great.  It stores the headset easily and neatly tucks into my backpack.
I am glad I treated myself to these headphones.
You should do the same.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Comfort and excellent noise cancellation
content: Very comfortable to wear and the noise cancellation is uncanny. Setup in Android was a bit clunky and I never did get Assistant working reliably.

author: inverted3600
title: super
content: only negative is maybe I'm volume control challenged using the right ear controls. I sat almost on top of the engine in the airplane and I was totally comfortable. they are perfect

author: sairoj
title: best
content: best purchase.. sound is awesome.. far more better than beats.. battery last for a week..

author: Frank Mccabe
title: Great headset
content: I like how simple they are to use.  No more switches than necessary, just two.  You can do a number of things with just a wave of your hand on the right side.

author: James Castle
title: Great sound, great noise cancelling, poor bluetooth connection
content: Sounds great, noise cancelling is amazing, but once or twice every time I use them they lose bluetooth connection. More if I'm moving around while using them.

author: Rad Jer
title: Phone calls aren’t what I was hoping for.
content: I’m not very happy with the blue tooth function when taking a phone call.

author: DAN
title: Best birthday 📦
content: The best birthday gift ever

author: Carl Truth
title: Nirvana
content:
The BT sound in the WH1000XM3 is not that great-the bass is too
overwhelming and cannot be tamed w/o severe trade offs. I also experienced some internal noise and distortion anomalies using BT, this in spite of all the sophomoric and mostly useless gimmick-ware in the Headphone Connect app.

Nirvana:
I use a wired connection and the Poweramp Music app instead. The WH1000XM3 ANC still works great in this mode also.

I can get both – excellent ANC AND great sound equal to (if not better), when compared to my beloved old Sony MDR-1R cans.

Caveats:

1- The Headphone Connect app will not function w/o a BT connection (no biggie).
2- The two buttons on the left cup work just fine.
3- The only right cup function that works in this mode is when you “Place your hand over the right ear cup to turn the volume down and deactivate noise canceling for instant conversation.”

This problem of losing other right cup functions (3) can easily be solved by using an appropriate music playing software (Poweramp for  example) and an audio cable with an inline remote (It works). In addition, using a decent inline remote/with mic might solve numerous complaints about the ‘bad’ phone reception’ problem.

I gave the Sony WH1000XM3 a 5 rating because of it’s fantastic noise cancelling,
and because the Sony engineers had the excellent foresight to allow for the above implementation.

author: John Brown
title: Exceptional performance in a fragile package.
content:
This is hands down, the very best fitting over the ear headphones I've had. I previously owned Bose's best available noise canceling product in 2013. I've also had the Zik parrot V1 and V3. The functionality is second to none.  Based on ask reviews I've seen this is tops.
HOWEVER, I made the mistake of picking up my two year old while holding these and the left side plastic casing cracked open. I'm not sure warranties cover any type of accidental damage. The left ear piece literally hangs from one wire at times. The cracks shown in the images I posted are enough to allow the metal head clip to literally slip out completely.
Don't use these headphones in any scenario that could involve any kind of impact. I'm just hoping that I can get 6 months of use out of these at this point.

author: adam
title: Almost Justifies the price
content: great noise cancelling, excellent sound, very comfortable.  these are exceptional headphones that sound great and have terrific ANC.  if these were $250 they would be the best on the market for price.  as good as they are, they are probably $50 too expensive.  they sound great but the advertised sound customization is overplayed.  if used in "sound quality" mode you can't really customize the sound.  you can work around this by using the EQ on your phone or streaming player but it was still kind of disappointing.  ANC and controls are elite.  great headphones overall with some minor quibbles including being slightly overpriced

author: mm
title: Comparison of Sony WH1000XM3, Bose 700, & Jabra 85+ Elite
content:
I purchased all three of these headphones because I couldn't decide which ones would be best for me.

Bottom line is, if you are looking for multi-purpose, noise-canceling headphones for the office, the Sony WH1000MX3 are NOT the headphones for you; but if you are are an audiophile who is mostly going to listen to music and just wants the convenience of being able to answer calls at the same time, then these are the BEST for you.

None of the three headphones do a good job of blocking out higher-pitched sounds like human voices, which was a big disappointment for me as that is a critical need in my new employers large "open office" setup. And the Sonys were the worst of the three. But all three do a great job of blocking out lower-pitched noise like fans, motors, etc.

Listening to music on the Sonys is phenomenal, and that's just using its default equalizer settings. It's rich, detailed, crisp sound that makes you feel like you are in the middle of a first class concert hall performance. There's no comparison between them and the other two, and I'm not even an audiophile. If that's your primary purpose, rest assured these are the headphones for you.

As an office headphone, though, they are lacking. You cannot connect to a computer, only your cellphone. As of this time, they don't use Siri, only Google Assistant and Alexa (I suspect Sony will fix that in a future firmware update). They don't block or even muffle human voices; of anything they made nearby conversations even clearer which makes them more distracting. The feature I was most excited about --  the hand-over-muff to pause music and "hear through" to ambient sounds -- turned out not to be all that helpful. As a right-hander, it ties up my right hand the entire time so I can't take notes on whatever I'm being told. Plus, people just seem to need me to move my headphones off my ear for them to believe I'm listening.

The Sony headphones look fairly high-end on the outer surfaces, but they feel cheaply made, especially inside the ear cups and the headband. The ear cups get hot much more quickly than the other two brands (compared all with music and ANC running). Instead of matching the cord colors to the beige-gold headset (or even using a standard white or cream cords), they are black which adds the the chintzy feel (for $350 you kinda expect more attention to detail).

The Sonys do have the best-designed case of all three. Compact, solidly built, has a built-in divider for the cords, has both a handle strap and an outer mesh slip pocket. Unfortunately it is covered in a cheap-looking tweedy fabric that grabs and holds onto dirt, dog hair, etc. if you get the "beige gold" headphones like I did, the fabric is a super ugly, chintzy-looking beige tweed that will look dirty within a couple of days.

In the end, the Jabras were the best suited for my needs because of their better noise cancelling of voices; Siri integration; ability to pair simultaneously with a phone and my laptop (note: the Jabras aren't designed to pair with laptops but I got them to by tweaking a few Windows 10 settings -- see my Jabra review for details); and clever convenience features like auto-pause music when removed from the ears and power on/off by simply swiveling the ear cups.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Do not get these headphones to use with a Kindle Fire HD
content:
These headphones are awesome IF you primarily use an Apple product.  Supposedly Android phones and tablets that can access the Apple software through Google Play will work fine.  But you can not access the required app through the Kindle app store.  Without the app,  the headphones will work only sketchily at best on the Kindle Fire HD.
My main frustration is that this information is not stated anywhere on the Amazon page selling this item.  In fact, there is a highlight that these headphones are an Amazon recommended product.  Why would Amazon not mention that this Amazon recommended product does not work on Amazon's signature tablet, the Kindle Fire?  Why do the specs not make a statement like "not recommended for Kindle Fire?  Why doesn't Amazon make and promote a similar type of headphones especially for the Kindle Fire?

author: Steven E.
title: Comfortable and Durable.
content: Beautifully designed Over the ear headphones, I purposely bought these for the gym, price was not a factor since I wanted quality. If you really focus through certain songs you can still hear outside noises while headphones are on, but minimal. So I’m very pleased with my purchase, I just bought swart Guards for them to help protect them from my training. But for me depending on the length I extend them to, they hold onto my head while running, lifting and jump rope. That’s all I need, but for quick movement training like run drills or any quick sudden movements to the left or right aggressively, I’m sure they would fall off.

author: Benjamin Chodroff
title: Terrible microphone quality
content: The microphone quality is simply awful. Yes, I have the latest firmware, reset the device many times, factory reset. Search YouTube and avoid this headset if you intended to use it to make calls. If you simply want noise canceling headphones with NO microphone needs, then this headset is great. However at this price point I would expect all features to work perfectly.

author: Anadmaudib
title: on a plane - INCREDIBLE
content: incredible noise cancelling on a plane....just incredible

author: Robert
title: The best
content:
These are the best over the ear headphones I have owned to date.  Noise cancelling, sound, battery life all 5 stars.
I think the software may have disrupted some on my earbud apps though.  I could not connect to certain earbuds after the sony  sound app was installed.

author: DustinG
title: Relatively Nice Pair of headphones
content:
I purchased these headphones and tried them out for about 2 weeks. I was upgrading from the Bose Soundlink 2s and was looking for headphones with noise cancellation.

I have to say that I really, really wanted to love these headhphones but could not bring myself to keep them.

-Features-
PROS
-USB C- Huge plus as I dont really have anything that charges with micros USB at this point. So definitely saves me from having to carry a micro USB cable for a single device. USB C is also a more robust connection when compared to micro USB and far less likely to wear out/break
-ANC- The auto noise cancellation in the MX3s is definitely top of the line. The MX3s did a great job at cutting out office chatter and background noise. Realistically when I was playing music as low to medium volume I could not hear a single thing outside of my music.
-Touchpad control- These worked very well, I especially like the cover right earcup to cancel ANC
-NFC pairing- very quick and painless pairing
-Sony MX3 App- The app was very cool with tons of customization possible
CONS
-ANC- The ANC is top of the line but realistically I was not BLOWN AWAY by it when compaired to the Bose QC35 IIs. switching back and forth between the MX3s and the QC35 IIs left no difference between the two that I could discern.
-Only able to pair to one device at a time. This is such a massive shortcoming for a $350 device. Some people will not find this to be a problem, and I must admit that I thought I could work around it. However, after trying them out I simply found this to be unacceptable. I work in an office setting and wear my headphones for give or take 6 hours a day. I have spotify going all day and the full app on PC is simply better suited for navigation. The mobile side works okay but i expect to be able to use the PC side app when I have it available. Couple this with the fact that I do not want to remove my headphones every time I get a cell phone call and the single pairing option is simply not workable for me. ***I did discover two things after some research. First, supposedly you can pair to two devices, one for audio, and another for hands free calling. However, after following the directions several times on sonys webpage I was never able to get this working. Second, you can pair the headphones to a mobile phone and control the Spotify app via you PC. This made the single pairing option much more manageable for me but is still an inconvenience.
-Sony MX3 app- Changing any of the audio settings in the app (base/treble/mids) drops the headphones into a lower bandwidth streaming option. I honestly could not tell a huge difference in audio quality when doing this but still found it disturbing

-Sound-
PROS
-I found the sound to be relatively accurate and warm, however that is about all I have to say that is nice about it
CONS
-Bass heavy- these headphones are really base heavy. This did make the headphones sounds more like a live concert, but I found the base to be muddy and actually drown out the mids and treble with some music I listened to. You are able to turn down the bass in the app but it drops down the quality of your bluetooth connection. On PC I had installed an EQ program and set up a custom profile to tone down the bass. Realistically though this is just extra dicking around that I did not expect with a 350 dollar set of headphones

-Comfort-
PROS
-i did like the fact that these hug your head in a more streamlined fashion, eliminating the Micky mouse look present in previous models
-The cushions on the headband and earcups are very plush and appear that they would hold up to years of daily use

CONS
-Straight up these are not as comfortable as my Bose soundlink 2s or the QC35 Mark 2s. I do not have overly large earls but still found that parts of my ear touched the inside of earcup. Its not like it was crushing my ears but the slight pressure was definitely there. This may sound like a small gripe, but when you are wearing these headphones for extended periods of time you will most likely find this to be an annoyance. These things also get hot unless you are doing absolutely nothing in a relatively cool environment. If the office was abit warmer than normal or I decided to take a walk around the office I could definitely feel the heat building up. Granted, I am normally not moving when wearing these but if I wanted to wear them while traveling and walking these headphones have a very good chance of making your ears sweat.

-Conclusion-
As I said, i really wanted to love these headphones. They are supposedly the latest and greatest, they look good, and have a ton of cool features and upgrades over anything else out there. Unfortunately, after only an hour or two of wearing them I found myself disappointed in them, not something you really want in a 350 dollar purchase. I stuck it out for two weeks and was actively trying to convince myself that these things were as good as everyone was saying they were. I am no music expert but found the sound in these to be very fatiguing and somewhat muddy. While my Bose may sound abit more hollow I have come to enjoy super crisp and punctuated listening across the whole spectrum. Sounds is obviously a very subjective aspect so you may feel differently but I find that my Bose offer a superior listening experience to my ear. The comfort was also a big letdown come from Bose. With my soundlink 2s i would often not even feel them. With the MX3s I definitely felt them and this only exacerbated with extended wear. While not necessarily uncomfortable they simply have a ways to go to dethrone Bose.
TLDR: For me, everything I found is basically the opposite of 98% of the reviews I read and watched on these headphones. I spent weeks trying to tell myself that I must be missing something that everyone else was seeing but in the end failed to change my views on any aspect of these headphones. For me in the end the Bose QC35IIs simply outperform the MX3s in every aspect that matters to me. I can wear my Bose all day without feeling the need to take them off, the listening experience is more pleasurable to my ear right out of the box (dont have to dick around with any EQ settings), and pairing to multiple devices eliminates the workaround pairing options on the MX3. My advice is to just go with your gut, nobody should have to justify shortcoming in a 350 dollar purchase.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great sound but terrible built quality
content:
I bought these after seeing all the reviews online about how great they are and as far as sound goes, they are. Music sounds great off my phone but there is a bit of lag when watching videos off my laptop (surface book 2). The ANC works great and the feature where you cover the right side cup to let ambient sound in works great.
Call quality is terrible, terrible, terrible!
I bought these with the insurance in case the hinges break like the previous models but thats pretty useless since it will not cover that and they will eventually break! What is gonna eventually break these headphones is the way you have to fold them to store in the case. Youll put so much use on the right cup and not the left that it will eventually just break from constant use versus the left side. The cups also swing in and out very easily when you hold them up, making them feel cheap.
For the high price point, look elsewhere, $80 headphones will last you longer, might not sound as good or have the great anc but others will last.
Returned mine after they started cutting out, major miss for sony.

author: Andrew Karaganis
title: Great. Best Purchase I ever made.
content: Great. Best Purchase I ever made.

author: Aaron Atkinson
title: You’ll fall in love with the sound of them but their comfort will completely surprise you.
content: The best noise cancelling headphones I’ve ever owned.  The sound quality is top notch and the ability to tweak your sound using the Sony app is a great touch. Beyond how great the cancel background noise what I love most is how comfortable they are. Some days at work I’ll wear them for 9 hours without any issues. Highly recommended!

author: Tsendsuren Baasankhuu
title: Not good quality
content: 3 months ago I bought it but now not working Bluetooth. Than blue light not turn on. Why i don't know. Anyway that is so expensive one. Very bad review for this headphone.

author: Bo
title: You'll be able to understand Eddie Vedder!
content:
Bought these via an open box deal, I guess some audiofile snob wasn't satisfied but I am.

I have a horse face and big ears that stick out so i find these more comfortable than the Bose qc3s however they do get pretty warm after a couple hours but they are light weight enough to do chores around the house.  Vacuuming with the noise canceling is pretty sweet.

The sound quality is pretty much what I expected, using the app is a must for different types of music.  My next best wireless headphones are the bluedio ufo2s and with the m3s you can definitely hear parts of the music that you can with the UFOs.  It's also kinda crazy when you watch YouTube because you can hear the slightest distortion or air touching the mic.  Sometimes its annoying but if you listen to asmr these will make your brain melt.

I only kept these over the audiotechnicas due to the comfort factor and the slightly better bass.  Not sure if they are worth twice the price for someone with a normal shaped head.

author: MW
title: Horrible noise cancelling
content: This purchase was a great disappointment. The noise cancelling feature is horrible.

author: Tyler Murray
title: This or Bose?
content: When buying noise cancelling headphones, it really comes down to these or the Bose quietcomfort 35 ii. Having tried both, I'd say that the Bose take the win in comfort, but everything else goes to Sony. Excellent sound quality, noise cancelling, battery life and touch features. The best noise cancelling headphones on the market IMO (at 350 price range).

author: Amazon Customer
title: Crisp, clear silence and you can still rock out loud music that is unbelievably clear.
content: These are by far the best noise canceling headphones I ever owned.  The noise canceling feature is so good in my opinion that it is like having your own silent room of peace and quiet.  The app for control seems to be very easy to use.  I think the sound quality from this unit is fantastic.  Used them on a recent flight and it was a blessing.  I’ve used them outside on my terrace in a noisy city and it made my evening incredibly relaxing.  They are very comfortable.  I have nothing negative to say at this point.

author: Anonymousse
title: Defective product--don't buy these from Amazon
content: After a month of off-and-on use my headphones go from full charge to dead in under an hour. Unfortunately these are now outside the return window. Buyers beware--Amazon has had problems with this product being defective in the past (they stopped selling the headphones for a while due to a "defective batch") and are unwilling to replace these headphones.

author: russell
title: Phenomenal sound
content: Simply great sound. And nc.  Get a little muddled with very complex sequences but great sound no or not.  And yes light years ahead of Bose.

author: Sherif Mokhtar
title: Works great..
content: Works great.. But expected total noise cancellation which in sometimes in some places still hear noise

author: Puya
title: Holy smokes!! These are awesome.
content: I've been stuck in a conference room with 10 people for the past few days, working on a project.  The noise was driving me crazy!  I tried some cheaper noise cancelling headphones, however, I could still hear people's conversations.  I decided to spend the extra money and give these a go.  I can no longer hear everyone's conversations.  The ambient noise feature is helpful when I need to listen in on a conversation.  In addition,  the sound quality is great!  Best headphones I've ever owned!

author: patey123
title: Not great for smaller heads
content: Noise cancellation would be great if these weren’t so wide/large on my head. My head is a bit on the small side, but the only way to experience the noise cancellation was holding them tight on my head. The side volume control either doesn’t function well or my product was defective. I returned them after a few days since they weren’t perfect for me and they are pricey.

author: R. O'Connor
title: An Excellent Purchase!
content: Sony put another great product out there. The noise canceling headphones work on a loud plane or in a crowded airport. I'm impressed.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Very good
content: Easy to use, good sound quality, excellent noise cancellation

author: Zaid Naser Al-Deen
title: The best!
content:
The 4 star rating is only because I cant get loud voice enough like other Sony's headsets

Otherwise this one is a beast!

author: TxAggie
title: Would buy again
content: Nothing to complain about. I love them. The associated app introduces soo many more useful features.

author: Joseph B.
title: The sound quality is top notch
content: Comfortable, and great noice cancellation. A little bulky, so I can see some people not liking them. But the sound quality is top notch, so worth it. The touch controls are a great concept, but it's easy to have the wrong gesture register (sometimes when you try and change the volume the track skips backwards or forwards, etc).

author: Roger L. McRobie
title: None better! Sony and Amazon.
content: There are no better noise cancelling headphones on the market. Period. You can't argue Sony quality. I've purchased their products 50 years ago. I could not find any of these for sale anywhere. No store or even the world wide internet had any. I prepaid order from Amazon and today, 18 days later I have them in my hands. Thank so much Amazon! Amazon and Sony, none better.

author: Shashank Govindarajan
title: 👍 - ANC and sound, 👎 - Comfort and touch controls
content:
These sound great and cancel a lot of noise. They just aren't comfortable enough for me. The earcups started getting warm and my ears started to itch after just 30 mins of use. I found my Bose QC15s way more lighter and comfortable than these. Also, the touch controls are finicky and take time to get used to.

Going to return these and buy a bluetooth adapter for my QC15s.

author: Covert II
title: These things are a lifesaver
content: Bought these after moving into my most recent apartment, let's just say the people upstairs have no respect for anything much less the people living below them (me). These headphones are the reason why I'm still sane, I just slip them on and go into my own world. The battery life is wonderfull, they charge really fast, they are super comfortable  (I have even had to sleep with them on a few times no complaints), and they don't give me a headache or put pressure on my ears even after long use.

author: brendon calderon
title: Great headphones
content: Best headset for flights

author: Moby Doug
title: Fabulous Noise Canceling Headphones
content: These are extremely comfortable headphones and the noise canceling feature is outstanding. Recently purchased for a long distance flight and the headphones were perfect.

author: DocJ
title: Outstanding product.
content: It was everything it was advertised to be.

author: Eugene Martin
title: BE AWARE These power down in 5 minutes while in noise cancelling mode!!!
content: Even when fully charged these headphones power down in 5 minutes when not connected to any device. So if one wanted to just have noise cancelling on while in your home or on a plane they will stop working and turn off in 5 minutes. After purchasing and having this problem I find out that Sony knows about this problem and refuses to fix it with an update. What a shame that Sony has all this high technology but has this one huge bugaboo. I hate to but I have to return these. Sony will probably make Amazon take this review down as they did on their own forums.

author: silona
title: It is NOT SILVER - it is a slightly shiny khaki... as best
content:
I'm returning it to get the black ones.

Why say Silver?  It is NOT silver!  It is a shiny dark khaki and looks nothing like the picture.  It is yuppie fugly.  it's so ugly - I just can't even.

author: D&I
title: Nice design!
content: Love the design and the case. Everything is good so far but after about an hour of use my ears are getting sweaty. Alexa is getting annoying so I am not so sure what is the benefit of having Alexa but I will give it a little bit more time to utilize it.

author: daniel
title: Not worth the money. Extremely flawed product.
content:
If you have done any research with these headphones you will see that they are top of the line with noise cancelling. This is true, and why they are so popular. However, many of the negatives of these headphones are very true as well. I thought I could adjust to the drawbacks, but it just is not worth it in the end. I wish I would not have put $350 into under developed headphones.
Here is a list in order of importance to me.

Pros:
-Sound quality is great and headphone EQ app is fantastic and underrated feature I was not expecting.
-Noise cancelling is as you would expect, very good.
-Lightweight and mostly comfortable
-Battery life is good, when powered on/off

Cons:
-Biggest con is there is no power-off when not being used. It is true that they will power-off when disconnected for 5 minutes from a source, but if you don't deliberately turn them off/on (and frantically keep checking) these things will stay on til 0%. Often my phone will remain connected to them for long periods of time even after use.

-Another huge con is the inability to make phone calls. They are practically unusable without a firmware update, which will likely never come as it would have already. Basically, the headphones are capable of picking up ambient noise through external mics and amplifying it is the headphones. This is a feature to allow you to hear external noise with noise cancelling enabled on occasion. However, this feature is forced on for every phone call. I mean unless you are in a completely silent area, there is no hope of hearing the person on the phone. It makes them completely and absolutely worthless for a phone call, which for a pair of $350 headphones should not be excusable.

-It is a chore to switch between which devices are connected to them. I quickly got to the point where I would just turn Bluetooth on/off completely on my phone or computer and just cycle power on the device to get them powered to the correct device. It is hard to explain the annoyance this is. My laptop will be closed and if it was the last device connected, I will have to open it back up, disable bluetooth, then close it again if I want any chance of getting my phone to connect.

-Their weight is comfortable, but they do not breathe at all. I could wear these for long periods of time if they did not get so hot around the ears. Even in cooler environment I have the same issue. My ears will get sweaty and it will be a huge relief to take them off. Don't even try working out with them. I tried a couple times and it is not worth it.

-Touch controls are simply awful. When they work it feels a little cool, but a majority of the time they do not, even with practice. I fear touching the control to increase the volume of a good song because it is a 50/50 chance it will just skip to the next song no matter how deliberately I try to not swipe forward. What is worse is you normally have to swipe multiple times to increase the volume more than a couple notches. That is, unless you perfectly swipe and hold the volume. I just get my phone out basically every time. That being said, it is easy to skip forward a track.

-The blue LED on the headphones flashes at basically random times every time you interact with the headphones. There is no setting to change this. This might seem nit-picky, but it will easily completely light up a dark room for no reason. I mean honestly if it would have a subdued LED and remain on as long as the headphones were on, that would help with the no auto-off issue. It got so annoying I opted to just cover the LED with tape.

I really wanted to like these headphones, but since the only redeeming quality is sound quality and noise cancelling, that should be the only thing you expect to get with your $350. With other headphones on the market with more advanced and also more basic features than these headphones, it makes you believe Sony put out an underdeveloped product and just ripped off their customers.

I would not recommend this product to anyone.

author: Dennis Lee
title: Very Comfortable.  Very Practical.
content: Very good headphones for how comfortable it is.  Very light and you can really focus on the music with the noise-cancelling.  Perfect for people living in noisy cities.  Links up with my Pixel 2.  Battery is great, I use it periodically so I am probably not a heavy user, but I find myself charging it every other day or a bit longer sometimes.

author: Richard T.
title: The best wireless headphones you can get
content:
These headphones are well worth the wait behind the backlog of purchases. Immediately after opening the box, and charging them, I took a walk into New York City. I adjusted the settings to noise cancelling, and then hit the play button of my music player. An audible "wow" came out of my mouth while walking with a crowd.

As with all noise cancelling headphones, it doesn't completely eradicate all sound, But I would say a solid 90% of the sound fades away. Especially the wind brushing sounds of passing cars. In my walk, I had moments where I had forgotten I was walking in the city and back at my apartment.

Sound quality is excellent for a pair of wireless headphones. The accompanying app is great to customize how much sound you want to come through using a scale of 0-20. Zero indicates the least amount of sound to come through.

Open palm to lower the volume of your music, and allowing sound to come through is great to use in the workplace, but will remain being awkward. However, I really enjoy it, and will continue being awkward. Down with the social norms!

Overall, the only problem I see with the earphones is during the summer. Around your ears will sweat, but my ears themselves have been all right so far. Since it's fall right now in the US at the time of this review, it's perfect.

author: 4togra4
title: Amazing but true!
content: These are simply amazing, the sound quality, and comfort obviously a quality product. I was reluctant to spend this much but man am I glad I did!

author: Esmond chen
title: Amazing!!
content:
You will not be dissapointed by these!
The ANC and sound quality is incredible!
Material quality is fair, lots of plastic to save wheight and lots of leather padding for comfort.
If your comparing these to the Bose qc 35 2
The Bose has the lead in comfort hands down. The Sony's are comfortable but not as close as the Bose. Sound quality is similar and only noticeable when comparing the tow side by side. The Sony has the lead there. ANC is great on both but slightly better on the Sony's. Durability and longevity goes to the Bose, they feature changeable earcups while the Sony's are fixed to the headphone itself. Overall the Sony's is an excellent choice for listening for about 30 minutes at a time before having to take a break from ear sweat. For long sessions for more than an hour go for the Bose. Their more airy and comfortable. I hope you found this helpful :)
This pair of Sony's is the best set of headphones I've ever used!

author: Jordan A. Mangano
title: Equalizer only works with phone
content:
Unless you're paired with your phone, you get stock sound quality. When paired with my Mac or anything other than my iPhone, there is no equalizer access. This causes the sound to be very bass-heavy and otherwise unbalanced. In other words, the adjustments you make in the app do not carry over to other devices or even, from what I can tell, to your next use after turning the headphones off.  I've also had some hiccups with the noise canceling, where the feature, that allows outside noise in, will turn on without touching the headphones.
I didn't think it was a big deal that these only connect to one device at a time, but it turns out to be a giant pain in the @$$.
I also have the Bose NC-700 and they are tuned very nicely. Not as much boom, but no equalizer necessary and consistent sound across devices.
These Sonys would probably have 5 stars from me, if not for these issues. I'm not sure why youtubers and reviewers go so nuts over these when there are such major issues that the competition has already taken care of.
I hope Sony resolves these issues in the XM4.

author: Austin Ace
title: Noice cancellation is excelent.
content: Volume control is erratic.

author: Alexey
title: Great headset!
content: This one is probably the best headphones I had. Used them for a while now. Has an app to manage the equalizer and other settings. Noise cancellation works fine. Cancelling voices and other sounds well.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Poor google connection
content: When connecting to my phone the google voice speeds up and the voice gets really high pitched. I don't know what is going on but the notifications are not understandable

author: ron wilson
title: Great for flights.
content: Nothing

author: Derek Sanderson
title: Some of the most comfortable headphones I've worn.
content:
I'm using these for work (2-4 hours TT per day), have already made several international flights with them, literally using these every single day, and it feels like I'm only having to charge it once a week.  So comfortable, noise cancellation is legit the best I've ever experienced (FYI - haven't tried out the Bose 700's to have anything to add concerning that one), sound quality is pretty good (I really had to experiment with the EQ in the app in order to get the sound profile in a place I was comfortable with), and I really can't stress enough on how good that noise cancellation actually is.

No regrets, at $298 these headphones are a no brainer.  I may sound biased towards these cans, but I'm no kidding currently wearing these at this very moment and they sound incredible after they've been broken in.  These will make your days better, I assure you.  Why are you still reading this?  Buy them!

author: vlad m.
title: Great headphones, superb sound
content: Incredible Noise Canceling, superb sound and great battery life. 10/10

author: Damion Waltersd
title: Sony putting in work!
content:
--Active Noise Cancellation: extremely solid.  What I appreciated most about the noise cancelling ability of these was that I did not need to crank my music to max volume in order to assist in cancelling out noise.  The fit, ANC tech as well as volume all are well tuned to allow for ANC.
--Fit: SUPER comfortable.  Cant emphasize it enough.
--Touch controls: very responsive and work as advertised.
--Battery life: I have never used these long enough to truly test the 30hr battery life claim.  However I had an 18hr flight in which I used these multiple times for 3-4hr stretches.  Definitely had 80-85% battery life left after all that usage.  Mind you this was with ANC at 100%.
--Packaging: the carrying case is very durable without being too bulky.  Easy to put the headphones away.
--EQ settings: besides comfort this is likely the best feature of these headphones.  The flexibility you have with the EQ are amazing.  You can literally get the exact sound YOU want and arent prisoner to the sound the company would like to put out.

author: Rita Taylor
title: sound quality is awesome
content: I love how it blocks out surrounding noise and the sound is excellent

author: djsh4dowfan
title: Bose QC 35 vs Sony WH-1000XM3
content:
I purchased both both Bose QC 35 and Sony WH-1000XM3 headphones. I ended up returning the Sony headphones. Here is my comparison of the two:

- Both have very good active noise cancellation (ANC)
- Both have good sound, although the Sonys probably have more base, which I personally liked
- Both come with an app you can install on your phone to configure them to an extent. The Sonys are more configurable, with an EQ and more granular noise cancellation.
- The Sonys have an adaptive noise cancellation feature that will change the ANC level based on where you are and what you are doing (e.g., sitting vs traveling). I personally don't care about this feature or find it that useful.
- I found the Bose to be more comfortable and easier to fold up put away. The Sony earpads weren't as soft, and the headphones clamped down on my head with more pressure.
- I found the Sonys to have more intense ANC overall. My ears are sensitive to ANC, and I get the feeling of having pressure in my ears with ANC enabled. That feeling was much less intense on the Bose, even on high, despite the Bose having very good ANC, which gave me the impression that the Sony ANC was more brute force and less accurate.
- The Sonys have neat touch controls for volume, play/pause, prev/next, etc. While it's a cool feature, it wasn't something I cared that much about, and I was often worried I was going to accidentally change something when taking the headphones off and on. I don't think the buttons on the Bose headphones detract from their looks.

Ultimately I returned the Sony headphones because I found the Bose to be more comfortable. My biggest gripe about both pairs of headphones is they do not save your last ANC setting! I cannot believe this feature was overlooked. I don't plan on using ANC all of the time. If I turn the ANC to low or completely off, when I turn the headphones off and on again, it will reset to high. The Sony app even allows you to configure the ANC at a granular level and allows you to configure the ANC for different usage patterns when the adaptive ANC is on; however, those settings also didn't persist, making them basically useless. I found the Sony Android app to be pretty buggy in general. I would strongly prefer an actual physical switch for the ANC setting instead of just having the setting be software controlled.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Hinge broke on the first trip while in the case
content: I've owned two different versions of the Bose QuietComfort headphones and recently purchased the the new Sony noise cancelling headphones based on reviews. The sound is indeed significantly better than the Bose and the USB-C rechargeable battery was a much better experience. Sadly on the second trip with the headphones the hinge broke while the headphones were in the case. I guess I must have misaligned them but I expected a lot more from a $350 set of headphones. My Bose had gone on countless trips and subjected to much worse and did not break.

author: Kaiwen Zheng
title: Great headphone, easy control
content: I really like this headphone, excellent noise cancelling and amazing sound quality. I returned the product cause it's a bit too large for me and I decided earbuds would work better, but I am still happy with the quality of the product.

author: LoyMachedo
title: VALUE FOR MONEY!
content: I was stuck in between the Bose QuietComfort 35 II and Sony Noise WH1000XM3. I think this one is much better. I would recommend you go for it.

author: Darren C Royal
title: Inconceivable how absent sound the experience is...
content: Simply the best headset I own. The NC tech is startling how noise depriving they are! I get slightly dizzy for first few minutes because it is what I image being in space or a vacuum. Sound quality is superb!

author: Gerald X.
title: Excellent
content: Best headphones i have ever owned.

author: Isaiah S.
title: Worth it.
content: Honestly the best pair of headphones I've ever used, yet also the most expensive. Anc is awesome and touch control was a thousand times better than I thought it would be.

author: US277437
title: Wow! Fantastic headphones! But missing USB-C Cable and crappy Sony support.
content:
These headphones are very good and have by far the best audio fidelity and noise canceling of any NC headset I have ever owned, approaching (though still not quite reaching) that of professional studio headphones. And they are comfortable to wear for hours on end. The noise canceling is very effective, even on commercial flights. The bluetooth is very stable and I have experienced no audio quality or disconnect issues as I have with other bluetooth headphones and earbuds.  And the battery lasts me a couple weeks and you can easily check battery levels by tapping the power button twice - battery level is reported via headphone audio.
One additional surprise was the great sound quality in both directions when making calls. I never could use my previous Bose and Sony NC headphones for phone calls.
