My job has me on several conference calls daily with most lasting 60 to 90 minutes and previous NC headphones would have poor audio quality with folks on the other end having difficulty hearing me, or the audio would cut out intermittently. Not so with Sony’s latest model. Audio in both directions is stable and FM DJ clear and strong. Instead of complaining they can’t hear me, I now get asked what headset I am using because the audio is noticeably better than others on the call.
So, with all those positive comments, why only 4 instead of 5 stars? Because Sony packaged them without the USB-C charging cable and would not provide the obvious remedy of shipping me one. I received the headphones the day of an evening cross-country flight. This is my first USB-C device so I had no cable to charge them and they arrived with no power. The manual and box both said the cable was included, and the headphone case even has a special pocket for it. The box arrived new, unopened from Amazon still wrapped in factory plastic, and Amazon was the seller and fulfiller. I could not even use my new headphones as I had no way to charge them and a long flight quickly approaching. I ended up buying a cable at the airport for way too much markup.
I could have returned the headphones to Amazon and waited for another set, but that meant traveling without them for this trip. Having bought my own cable, I was still owed one and figured Sony would gladly send me the missing cable for my inconvenience. Manufacturers usually prefer handling issues this way versus a full retail return which is more costly for all involved. Sony’s response follows and is why this review has a 4 rather than 5 star rating.
“We really wish we could help you. We at email support deal with basic troubleshooting steps. We request you to contact the Amazon support team. We are positive that they will help you.”

2018-11-16 EDIT: I recently switched to an iphone without a headphone jack. When used over Bluetooth for conference calls, I do get frequent complaints that folks cannot hear me. Wired, these headphones are xcellent for conference calls. Over Bluetooth for conference calls they are, unfortunately, mediocre.

content: Great headphones. They feel a little fragile but if you get a case that you don't fold them down into should cut down on the stress on the joints.

author: MU

content: Great for Airplanes! NC works incredible, companion app for android is a must. Hard to drop 350 USD for headphones, but if you enjoy high quality sound, performance and style, you'll love these.

author: Skylar
title: Just buy

The sound quality is excellent, the noise cancelling is outstanding, USB-C charging, but at the end of the day, if youre not comfortable, you gotta make that tough choice to return which I did. author: d,harris
title: Good quality

author: Amazon Customer
title: Sound cuts out at odd intervals
content: I like the design and feel of them, better than the bose in that respect. I owned a pair of QC35 for a while but decided to upgraded because they fell apart and where crap quality. These seem a lot better except for the fact that you can't listen to music! The bloody things keep cutting out at odd intervals and it drives me up the wall to the point where I just use the wire. Kind of defeats the whole point. Idk if it's the new bluetooth or what but neither my computer(Zephyrus) or phone (Xperia Z5 Premium) can function properly with these new sony headphones. Too bad really, I was hoping for someone to outdo bose after the experience I had, but whenever I need bluetooth now I have to go back to the old busted bose. Anyway, I have seen a ton of positive reviews so this might just be isolated to my case but I thought I'd throw it out there in case anyone else has a similar issue.

author: toobz
title: great sound but mediocre connectivity
content:
I purchased these to replace V-Moda Crossfade2 Wireless Rose Gold and the Sony does offer superior sound and the touch controls work adequately.  I prefer the touch controls to tiny buttons.

Where the Sony fares less well in comparison to the V-Moda is that it drops the Bluetooth connection more often, with a turn of the head or relatively small movement from the transmitter.  I'm going to keep these because of the superior sound, but the connectivity issue is annoying.  Nonetheless the Sony represents an advance in this technology and one can see the day when wireless supplants wired is not far off.

author: anmb
title: Great Noise Cancelling Quality and Super Comfortable
content: I’ve been looking for noise cancelling headphones for a while now, especially because I travel so much, and was initially deciding between these headphones and another leading brand. After trying both pairs in a nearby electronics store, I quickly found that the noise cancelling quality and level of comfort of these headphones was superior. Really happy with this purchase!

author: Pedro Leal
title: Better than Bose
content: Amazing sound quality and noise cancellation. Good touch controls, comfortable to wear, and the phone app is awesome.

author: Clay Kirby
title: These headphones will amaze you!
content:
I was a little leary of buying these because of the price.  But now that I bit the bullet I have absolutely no regrets.  Definitly worth the money!!!

Sound quality.
Absolutely amazing.  These deliver robust lows, great mids,  and very crisp clear highs.

Noise canceling.
I had no idea how much ambient noise was in my office until i put these on and turned them on.  The is the most silence i believe i have ever heard.  On a plane you can still faintly hear the noise of the engines but definitely filters out most of the sound.

Controls
The controls on these are top notch.  There is only two buttons but one whole side it touch sensitive and uses gestures to control the functions.  Very creative and easy to use.

App
The application for the phone works well and very easy to use.

author: Amazon Customer

When I reach to take them off of my head, I end up switching tracks or performing other unwanted actions.  the NC/Ambient button is very pointless.  ++ on that they charge quickly and deplete slowly.  I'm really enjoying the battery life.

author: Luis Acosta
title: Comfort and sound
content: These  headphones are amazing talk about technology wow 100% satisfaction

author: Peter B. Nelson
title: Superb investment for knowlege workers
content:
I'm sorry to say, but these Sony WH-1000XM3 wireless, noise-cancelling headphones have replaced my Sennheiser Momentums as daily wear. It's not because they sound better, but they're **almost** as good, and the noise-canceling is so fantastic I can't go back. The wireless is a bonus.

I use these headphones from my Acer laptop running Linux, or alternately from my Samsung S7 Android phone, both over bluetooth. I write code, all day, every day, usually from my home office. I wear these headphones for at least eight hours a day. I use them for video-conferencing, music (mostly Gregorian chant, some EDM, whatever) and occasional podcasts (when drudgery-coding).

An added use-case for these headphones is just sitting in silence. That turns out to be pretty danged amazing for intense coding sessions. When my kids start practicing piano in the room next to the office I simply cannot work without some kind of ear protection. I previously wore industrial ear-muffs.

These noise-cancelling headphones actually reduce noise (specifically piano practice) volume even more than a pair of Sellstrom HP431 premium ear muffs rated at 31db. And the Sellstroms are so uncomfortable I can only wear them for an hour at a time. The Sonys are so comfortable I can wear them all day every day. And because they're wireless I often just wander around the house with them still on my head and I don't even realize the family is calling me. I live my life now in a blissful cone of silence. Ahhhhh...

Regarding battery charge times. I intentionally tested them by disabling auto power off (using the app, see below) and running them down to the "battery low" warning, then charging them for 20 minutes. A 20 minute USB2.0 charge (at 0.5A) provided 4 hours of listening time. I did this test twice and got the same result both times. Other than that intentional test, I charge these overnight every couple days and have never run them down in the course of a full day's use.

Positives: excellent audio quality. Incredible noise cancelation. Superb comfort. Wireless.

Negatives: microphone quality for voice conferencing is decidedly sub-par. I use my external USB mic for all calls, so this defect doesn't affect me. But if you expect to use these headphones for making phone calls, definitely try before you buy.

Tips! After using these headphones for a few weeks, I have some tips:

Phone App! Install the app called "Sony Headphone". You need it to change some settings, including the equalizer.

Equalize! I find the default settings to be far too bassy, stupidly boomy. There are six equalizer presents, none of which are to my taste. My preferred settings are to drop the 400Hz bar to -3, and put the Clear Bass setting at -1. This makes the Sonys sound almost as good as my Sennheiser Momentums.

Volume Swipe! Control the volume with your finger. The volume of the headphones can be turned up or down with a finger slide on the exterior of the right ear-can. If volume is too low (as mine was, at first) be sure to swipe-up repeatedly to maximize the volume to its highest level. You'll know when your at full max when you hear two beeps.

Blueman! For Linux users (I'm running Mint 18.3) my built in bluetooth settings application didn't work. To use these headphones with my Acer Linux laptop I had to install a superior "Bluetooth Manager" program, which worked much better. To do this (in Ubuntu or Mint), just run `sudo apt-get install blueman`. Also, after pairing and connecting, be sure to set the device to "Digital Stereo" mode, not "Headset" and not "Handsfree." The latter two sound like a tin can.

Hey, get this! The super cool song in the Sony marketing video is available on youtube for free. Be that guy! Just search for "Sam Fischer x TheGifted - Restless (Official Audio)". Sweet, sweet tones.

author: Grant E Knowles
title: Great!  My ears still get hot.
content: Love this product. Love the sound. And especially love the battery life. Your ears will get hot in these. Be aware:).

author: Mark M.
title: Really good, but not quite for me.
content: These are good headphones for their price-range.  The sound and noise cancelling are great as many other reviewers observe.  For me, I didn't like the feel of the ear cups after about 40 minutes.  They were a little to small, but what I really didn't like was the feel.  They were kind of a cheap plastic that didn't breath like leather, which competitors offer, albeit at a higher price.  For that money, I decided to return and go to a Bose or Master & Dynamic.  I decided on the M&D MW65 at 500 bucks.  I'll see if it was worth it when I get them next week.

author: Michael Pouchet
title: Don't hesitate....just buy em!
content: It was a tough decision between the Bose QC-35II's and the Sony 1000XM3's but USB-C & 30hrs battery...sold. Just get them already!

author: Malcontent
title: I can't believe how good these sound
content:
Holy cow.

I was prepared for some sort of compromise, even at this price, but there's practically none at all. The noise canceling, as you've probably read, is great. But I want to emphasize the sound quality... it's simply stupendous.

My first reaction to the sound was "yech", actually, because they sounded so different from my wired headphones, the Sony MDR 7506. Compared with those, the WH-1000XM3 initially sounded "muddy" to me and I was ready to box 'em up and send 'em back. But after listening to them for a couple of days they grew on me tremendously, and I had to admit that I was really just accustomed to the sound of my MDR 7506, and after taking time to adjust, the WH-1000XM2 actually sounded way, way better. Way better.

I also have a pair of Sennheiser HD6XX 'phones paired with a Schiit DAC and amp stack, and truly, the Sonys are not a really noticeable step down.

I wear the Sonys at work, and can listen to them for hours at a time with no discomfort. I can't overstate how amazing these are. Just get them.

author: Amazon Customer
title: High-latency, miserable set up
content:
I bought this product thinking that it would be great for gaming and listening to music. Good news, it works perfectly for listening to music- on my phone, and exclusively on my phone.

On my PC, I originally couldn't get it to work at all. Then slowly but surely I got the headphones to work at horrendous quality. Like worse than AM radio quality. I bought a physical bluetooth transmitter (instead of the integrated one on my motherboard that works perfectly fine for everything else) and tried using that. Some more piddling to get that to work and I finally get to the point where I can listen to a youtube video. I already feel some latency so I take an audio reaction time test. Average reaction time: 400ms. Just to scale, on my usual headphones it's under 200ms. I change the codec (using the phone app, since there doesn't seem to be a different way to change it) and it only seems to go down to APTX. Regardless, I try it again and get slightly less latency. Still essentially unbearable for playing games and makes watching videos feel shitty. The sound was great besides the buzzing white noise that never seemed to stop. I've now worked on fixing these headphones for 6+ hours and bought a wireless transmitter that just makes them usable. I really wanted to like these headphones; they look nice, my music sounds good on them and they're super comfy but I can't justify almost $400 (more if you count the bluetooth transmitter) for a product that I can't play games with.

author: Vlad
title: Best value
content: WOW just WOW. Everything about these headphones is amazing! These are the best bang for the buck headphones you can get if you travel often. The noise cancelling feature really silences outside noise making you feel a little more cozy in the airplane seat.

author: Jessie N
title: 9/10 Amazing sound, NC works awesome, just wish they got louder
content: Amazing headphones with superior NC abilities, they will truly block out any & all outside noise and have you completely committed to the music. My only true gripe about them is that I wish they would get a bit louder but I am someone who likes to blast music so if you’re in the same boat as me and noise cancelling isn’t the most important thing to you, go with some Beats Studios for enhanced volume. Other than that, the sound quality is impeccable and is also super customizable to anyone’s liking.

author: Amazon Customer
title: I received a Faulty Pair unfortunately.
content: Excellent  headphones other than the pair I received randomly skips songs or pauses while I'm listening to them.. if I could trade these in for a pair that works properly I would have no complaints.

author: Karim
title: Great product that has issues connecting easily to devices via bluetooth
content: This headphone can't connect easily to some laptops.  It can't connect simultaneously to 2 devices. My  Ears would sweats after about 20 mins of use. Overall good product with minuses when connecting via bluetooth to some devices .

author: Bruce West
title: Dear sweet Baby Jesus!
content:
Are you kidding me?!
Are you really kidding me?!
This is what I’ve been missing my whole life!
My life is complete. I’ve truly lived. I may now wander off to die a glorious, fulfilled death.
These things are incredible! I LOVE LISTENING TO MUSIC WITH THESE!
Excellent battery life. Excellent audio. Excellent quality and feel. Bonus: the active noise cancelling drowns out the sound of my wife complaining that all I’m doing anymore is listening to music. Winning.
I mean, I’ve used high end headphones before, but these things take the cake.
I wish I’d had headphones like these my whole life.
I wish I had more ears so I could justify buying more of these.
Amazing.
Simply,
Amazing.

author: Johnny
title: They were the best headphones of the year for a reason
content: The best headphones I've had and well worth the price to me.

author: J. Love
title: Total Dud
content: Two days after use the unit would not power up. I tried multiple chargers, several reset methods in the programming, you name it.  Refunded it and never looked back.  Clearly, you have an over-engineered product if the flippin thing can't even turn on after a few days of use.  My 30 dollar Noise Canx  headphones are still going strong ... C'mon Sony.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Sony comfort?
content: I had this product for a few days, but then returned it. Sound was great. Noise cancelling was great. Fit was good. There are a lot of reviews that say these Sony’s are as comfortable as the Bose QCii. I suppose everyone is a bit different, but in my experience, no way. These Sony’s get hot and uncomfortable (for me) in about an hour. The Bose are lighter, more comfortable, and frankly has a bit cleaner sound. These Sony’s are nice, but not for me on an 8hour flight.

author: Steven Price
title: Fantastic headphones, better than Bose
content: I couldn’t be happier with these headphone. They block out all the sounds of my office. I really like how customizable the noice cancelation is from the app. Best of all, they don’t give me a headache from pressure like the Bose headphones did.

author: Kindle Customer
title: It's okay..
content: This product is ok. The touch pad is not as convenient as you would think. It can only pair with one thing at a time. For $350 dollars I am disappointed

author: Min
title: Amazing!
content: Totally amazing!!! Good for traveling and gym workouts. The moment When put on the Song WH1000 the world is belong only to my self.  Everything and everyone else are fade-away.

author: GR
title: Excellent Noise Cancellation, Great Sound Quality
content:
I'll preface my review by stating that these are my first pair of bluetooth cans, as well as first pair with noise cancellation. I travel for work quite frequently and have been wanting a pair of noise cancelling headphones for quite some time. Like most, I was between the Bose QC35 ii's and these Sony WH-1000xM3s. I visited a local store and tried out both. My initial conclusion was that the Bose cans are more comfortable (lighter, deeper ear cups), but with weaker NC and a more neutral sound signature. I ended up ordering the Sony's and now have used them for 3-4 hours/day since receiving them.

Build Quality/Materials - Initial thoughts upon unboxing - these are solid. The soft touch plastics used feels durable and of good quality.  These do not feel cheap to me whatsoever. The detents on the headband are well defined and feel like they'll hold up to daily adjustment. Sufficient padding on the headband as well. The ear cups are well padded and the synthetic leather feels of high quality. No creaking or odd sounds when flexing these way past what normal on/off the head use subjects them to. Only time will tell how these hold up to daily use, but I'm happy with the build quality out of the box.

Fit - I have a large head. I wear a size 7-5/8 fitted baseball cap. My longest continuous listening session with these thus far was ~4 hours. No major discomfort to report. I had no fatigue along my jawline from the ear cup clamping force, and zero discomfort along the crown of my head. I will say, my ears/head get warm with these on for extended periods of time, even while stationary. When moving around the house, I started to sweat a bit. I do tend to run hot but regardless, these are a warm set of cans. I do think these will be just fine for stationary use (such as on a plane) and that's how I intend to use them 95% of the time.

Noise Cancellation - One word: Wow. As mentioned above, this is my first pair of headphones with noise cancellation. I fly a lot for work and wanted the best of the best in this category. My old Sennheiser HD 429s, which are over ear/closed back, but have no noise cancellation, only really drown out ambient noise when listening at 80+% volume, which is not ideal for hours long flights. After watching the numerous comparison review videos on YouTube, and trying both the Bose QC35 ii's and these cans in store, I feel I made the right choice. The noise cancellation is truly remarkable. The quick attention feature works great as well. I can cover the right ear cup and ambient noise/voices become almost immediately audible. I've tried the Ambient Sound Mode around the house and I will say, that even with "Focus on Voice" selected, I have a hard time hearing someone speaking to me if the music volume is above ~20%. I have a flight next week and will amend this section of my review after with my thoughts on the NC on a plane.

Sound Quality - I've been leary of bluetooth headphones for fear of sound degradation due to the wireless connection. My iPhone 8 Plus doesn't have a headphone jack and I've been forced to use the dongle to listen to my Sennheisers, which is less than ideal. After my first listening session with the Sonys, I can confidently say that to my untrained ears, the 1000xM3s absolutely blow my wired Sennheisers out of the water in terms of sound quality. Yes, these are 3x the cost, but I'm still incredibly impressed with the sound quality here. As others have mentioned, these were a bit bass heavy for my tastes out of the box. However, the Sony Connect app gives full EQ control over the sound profile of these cans. In my opinion, the user control available in the app truly pushes these headphones to the next level. Everyone's musical preference is different, and you have full control of the sound with this app. I'm all over the place with my music - from progressive jazz such as Pat Metheny, to the fast and furious riffs of Mastodon, to the undulating bass lines of Flamingosis and Jazzinuff. These headphones deliver! The bass is punchy (and heavy at the upper EQ levels), mids and highs come through prominently and clear, and the soundstage is spot on for my ears.

Pairing & Battery Life - After unboxing, I powered on the headphones and connected them to my iPhone. Pairing was quick and painless. Battery life was at 60% out of the box. I plugged them into a 5V, 1.5 amp power adapter for 10 minutes, using the included USB-C cable, and the headphones were bumped up to 80% battery level. It seems the quick charge claims of 5 hours playback in 10 minutes of charge are valid. I've since listened to them for a total of ~15 hours, and the battery level is showing 30%. The battery level changes in 10% increments. So for my use case, 50% battery loss over 15 hours of listening = 30 hours assumed playback with a full charge. Bang on to Sony's claims. All of my listening has been with Noise Cancelling active, and anywhere from 30 - 70% volume. I'll top these up to 100% battery prior to travelling and will report back with observed battery life for a full charge.

Included Accessories - The carrying case is what I expected. I see it holding up to travel just fine. The internal cable pocket is a bit tight but fits the included cables without much fuss. The included USB-C cable is shorter than I'd like, but seems to be of good quality. The included 3.5mm cable has a straight male connector at one end (for connection to the headphones) and a 90 degree connector at the opposite end. It's an acceptable length.

Other Notes - I've yet to make or receive a phone call with these on. One of the most talked about negatives, at least in the reviews I've read, is how poor the microphone quality is on these headphones. I don't ever plan to take phone calls with these on, so this was never a factor in my purchasing consideration for these. But, I'm sure at some point I'll test out the mic and will report back. Lastly, single device connectivity - I only ever listen to music from my phone so this is another non issue for me. Just to try it out, I did switch listening from my phone to my laptop, and it took maybe 45 seconds to disconnect from one device, connect to the other and then start playing music again.

In conclusion, I'm VERY impressed with these headphones. The noise cancellation is top notch, sound quality for a music enthusiast (read: NOT an audiophile) is excellent, the Sony Connect app is feature rich and gives the user full control, the carrying case is sufficient/in line with other headphones of this class and the build quality is great as well. Only time and use will tell how these hold up in the long run, but so far, these are hands down the best headphones I've ever had the pleasure of owning.

author: D. Burton
title: Way too warm to use for very long
content: These are really awesome with one fatal flaw, which caused me to return them.  I felt like I was going to pass out from how hot I got when wearing them for more than 30 minutes. I’ve been an in-ear guy, and maybe a hot head is common for all over-ear headphones, but I’m going to go back to buds.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Very good product
content: The headphones are great.

author: Nick
title: Sony brings the bass!
content:
I couldn't decide between the Sony WH1000XM3 and the Bose QuietComfort 35 II so I bought both for a side by side comparison. I initially bought the Bose due to the slightly better reviews.

Sony vs Bose
Ultimately both the Sony and Bose headphones have great sound, noise-cancellation, style, and work well with your smart assistant. However, where the Bose fell short for me was in the bass department. It had none. I felt something was missing with all of my music while using the Bose.  I listen to a lot of EDM music while I code (don't judge me) and without good bass you just can't get into the zone, ya feel me?

All about that bass
The Sony WH1000XM3 on the other hand has amazing bass. Even better is that the Sony Connect app allows you to adjust bass levels and has an equalizer to adjust music settings to your liking. It also has a setting to mimic different environments such as putting you at an outdoor concert, concert hall, or in the middle of a club. This is a great option and really lets you experience the same music in multiple ways. The Sony app also has sound positional control as an additional setting. The Bose app does not have any options for customization, what you hear is what you get basically.

One feature that the Bose wins on is connecting with two devices simultaneously. With the Sony you will have to disconnect from your current device before connecting to another one. It's not a big deal to me, but some people really like that feature about the Bose.

Final Verdict
I ended up keeping the Sony and returning the Bose. The Sony WH1000XM3 ultimately gave me a better experience with my music and more importantly it gave me the power to adjust music to how I wanted to hear it. Algorithms are great at automating a lot of things, but not when it comes to personal music preferences. Sony made the right choice by leaving it up to the end user.

author: Amazon Customer
title: The best available
content: Simply the best available ANC headphones at the moment.  My coworker has the Bose QC35 II and another has the Surface Headphones.  We all agree the Sony is the best all around.  Noise cancellation is noticeably better than Bose and leaps above Surface.  Same with sound quality.

author: Anonymous
title: Unusable in the cold
content:
These headphones are unusable outdoors. If the temperature goes below freezing, the touch controls go crazy - registering random clicks/gestures, muting your music, starting up the Google assistant, and then not responding at all to your actual gestures.

The headphones are nice, but you really can't use them anywhere remotely cold. And the worst part is that the touch controls aren't necessary (I don't use them at all because they're not responsive enough even at room temperature), but there is no way to disable them in the app.

author: Andrew
title: Solid Product, worth the price premium
content:
From a person as miserly as I am, it takes a lot for me to feel like dropping $300 for anything, let alone some headphones, but these are a high-quality product.

Sound Quality is paramount for me, and I love the customization from the supplemental app you can use as an equalizer, and this product does not skimp at all.  It catches details in songs I've known for years, which I've never heard. I love these things.

Comfort is another factor, as I typically get headaches from anything on my head from hats, to other headphones. I can honestly say these are very comfortable for extended use even with a giant noggin such as mine.

A word of caution to anyone looking to use these during athletic endeavors, (e.g., at the gym or running): if you plan on using these while working out, beware of the wider headband fit on this model causing these things to slip off your head with too much movement.

Durability hasn't been tested much as I put these things in their included hardcover case as soon as I stop listening to music. They are plastic, which certainly helps with keeping these things lightweight, but I worry how these things would fair if I gave them an actual drop to the pavement from 6 ft in the air.  I think they would survive but may easily scratch or crack somewhere.

Noise-cancelling is nearly unparalleled from all other headphone models I have tested against (Bose, AKG, Jabra, Seinhauser, etc.)

Controls/ Interface- There is a bit of a learning curve with the touch-sensitive design of the controls, but otherwise straightforward. The Google Assistant is a fun feature (when it works), and the "hand-cupping" gesture to turn off the noise-cancellation is excellent in a pinch.

If you are teetering on whether to buy them, DO IT as after literally weeks of comparing spreadsheets and paneling friends like the nerd I am, I kept coming back to these.

author: joshua E. johnson
title: Great Sound, Bad Rash
content:
I was loving these for about 3 straight days before I realized the discomfort of my ears was a horrible rash! It's exactly where the headphones were pressing and spread into my scalp area too. Not fun. I went to the dermatologist and she confirmed my suspicion that it was these headphones that gave me an allergic reaction. Lots steroid creams. First allergic reaction to anything besides poison ivy.

I was bummed because I LOVED these for both my morning NYC train commute as well as my video editing at work. It blocked out all the loud sport talk from my friends and helped me focus. The sound was really great and loved the google assistant UI. Made sense. The controls for volume and skip are a little tricky but would have prob got used to it.

Anyone else run into this?

author: Brian Jimmerson
title: Great pair headphones
content: The Noise Canceling feature on these headphones are outstanding.  Sometimes my office gets a little loud, so I use these with some soft music to stay focused.  Occasionally, my co-workers, complain about me not being able to hear them, so I use the Ambient sound mode to alleviate that complain. The only issue that I have is that the volume control is not as responsive as I would like.  These are the best pair of headphones that I've ever owned.

author: Nik P
title: battery didnt charge
content: the battery didnt charge from the day one. The charging indicator turned off after a minute of being plugged in. tried ac adaptor and cable but nothing. had to return

author: aaron
title: GET THE AUDIO TECHNICA M50XBT INSTEAD!
content:
The hype is dead. These headphones are not worth the $300+. Maybe I had a lemon but let me tell you a few reasons why these are not worth the buy.
1. The Bluetooth is choppy and interferes with the audio. I would take them with me to the gym and whenever I would lift weights my music would not play.
2. Forget about wearing these with a hoodie. The touch controls are so sensitive that my hoodie would pause the music.
3. They are very fragile. Any accidental drop will brake these. I have audio Technica m50x and those have lasted me year's. I've dropped them sat on them and bent them and they are still kicking till this day. The Sony's feel like any wrong twist will brake them.

If you are in the market for good headphones that are going to last you long then I suggest getting the m50x Bluetooth version. They are $100 dollars cheaper and just as good as these if you don't mind not having usbc or ldac.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Plastic discolors on the silver headphones.
content: This product works as advertised and I'm happy with the overall functionality of the product. My main reason for the 1 star is that the product took up paint discoloration from an airline seat and I believe it's because their plastic has issues. You should not buy the silver product - if you do, expect plastic discoloration to occur.

author: Andrew
title: Great headphones
content: Dont like the volume control but other than that amazing product

author: Billy liu
title: good
content: good

author: James Welsh
title: Sound in right ear cup
content: There is a static sound in the right ear that is really annoying. I have only had my headphones for about 2 months and while the noise cancelling is good, there is a sound like win rushing around constantly in the right ear cup.

author: Rob Holub
title: Awesome headphones
content: These are amazing headphones, great sound quality and balance, noise canceling works well also. Great battery life

author: Kit
title: By far the best Noise Cancelling set.
content: I have used this 1000XM3 for couple months now and I love it. Very good quality on both sound and build. I forgot how much I get mine, but you should try to get one when there are discounts.

author: Tm
title: Great Headphones but AMAZON IS SELLING ALREADY OPENED UNITS AS NEW
content: I got a pair of these from Amazon about a month ago and they've been the best pair of headphones I've owned ever. Unfortunately, I'm prone to losing things, and left my backpack (with headphones in it) in a restaurant. Never got them back. I love these so much I immediately bought another pair (much to my wallet's dismay). Amazon sent me an already open unit. For this premium price, there's no excuse. Especially for an item that's been on peoples heads and around their ears. Really pathetic Amazon.

author: Thatonebuyer
title: Customer service/faulty
content:
The left casing cracked for no reason. On my
head, Ouch! I called customer service and they told me that this is not not something they cover in the warranty. Awesome. Waste of almost $400...

author: Selin
title: Mind blowing
content: The noise canceling is amazing and sound quality is exceptional. They are also super lightweight and very comfortable to wear for hours on end. I would buy these again and again.

author: We Are Desire
title: Great sound, poor quality, worse customer service
content:
I picked these up and loved them! I read so much about how amazing these headphones were: the comfort, the battery life, the sound, and the noise cancellation. When I first wore them, I was in love. These were everything I wanted and more, and I was so proud of this purchase.

Unfortunately, after only two months, I noticed a small stress crack where the right ear cup meets the headband. I was bummed, but thought it was no big deal because I hadn't abused the headphones in any way, and surely Sony would stand by the one year warranty. Nope.

Sony stated that any physical damage isn't covered, even though the warranty states it only does not cover damage incurred outside of normal use. The headphones are pristine other than this small crack and obviously haven't had any damage. I disputed the findings and was still told they would not be covered. Now I move into the arbitration phase.
Was a great product ruined by terrible customer service. Really makes me second guess my purchase and Sony in general.

author: DT
title: Awesome
content:
Coming from noise cancelling Bose earbuds that I used regularly in business, at Starbucks, at home and when traveling. After 6-7 years the battery began to suffer and then, my brother in law forgot his Sony M3's in my car after a recent family road trip. Basically, I tried them on and immediately thought this is the answer to all my problems at work.

 The noise cancelling is at least 5 times as good as the aforementioned Bose. The sound quality is immersive. Comfort level 10/10. The case is nice and I feel they are well protected when not in use.

Note for adjusting your EQ. I am a hobbyist guitarist for 30 years. Mostly acoustic and classical but I can do metal, rock and blues. I have rap, and many genres in my collection, so I did some testing. I turned the iTunes EQ OFF. In the Sony app, I set the EQ to treble boost and turned the Bass slider up to 65% approximately. The headphones are naturally bass heavy , so this leveled it out to a more neutral , slightly higher treble and overall brighter default setting. Although I will mainly be using these for the noise cancelling at my office, the music sounds incredible for the price point.

I have a home office that I am reluctant to work at due to the kids bouncing around. Putting these on allows me to focus there when I need to. Well worth the cost.

author: reg
title: Sony wins vs Bose mainly due to the available codecs
content:
This is a comparison between the QC35ii and the Sony WH1000XM3.

Comfort: Bose is ahead by a small margin

Electronics: While most prefer Sony, I prefer Bose. The extra features that Sony has are frivolous, IMHO. More important, I like the fact that I can simultaneously connect my IPad and my phone to the device. Can't do that with the Sony

Noise Cancellation: Sony is better. Surprising, but true

Sound Quality: This was the reason that made me return the losing headphones. I very much prefer the open back system that Bose uses vs the closed over the ear Sony cans (which could sometimes result in standing waves). Besides that, Sony sound is more clear and encompasses a wider range than Bose (assuming that both use the same codec). However the big, big difference is in that with Sony, I can use much better codecs (like LDAC). This, to me, makes a huge difference in sound quality. Enough for me to return the Bose and keep Sony.

author: DOC
title: Good wireless headphone with ANC
content: Just tried it on a flight. ANC works very well. The noise from environment is effectively suppressed. The adapter in the package is very useful if you try to watch a movie on the plane.  The sound quality may not be as good as the best audiophile level ones, but it is surprisingly better than I expected. My only complain is that it may not feel comfortable for someone with bigger ears like me at first. However, after wearing it for a while, seems I can get use to it. Anyway, this is an excellent wireless headphone with ANC functionality,

author: John Cruz
title: Excellent headphones!
content: It is the most advanced headphone of the year!

author: Mark Hilliard
title: Big ears comfort issues
content:
Coming from the Bose QC35 I’m spoilt for comfort, as a person with large ears and a fairly large head these simply hurt after a short period of listening for me. The foam in the pads push back a little and after only 15 minutes it causes a slight sting of pain. If wearing nearly an hour the top of the head band has a pinching feel either due to the band being too narrow or the top band foam being too stiff.

However sound and features are great, battery life second to none, and a great balance of base and adjustability makes it sound how you want. I really wanted to love these but I can only come away saying that their just fine. To reading on a couch the touch controls are too sensitive and register unattended swipes or presses. For someone with big ears (and head) these never disappear off my head and for multiple hours of use in one session these are just distracting which is unlike what noise cancelling headphones are supposed to accomplish.

author: Brad
title: No multi device connection
content:
These are great headphones other than one MAJOR annoyance. I like most things about these headphones. There is one glaring issue that has caused me to write this review. There is no TRUE multiple device connection. Sony is very deceptive on this issue in that they have a link describing how to link to multiple devices, however, what they are describing is connecting the media audio from one device and the call audio from another device.

If you want to switch media audio from one device to another, you first have to disconnect the bluetooth on the first device and then connect it to the second device. If you are using your phone and computer this becomes an issue that arises multiple times per day. If I have the headphones connected to my computer and I close it before disconnecting, the link still stays active and I have to reopen the computer to turn off the bluetooth in order to listen to audio from my phone.

As most people switch back and forth between devices multiple times a day this becomes a huge hassle and makes what should be a seamless transition a huge pain point. I thought that Sony would fix this or I would have returned the headphones. I do not believe that the have any plans to do so. If you read the many comments on this issue on Sony's own forums and their total lack of a response other than stating that they will pass this on on someone else, you will see that they have no plan to fix it.

It's sad since these could be fantastic headphones.  If you don't switch between devices, they are, but I'm not sure how many people will use them for only one device.

author: Justin Scarpello
title: Connection is not great.
content: Connection is not great.  For this much money, it should be right.

author: Xavier
title: These Headphones are superior!
content:
I love everything about this headphones, I had to give them a try.
After a few minutes of messing around with them and the settings I had to drop my beats for them! they are truly Superb!

author: Juda
title: Painful to ware
content: These are painful to ware if you have glasses.  The ear cups are too small.

author: Gon
title: Muy buenos auriculares
content: Los auriculares son muy buenos y cómodos. La cancelación activa de sonido ambiente realmente es muy útil en ambientes con mucho ruido de fondo.

author: Bpetrus
title: Great sound quality
content: Volume control could be a little bit better

author: Daniel Giambalvo (ShareScan)
title: Personally preferred the WH1000XM2s to these
content:
I had owned the second gen (WH1000XM2s) for about 6 months when the third gen (WH1000XM3s) came out.  Every review I read sung their praises, and I'm something of an audiophile so I was excited to pick them up.  However, after using them on and off for a bit, I'm returning them and for me they aren't an upgrade.

If you've read the other reviews here and elsewhere, you can get a pretty good idea of what' makes these great.  But I'm going to quickly highlight the few things I didn't like in case it's helpful:

Build - While they are indeed smaller/lighter than the 2nd gen, they feel a bit cheap/pasticy.  I think they were trying to compete with Bose and the lightness does make them more comfy (though I never found the 2nd gen uncomfortable) but they don't feel like they are a $350 headphone to me.  I also thought the 2nd gen had a bit of flare with their textured ear-cups.  The 3rd gen just blend in to the crowd and look boring.

Audio - This was one of the celebrated improvements but to me I think they sound worse.  The 2nd gen had a good amount of bass (more than I needed) but I thought it was balanced.  (I preferred the sound of the B&W PX, but found them uncomfortable to wear.)  With the 3rd gen, I feel like the bass is just too much.  Things sound muffled and the lows are significantly over-accentuated for my tastes.  As I mentioned above, I have audiophile tastes and so I'm more interested in detail, soundstage, etc.  Obviously, many folks like them based on the reviews. I could EQ the sound, and have played with that but a) then you can't use LDAC and b) I don't want to have to do that to enjoy headphones this expensive.

Controls - This is a minor point really, but the controls generally seem less responsive.  One concrete example is switching between NC, ambient, and off modes with the toggle button.  On my 2nd gen, I could quickly double-tap to get to the setting I wanted, but not with the 3rd gen.  Beyond that, changing volume, play/pause, all seem a bit laggy to me.

Beyond that, there are things that are great here.  Noise Cancelling - top notch.  Battery life - amazing.  Comfort - great.  So, I'm not saying they are bad.  But the above are enough that I think the 2nd gen are the way to go for me.

author: Jonathan Longenecker
title: Great headphones
content: Great for noise cancellation, and extremely comfortable. Good for long trips or daily use. Easy set up and USB C charging is great. Touch controls are responsive but take sometime getting used to them.

author: Ramon
title: Good wireless headphones
content: Like the way the fit around my head. Also the sound quality is awesome!

author: Jonny S
title: Super Sexy - But Outdated
content:
I would give these Sony Headphones 5 Stars if we were living in 2016. We are in 2019 and for whatever reason, they still haven't upgraded these to Bluetooth 5.0 (which is a major upgrade from Bluetooth 4). It's behind the times. Catch up Sony, or someone else will.

I give your style department 5 stars though. Super sexy model. Happy that it is USB-C (rather than cheap micro like Bose). The swiping is fun, effortless, and cool. The hand-over for ambient noise is awesome and great for conversation.

Unfortunately, I am returning these for two reasons:
-No Bluetooth 5.0 (C'mon it's 2019)
-Super Sweaty (With Bose QuietComfort my ears didn't sweat at all...Pay attention to your over-ear design)

author: Amazon Customer
title: The best pair of noise cancelling headphones as of Nov 2018
content:
Ok. Although this product is amazing, I was debating whether or not to give a lower review just based on shipping speeds. It took me 1 to 1.5 months or receive this item when I even paid for 1 day shipping. Problems with shipping aside, this pair of headphones are amazing.

Although I am not an audiophile by any means, to me, the sound quality is superb (the sound profile fits me better than the QC's) and the noise cancelling is the best I have experienced out of the competing headphones.

While the noise cancelling and sound is excellent, this headphone isn't without it's faults.  The app is absolutely horrendous, which is why I stay away from it. Although I appreciate the gesture of adding an EQ to further change the sound signature of the headphones, it is quite gimmicky and requires me to keep the app open. In addition, the ability to connect only one device at one time is very annoying. I thought it wouldn't be much of a nuisance, but after a month or two of using the headphones, I realized how much of a hindrance it is.

It is very nice that the headphones can charge using USB-C, but it is sad that it is not possible to listen to music while charging unless I am plugged in using an additional 3.5 jack cable.

All in all, however, the updates from the 2nd edition to this one, in my opinion, pushes this pair of headphones ahead of it's competitors.

author: onton
title: Good
content: Good noise cancelling and reasonable sound quality, worth the money.

author: Jairo Alberto Peña Ortiz
title: Best of the best
content: There are no other headphones that can match this noise cancelling performance. Great sound (had to set equaliser manually), very comfortable for long use and amazing battery life. I’ve got no complaints for this device and it’s one of the best things I’ve ever purchased.

author: Azadeh
title: Nice quality
content: Everything is perfect about it. Just the touch controls I did not like.

author: Sanky
title: Headband cracked within 1 week
content:
Terrible build quality. The headband cracked within 1 week of buying these.
Sony...pay attention!!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great
content: I most lay listen for podcasts and I love how easy it is to tune everything out.

author: patricia
title: Amazing!!
content: I switched my bose headphones for these and i am in love with them!! Theg r as good if not better.

author: Jpeg
title: Great noise cancelling, almost perfect but not quite, likely good enough for most people
content:
I just got these yesterday, 50% charge out of the box. I did A LOT of research and already knew the negatives on this (can't pair multi device, high latency so not good for video/audio sync for movies/games, gesture control issues in the cold).

So first off, I found the sound not that crisp and soundstage not super grand like others commented, but after using it a few hours I find the sound is clearing up and less muddy so I'm either getting used to it OR it's already breaking in (although that happens after 30+ hours usually) and you start to get used to it (if you're switching between different high fidelity headphones you're likely to hear clear differences, but if it's your main one, you get used to the sound signature).

The multi-device pairing I didn't think would be an issue for me cuz I'd mainly use it at work on my laptop however, I had it paired to my laptop last night. The laptop was in sleep mode in my bag. This morning I grabbed my phone to use the headphones and it would simply not connect. So I had to do like a reset bluetooth connection. I found that supremely annoying, because I don't see myself switching devices all that often but I figured a laptop in sleep mode would let me prioritize my phone bluetooth connection.. WRONG.

Gesture controls I like, I find it great, I haven't used this out in the cold and it's now warming up so I can't comment on how this fairs outside messing up like a lot of other users have mentioned. I did try to sort of sleep on my side and it didn't affect gesture control, but you can't sleep on your side with this because it's bulky. The cupping "hear ambient noise" works pretty well, although it does take about 2 seconds to kick in.

Noise cancelling is great. It can sometimes cut out people talking, if you have music on, it'll most likely cut it out by 95%. I'm in an office and I can barely hear my own keyboard typing (and I'm a loud typer), I took off the headphones and all of a sudden I was very aware of the ventilation of the office and I've been here for a year and never even noticed it (and I'm very sensitive to noise and details). I can't wait to use these puppers on a plane.

Very comfy, very light, I sort of feel it's a bit big on my head (I have a small head) and I'm on the smallest setting. Wearing glasses, feels superrrrrr comfy, my old Audio Technica's gave me a headache after an hour, especially with glasses. The cups don't fold the "right way" that makes sense when you want to put it down, you just have to get used to it. I think they designed it this way so the cups sit on your shoulders when they're around your neck but then it doesn't feel as straight forward to put them down on a desk. I also love the design and find it really sleek compared to others. I don't find it looks ridiculous on my head, and my head as I mentioned is small, like kid size.

The app is cool, though I didn't do much with it and likely won't personally. I did notice you can't play with EQ if you prioritize sound quality (LDAC for example VS SBC).

The quick charge (10 mins for 5 hours) and the 30 hour playback time (though I think a lot of tests said it gave them 22 hours) is super awesome. I can see this being useful in many situations, ex: you forgot to charge them before a plane ride. No problem! 10 mins for 5 hours. The case is also great because everything fits in there nicely (the USB cable, the 3.5mm audio jack, the audio L/R splitter which I haven't seen on any planes anymore because it's 2019 but maybe if you go to a super secluded area where the planes are from like 1990 they might have that. Good luck on that flight, at that point you're likely to hook your headphones up to your ipad anyway and watch a movie because if you have these headphones, you probably have a tablet, or at least a smartphone.

Sound quality for calls. I tried it on a phone call with a friend at home with the laptop running street noise in the background to simulate outdoor environments. I tried it with the 3 diff NC/Ambient settings. I didn't find much difference between the 3. I didn't sound like I was in an underwater cage, it sounded pretty clear, HOWEVER, it sounded like I was across a football as in very very quiet. So this would be shit to use IRL. I see on my phone that I can choose if my bluetooth connected XM3's use the headphones for call audio and I see a toggle. So I think technically I can set that to use the phone's mic, if I were to get a call, that would mean you'd have to take the phone out to speak to and hear the other person on your headphone so it's kind of useless. On a laptop though, Macbook anyway, you can also adjust the output and input (mic). So I had a video call yesterday and the mic was set to the laptop and I was listening in my headphones, worked great. So there is a workaround.

The high latency is noticeable on videos, definitely won't be good for gaming. But it depends how often you'll be using these for videos or how much you care or notice these things, that's on an individual basis. I think if you use the supplied wire instead of bluetooth then you'll remove this issue so let's say you're in a plane using the on-board entertainment unit, you won't have video/audio sync issues but that screen is tiny anyway, low quality, and you have no choice but to use the wire since they don't have bluetooth. So voila.

Adaptive sound control, I played with it only very little. I can't get a straight answer during my search and am waiting for Sony to answer how it works other than "sense engine" detects when you're moving. I think it is only through the app so you need to be connected to your phone for example if you're music is coming from that. I believe it works through location on your phone/app. I tested this by walking around my room without the phone in my hand, then walking around the room with my phone, and shaking my phone but not moving. It only worked when I moved around with the phone in my hand. Takes a good 20 seconds to turn on, I don't see myself using this, I would rather shut the ambient sound on/off with the physical button. The Surface headphones does this the best by having one dial for noise cancelling, I would have preferred that to just manually adjust it super easily on the fly.

Ultimately, this being "perfect" will depend on your needs. I didn't want to wait for any new headphones since CES 2019 passed and neither giant (Sony or Bose) announced any new ones. I'll see when there is a new release, if Fall 2019 or later, if I keep these or sell and upgrade.

author: Kevin R. McManus
title: Very well made Performance as promised
content:
Very well made Performance as promised.
 We been joyed it so much we bought another.

author: nickspecial
title: USB Type-C wire means faster charging!
content: Design of the headphones are amazing and are worth the price even though I bought them on sale.

author: AC Griffin
title: Not that great honestly
content:
I had researched these prior to buying on multiple sites and heard nothing but great things.
The noise cancelling is ok - there are plenty of better alternatives out there - the sound quality is absolute garbage - I played around with the settings for hours trying to get a decent sound balance - the issue being that the noise cancelling is kind of weak so you have to play the volume higher to compensate which then end up with a load of distortion even at 2 or 3 clicks below max.  Treble sounds tinny - bass is ok - not nearly as deep as other NC in ears I've used.
Overall these aren't great - they cost a lot and there are much better alternatives out there in this price range - these feel and sound like what you would expect 60-90$ in ears to sound like.

author: Hawaiifarmer
title: Noise cancelling is worse! Most flaws still exist, calls much worse. Keep your XM2s!
content:
I've had the first version, 1000X, the XM2s, and now the XM3s along with the Bose QC35 and Sennheiser PXC 550. All tests were done with the same settings, volume levels, bluetooth connections, NC settings, etc. Music was evaluated by playing the same songs on both sets of heaphones at the same time to seamlessly go from one to the other for easy comparison.

UPDATE: tried them on a plane and in a loud airport lounge and I'm taking off another star. They're being returned for a refund! Noise cancelling is obviously worse both in a plane and in terms of blocking conversation. The 3s let in an annoying fan like noise on planes that the 2s block. Riding on BART (an extremely loud commuter train) the XM3 are just bad. I had to double check that they were actually on, they let in so much more noise than the 2s. I was concerned I might just have a bad pair, so I took my XM2s into an electronics big box chain and compared the NC to the 3s on display. The ones on display were fully functional. No question, the NC on this pair of XM3s was also clearly worse than the XM2s I've owned for 6 months. It just confirmed I am correct to send back the inferior XM3s. Wait for the 4s if you want to upgrade your X or XM2s.

The 3s just aren't enough of an improvement so far to justify the purchase. On various noise cancelling tests at home (using fans, AC, fridge hum, dryer) they were different, but on some things quite a bit worse. Now that I've flown, they're definitely worse on planes and public transportation. One clear improvement is that the 3s lack the very slight hiss of the 2s, which is only noticeable if no audio is playing, and certainly can't be heard over a plane's noises. Music sounds better at high volume with less distortion than the XM2, but for the most part, the XM2s are more enjoyable to listen to.

The 2s were far better than the 1000X and XM3s on calls. The 3s are unusable for calls. In my quiet home with no background noise, call recipient immediately complained he couldn't hear me well. Put the 550s on and no problem. So Sony really failed here by creating a problem that was previously solved. The other issue is inability to connect to more than one device at a time. I have 6 devices I use regularly. The Senns and Bose are much older models and they can both connect to 2 devices at once and actually function properly.

Even the 1000X were far better at noise cancelling in every test I did vs. the Bose and so are the 3s. Not even close. But the clearly worse system in the 3s is mind boggling. Did no one at Sony actually ever test these?

Out of the box they sounded awful vs. all the others, but after a week of use, they're nearly as good as the 2s, just different. Definitely improved at highest volume, where the 2s have much more distortion.

They're lighter, but feel cheaper, and are slightly more comfortable but still way too hot. I thought the 2s were already very comfortable, just too heavy. If you live in warm weather you're ears will sweat quickly. The much faster charging is great. The ridiculously short charging cable works at least. The annoying, always on, blinking lights are gone fortunately. The power light still blinks, but less than before. The light for NC is gone. No lights would be best. So you get slightly more comfortable (actually a tie for me), slight less weight traded for a very cheap feel.

If sound quality is your main concern, get the 550s. If noise cancelling is, then get the 2s. Can't see any reason to buy the Bose or the XM3. Bose sound the worst of the 5 models I've owned, though they are comfortable. The noise cancelling on the Bose are no longer very impressive, and not much better than the 550s overall and actually let more annoying sound through on a plane.

I bought the alleged "silver" model. Hideous! If you have a 84-97 era Mac I guess you'll be happy that you have matching beige headphones. Was hoping they'd be like the silver Bose. They are more beige than in any of the official pics. One of the official pics I've seen is obivous fraud. As for the case, it's fine but BIGGER, wtf?

I'm hoping they blow me away on a plane and train. I've read they cancel voices better so I hope that's the case. UPDATE: NOPE! worse in all regards.

The 2s, which can be found for $200 now are a much better deal than these for $350. When the difference gets down to $50, go for the 3s.

If the 2s had never existed, the XM3 would seem like a great heaphone overall, and it still is. I can't see why anyone would buy these over the 2s now. They also make the Sennheisers the clear winner.

author: Ylo
title: Great Nosie Cancellation & Battery Life
content: The Sony WH1000XM3 does not disappoint.  I have made several trips from Boston to S.E. Asia with these over the past two months using them for watching in-flight movies, and the cancellation and battery life have amazed me.  Keep in mind that I'm not using the Bluetooth, but I have had above 85 percent of battery remaining after more than roughly 10 hours of use.

author: Jeff Darcy
title: Truly next-gen noise cancellation
content:
I had two experiences very soon after I got these that convinced me they're something special. The first one was after I'd been wearing them for a few minutes, then took them off to go from my office to another room in the house. I realized that my neighbor had started mowing his lawn while they were on and *I hadn't even noticed*. Absolute silence. The second experience was about half an hour later, when I felt a tap on my shoulder. It was my wife, having failed to get my attention verbally through several attempts. Again, hadn't even noticed. I was playing music by that point, but pretty quietly. My Bose and Plantronics headphones were never *that* effective.

This is similar to the experience I had when I first tried Bose QuietComfort headphones, and they blocked out noise I hadn't even known I was hearing, except that these are as far beyond the Bose as those had been beyond earlier ANC tech. They're *addictively* good. I can't address durability yet (nobody can), but everything else has been good - pairing, battery life and recharge time, comfort, sound quality, etc. The swipe-based controls are responsive and easy to get used to. Quick attention mode is a very nice touch (pun intended) though it's a bit counter-intuitive to cover your ear when you want to hear someone.

These ain't cheap, but if you want the best there's no question these have leapt to the top of the heap.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Worth the $$$
content: Great headphones that are comfortable to wear for an extended period of time.  The noise cancellation works great including the adaptive sound control. The sound quality is great as well.  A little pricy but I enjoy these more than I enjoy Beats Studio 3's.

author: Cami Libby
title: Love these headphones!
content: Superior sound quality. Super simple to set up and super nice looking

author: Noah
title: Best headphones on the market
content: Best headphones I've ever bought

author: Jose Orozco Flores
title: Great product, excellent quality
content: Great product, fully recommended

author: Jszapp
title: Worth the money!
content: I got these for my husband for Christmas! He does a lot of travel on airplanes and he has done nothing but thank me for them. He says it’s so quiet he can fall asleep easy but playing is music and movies is clear! Worth the money!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Pretty much perfect!
content:
These headphones are absolutely amazing.

I use them daily at the office. If I run low on battery... I plug them in for 5-10 minutes while making coffee or grabbing a smoke break and they are back to 80% or more.

Noise cancellation is great. Added bonus is that people are now forced to do ridiculous dances and hand-waving if they want my attention.

I used the phone app to activate some of the added base functionality for certain types of music... and my... it is lovely.

Only drawback I've found is that in a hot room the headphones can get a bit uncomfortable due to heat being retained inside the ear cushions.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Missing part of great listen to Audiobook.
content: I use the headphone to listen to audiobooks when I workout - mostly running in the nature. I have been listening to audiobooks almost everyday since mid 2017. But when I used this product, instantly said MISSING ELEMENT OF A GREAT LISTEN . I am waiting for the next generation of this phenomenal product to enhance my listening experience. Note: since mid 2017 I have listened to 210 audiobooks - some of the books. 2 or 3 times.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Only one bad thing
content: Wish I could change settings in my PC just like with the headphones app on my phone.

author: Jayvardan Naidu
title: Good quality
content: Have also had the Bose qc 35’s and this is higher quality

author: disappointed sony fan
title: half dead in winter
content: I live in Illinois and it just hit 0 degree today. This headphone just kept having glitches every 15 mins in cold weather. The touch panel proves more of an unreliable frustration than an upgrade. Now I regret didn't go for the "dumber" Bose qc35.. FIX THIS ISSUE SONY DONT LET ME DOWN!

author: Jack silk
title: Sound is so crisp
content: Do your ears a favor and buy these headphones! I own Beats, Bose and Sennheisers, and these crush them all. Sound is so crisp. Definitely must use the app to maximize their output. They are amazing, period.

author: Michael Genao
title: Hawt
content: These are great. Looks hot.

author: Ethan
title: First time buyer of higher end headphones.
content:
So I bought these headphones because I wanted to experience what listening to music on higher quality headset was like.
I live in a full household with lots of background noise and wanted something to block that out. I game with them on. Microphone isn’t supported with gaming systems FYI. Not a big deal.
The audio quality is balanced and very clean.
The app for these headphones has some fun features but generally useless in my opinion.
As I used them I found myself using them for more and more things. I found that I can broadcast to my tv using my iPhone but funnel all my audio through the headset so I can watch tv without disturbing anyone.
I added Dolby Atmos to my game systems and my phone to enhance the audio output and it gives great immersion during gaming sessions.
The headband and ear cups are ultra soft. They form a great seal around my ears but still manage to breathe enough that I don’t sweat.
Battery life is as advertised. Long lasting and easy to recharge. Usb C is a great choice when trying to plug in in the dark.
I had not budgeted for these when I bought them but amazon had a pay as you go option at check out which was very helpful.
Overall I am very happy with my purchase and I will keep using them until they fall apart.

author: Yuchen Lin
title: Missing parts and too-low volume
content: Volume is too low and there is no 3.5 mm cable

author: Just Me
title: Sony headset
content: Noise cancellation

author: Daniel
title: Battery never ends. Perfect for frequent flyers.
content: Use to listen music at Max volume and still could hear a lot of noise. Now I use it at 1/3 of the volume. It's great. And the battery last forever.

author: Qui Mai
title: Bluetooth Connection
content: It can be a hassle with switching from different devices when it comes to bluetooth connection. It requires you to disconnect the device first for you to connect to the 2nd device. For example, you're connected to your phone, but then would like to connect to your laptop. You would have to go into settings to disconnect the bluetooth from your phone first then youre able to connect to your second device. This can be a hassle but that's probably the only issue I have with this headphones.

author: Ed Z
title: Very effective noise cancellation
content: Did a lot research and I believe these are the  best wireless noise cancelling headphones. Batter life is off the charts. The touch control for volume and track takes some getting use to, but works quite well. There is the unintentional hand movement that can change tracks without you realizing it.

author: LREdwards
title: Comfortable and Excellent Sound Quality
content: I purchased these headphones for a recent international trip to wear on the airplane.  I have used noise cancelling earbuds in the past but found they didn't cut the engine roar in the cabin very well and they were uncomfortable in my ears for long periods of time.  I decided to try these headphones after reading the numerous highly complimentary reviews.  I found them to exceed my expectations for airplane noise cancellation and they were very comfortable to wear for the entire length of the long international flights,  The sound quality for listening to music was excellent but they were even comfortable with no music playing when sleeping with only the noise cancellation function operating.  I also used them connected by the USB cable for watching movies, again with fine results.  I especially liked the ease of increasing/decreasing volume and stopping the noise cancellation by either just holding my hand on the right earphone, or by sweeping up or down for volume.  They are very user friendly, comfortable, with long lasting battery, and excellent sound. I am very pleased with my purchase and highly recommend these earphones!

author: Josh Peterson
title: Spend the extra dollar for these. Worth it.
content: Best headphones ever. Easy as that. Sound is perfect, especially with the app to customize to how I like my music. Only dislike is that surface of the headphones can look oily very easily. Absolutely no regrets with this purchase.

author: Paul Hildebrand
title: Great product
content: Best headphones I have ever had!

author: Gerald
title: It just works!
content:
Got these in time for travel to NYC from LA. Noise cancelling (NC) kept me in my world of music from liftoff to touchdown with 20 hours of power to spare in each direction. I assume there would have been more power left over if only Ambient Sound (AS) was used, but NC is the only way to go to stay in a cocoon of music. Noticed, however, that one person's medium-pitched voice avoided NC every now and then. Not a problem when there's a cacophony of voices being filtered out. Also, NC dropped to AS a few times. Don't know if it was caused by spurious radio signals during take-off/landing or atmospherics in flight, but again, not a problem. Two clicks of a button and NC was back in control.

In flight and at home, these Sonys allows me to crank it up without bothering anyone and not being bothered with noises that abound. And that volume control? Perfect! No fumbling for buttons. Just a swipe and the volume is where I want it, as well as the playlist tracks.

I dinged one star on sound quality only because I know how Bose sounds. Sony come close enough. Its NC makes it worth the trade-off!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Awesome headphones!
content: Nagging wife deterrent!  Kidding.  The headphones sync up easily and soundcquality is amazing and they feel comfortable, like sone reviewer's mentioned you can sleep wearing them.  Holds charge for days, I've had it for 3 months no charging and no issues yet.  Of course not a daily user.

author: Katherine Pfaff Galvez
title: It’s so comfortable! And it actually helps when you’re in the plane!! Works better than earplugs 😂
content: Love it

author: T.S.
title: Great Headset for listenting to Music from one source
content:
I love the sound quality of the SONY WH1000MX3, and that  you can set the Equalizer to either a pre-set or custom setting through their mobile app!

The design is awesome, and the wearing comfort is exceptional -- these headsets are awesome for wearing them over a long period of time -- the cushions go nicely around the earlobes, and do not touch/squeeze them.

The 30 hour battery is amazing!

At max volume the ound is a little bit louder compared with it's competitors, and I rate that as a definite plus.

So why only 3 stars?

Compared to it's competition, the SONY headset does not support Bluetooth multi-point connections (DUAL A2DP).
This means that you CAN NOT connect your phone and a computer at the same time, and it will NOT switch the audio seamlessly between audio-sources.

So if you want to be connected to two devices, this might not be a good choice for you

Another problem is that when you have audio playing on the device (e.g. phone), and then switch on the SONY headset, the audio does not automatically get switched to the headset after it bluetooth connects :(
With other brands this is not an issue

author: J. Dioguardi
title: JD TRAVEL HEADPHONES
content: They work GREAT !!!!!!

author: Brian Treusdell
title: Many pros...one big con!
content:
Just the facts...
Pro: Great sound quality, different modes of sound blocking, quality construction, long battery life.
Con: Tight fit, warm (would be uncomfortable to wear for 2 or more hours), the killer for me was this...their sound blocking ability is directly proportional to the volume, the higher the volume the more sound blocking! I wanted max sound blocking while playing jazz at low volume. This isn’t possible, so I returned them.

author: richdark974
title: Woaw
content: Just exellent

author: AmazonCustomer
title: Amazing
content: Amazing.  Made the switch from Bose

author: MANSOUR
title: V v nice
content: V nice

author: Matthew DeMorat
title: Quality
content: Would recommend

author: Alice
title: good
content: good

author: Brian Donahue
title: oh dang
content:
My previous noise cancelling headphones were the Cowin E7 which I thought worked pretty well at reducing noise. These were an impulse buy that I regretted immediately, assuming the difference would be pretty small. Then I put these things on and holy forking shirtballs, the silence was shocking. Yup, these are worth 300 bucks more than the cheaper ones. I say $70 for the Cowin headphones and $300 or $350 for the Sony ones are what they are really worth, both fair prices.

Edit: The padding design is weird, it dips down in the center so only a small area makes contact with the top of the head and it causes a dull ache. I fixed this with the super weird knitted headphone cozy in the picture, bought here on Amazon. Now I am comfortable and stylish.

author: Kevin
title: Way better then bose...
content:
As a owner of the qc 35 ii's i was unsure if i really needed a new pair. I was already happy with my previous pair, and was not a huge fan of the mx2's. But every professional review of the mark 3s was close to perfect so i decided to buy a pair.

Things i noticed right away is how much more comfortable they were than the xm2's. The design has improved a lot and they look less awkward due to the closer (?) Fit to the head. I wore them for 4 hours straight earlier and they never bothered me, they seem to be much lighter this time around.

The noise cancellation also blows bose out of the water. It is honestly amaIng how much sound these cancel out, felt like i was alone when surrounded by a ton of people at my campus today. These have the best noise cancelling feature i have ever used on a pair of headphones for sure. Also, it has a 30 hour battery life while using the ANC feature which is awesome. But with the added usb-c charging you dont even need to worry about that because just 10 mins of charging gives you 5 hoursmin of battery!

I dont know much about sound and what makes it good, but i prefer the sound of these compared to bose, it feels more full and lively.

Lastly, the touch controls are honestly great and really easy to use. Dont need to pull ouy my phone to change basic settings which is pretty convinient.

So if you are looking for headphones that have great noise cancelling, high comfort, and a good sound. I would recommend the Sony 1000xm3 over the Bose qc35ii

author: Trevor Esnouf
title: Stunning! And brilliant service from Amazon.
content: I ordered these on Friday and they were here in Cape Town South Africa on Tuesday. Excellent service from Amazon. Headphones are way better than I expected. Stunning detail and seperation. I own the rubbish Bose qc35 and these blow them out the water in almost every department. The sound in way better, the noise cancellation is way better too. They are super comfortable too. If you are in the market for the best in the business these are them. Tried the B and W PX and they are not even near the same league as the Sonys.

author: Jin-Hwan Doh
title: First time to buy noise cancellation headphone
content: This is my first time to buy noise cancellation headphone. Working well when I'm in airplane and especially in noisy places like ice rink where I'm waiting for my daughter playing ice hockey. But little bit worry about durability so that I bought protection plan together. I hope I never use protection plan in the future.

author: Russell Daugherty
title: I love the sound quality and noise cancelling.
content: Pros, long battery life, good quality build, excellent noise cancelling. I upgraded firmware through app on phone and was hoping to be able to sync with more than 1 device at a time. NO Go. Sync with only 1 device. It usually works fine, a couple times I had to manually disconnect from phone to listen on ipad. if firmware gets upgraded to multi-device sync would be 5 rating.

author: Michael
title: Honest Review from an ANC-Loving Misophoniac
content: ANC is bonkers. I had the old Plantronics Backbeat Pro 1 and after 3.5 years I decided to upgrade myself with the prime day price and am pleasantly surprised. I wish the headphone functionality was a little more intuitive, I wish they could connect to two Bluetooth devices at once and I wish the battery lasted longer with ANC on, the Plantronics seemed to last for days, but the audio quality and ANC make up for those deficiencies. I recommend at the $300 mark but I'd probably be a little disappointed if I paid more than that. Overall a solid value if you take solace in the silence. If you're someone who "wants solid headphones and some noise cancellation would be cool" get something like a cheaper Plantronics or Senheiser and save your money

author: DawgShipment
title: Excellent Headphones
content: Great sound quality and a really helpful app for customization. Sound cancellation is the best I've (not) heard in a pair of headphones. Would definitely buy again.

author: L N
title: SOUND FK FAILED AFTER 1 MONTH.
content: I was good for about one month. Last few days, the SOUND WENT BAD, REALLY BAD. sound like the hurricane in my ears, so HURT. And I can't return it now because the the return window closed after one month. and I am one day late . this is HORRIBLE

author: MAESVI
title: Excelente - Excellent
content:
Excelente calidad. La cancelación de ruido es espectacular! Lo use en un vuelo de Costa Rica a Los Ángeles y Los Ángeles a Shanghai. En realidad aisla el ruido externo de forma espectacular. Es espectacular. El rendimiento de la batería muy bien. No estoy seguro si dura las 30 horas que promete, pero pude hacer el vuelo de ida sin necesidad de cargar la batería. El único PERO que tengo es el control de volumen. Al ser táctil, es muy fácil que un roce cambie el volumen.
