author: Lauren Muneoka (NEW)
title: Sony WH10000xM3 beats Bose QC 35 II hands down!
content:
This review will be most helpful for those who are comparing the Bose Quietcomfort 35 II's with the Sony WH1000XM3's.

I ordered the Bose QC 35 II's as an early Christmas gift to myself (December 2018). I've owned and loved my Bose QC 20 noise cancelling earbuds and was expecting nothing less from the more expensive flagship model. In deciding between the Sony's and the Bose, it helped that Bose dropped their price to $299 for the holidays.

The Bose QC's were extremely disappointing right out of the box. I followed all of the directions to the letter and downloaded the app. The noise cancellation was sub-par at best but I was dreading a lengthy return and stuck with them for another couple of days. The active noise cancellation never improved. I could hear an entire conversation happening next to me even with noise cancellation on at it's highest setting and music playing. These weren't even as good as my old Bose QC earbuds!!

Before returning them, I did some research and discovered that many, many, people were having issues with the QC 35 II's newest firmware update. Just Google it, the info is readily available. The most common complaint was degraded noise cancellation after upgrading the firmware. It was reported that there were no patches and no relief even if you installed an earlier firmware to your headphones.  That was the last straw and I decided I had to go with the Sony's even if they were a little more expensive.

Amazon gets major points for making the return process unbelievably easy and quick. (They processed the refund for Amazon credit before they even received the headphones back.)

------------
These headphones are an absolute dream. The active noise cancellation destroy the Bose by a healthy margin. They are both comfortable and light and the sound quality (to my ears) is also superior to the Bose. If you are looking for an experience that makes the world around you "drop away" then this is the pair for you. Battery life is excellent and being able to fast charge with USB-C aka your laptop charger is a game changer.

I was worried about call quality and the fact that you can't hook up two devices at once. I can report that the call quality is just average but wasn't a major deal breaker for me. The device switching issue is a flaw that I hope they will address in subsequent models. The reality is that it takes about 1 minute extra to switch between your laptop and phone. It's annoying but mainly a first world problem.

And no, the model I received doesn't feel like the band is going to crack.  I would pay the $11 to get insurance, though, just in case.

author: Edward A. Gelb
title: Comfortable even with glasses and sound terrific
content: I like the looks of the headphones, the very good sound they produce, the option to use them wired or wireless, and the feature that allows me to hold my hand over the right ear cup to mute the sound and allow me to hear voices around me.  I wear glasses, and at first the headphones were not as comfortable as I had hoped, but after a week or two of using them, they are very comfortable and I can wear them for hours without adjusting the fit. The  headphones have two of the most important features for me: comfortable to wear with glasses and sound terrific.

author: Amazon Customer
title: best muffs around
content: work great, no negatives, not sure why price isn't dropping with time

author: Patrick
title: Noise Cancelling is amazing!
content: I purchased one of these for my son in graduate school.  He was very happy with the noise cancelling and sound quality.  His love for the headphones convinced me to buy two more for my other children that are in college.  It has been two months and all three of them use the headphones daily.  Such a great gift for a student!

author: Anthony
title: NOISE CANCELING
content: This set of headphones are more then I ever expected. I was amazed at the quality of craftsmanship in design. They fit perfectly to my ears and head. Till I turned them on, I was already pleased with my purchase. Then with them on my head I turned them on. I was sitting ten feet to my tv and another five to the window A/C. Initially I thought the power went off in the house because it became very quite. Everything was still on though. The noise canceling feature just surprised me beyond reason. Blown away! Then when I got on my lawnmower to mow the grass again I was overwhelmed at the ability to hear music then the mower cutting grass. Thank you Sony you have made me a extremely happy customer!

content: Used this for flying and working in an office. NC is great to a certain point, high pitched sounds come thru. Sound quality is good for a wireless headphone, and range is pretty good. The side panel for controls are marginal, and more work needs to be done here.

author: Mark Beech
title: As good as they say
content: The functionality from the touch pad on the outside of the ear takes a little getting used to but is great when you do. To be honest I take them off if i'm ordering a drink on a plane but the mute through the touch pad is very useful in other situations. Overall the noise cancelling is very good, the button that tunes the noise cancelling to the surroundings improved it noticeably. Sound quality is very good, I back to back compared them to a pair of equivalent Bose and the sound with these is just nicer and more rich.

author: Damian
title: Works as advertised, but...
content:
The headphones are perfect for what they were designed to do... which is to wear them while commuting through the city, air travel, and office use. Quality is great for those situations.

However, these do not have the power that some cable/battery headphones have. I you want lots of bass and "loudness" these are not for you. And honestly no bluetooth headphones will have enough juice to produce incredible power. Might have to wait a couple more years for that tech to catch up.

Also, WILL NOT work for the gym if you do cardio and higher intensity workouts - they produce lots of sweat and get really wet really fast. If you just go to the gym and throw some weights around without breaking a sweat then sure.

very nice sounding headphones.
They are lacking a little in the mid range

author: J. Price
title: Loving these Headphones - round 2
content:
I purchased these headphones to replace my Bose Quiet Comfort 15s. I still have them. They still work but they are corded and I have been looking for a corded replacement when I caught these on PRIME Days sale.
What I like: the sound quality is awesome.  There is a button that allows you to toggle back and forth between ambient sound or noise cancelling.  When I listen to rock, the base and treble all come through clear and clean. I like the sound and noise cancelling more than my Bose Quiet Comfort 15s that I have had for years. I may have to put those in the drawer.
What I don't like: the app you need to load to use this headphone set is nothing special. I have also not figured out how to save my equalization settings so they stay (maybe user error).  There is another recommended app that is Sony approved that I have not used yet. I am out of space on my phone so stuck with this app.
Lastly, I gave it 4 stars because this is my second set. The first one did not hold a charge and I had to send it back. That is a big negative in my book.
Overall, like the choice and seems to be, to my ignorant ears, all that has been advertised.  Good job Sony because your Vaio is trash.

author: Dexter Legaspi
title: Sounds Great but Uncomfortable
content:
I wanted to like this, but the comfort level is just not there which is very important for me; Bose QC line is better by a long shot. The problem is that it’s heavier but the issue--I believe--is that it’s not evenly distributed which causes pain on my temple even for a short time.

It's a hame, because the sound is better than Bose (not by much IMO) and it's USB-C!  in the end, though, if it’s not comfortable then it's a deal-breaker for me.

author: ILikeMovies
title: Switching between devices is a complete pain
content:
Bluetooth has it's perks but I hate trying to switch devices. These headphone have an iphone app that makes connecting to the phone very easy but I use these headphones at work. I want to control my music from my computer. I have to go into my phone settings and turn off bluetooth there and then go into my computer settings and repair the headphones by turning off the headphones and then turning them back on with a long press. Then when I leave work I have to go back into my phone settings and turn bluetooth back on and turn my headphones off and then turn them back on with a long press of the power button.

Know what I did before? I plugged in the headphone jack.

Sony's help articles aren't clear and trying to reach out to customer service is difficult because they keep redirecting to community and help articles. Paying $300+ for headphones should allow me to reach a customer service agent with out this much trouble. If they don't want to help resolve this issue then I'm giving them a 1 out of 5 for the inconvenience.

content: Once you get it hooked to music or an app or game and HAVE sound(doing that is the tough part) you will like the quality. There are a lot of problems that need to be addressed though. Pairing went okay, but if you have two device(I have an iPad and iPhone) to switch between them you have to turn the blue tooth off on the device you don't want sound. Bose connection to two device is simple and you don't have to turn off blue tooth... just turn off the screen. The Google assistant app messes things up a bit too as it adds another bluetooth device. I got it going but then I wanted to watch football on the iPad so switched off bluetooth and things were messed up when I tried to use a second time. Decided the assistant was not worth the hassle until Sony catches up with Bose with such things. I'm still deciding whether to return the headphones or not. I do like the sound!!! It's better than Bose. Perhaps a firmware adjustment from Sony will help. The app is "meh" Maybe I should wait for a WH-1500M4 or something ;)

author: JSG
title: Does not work in cold weather
content:
In normal room temperature conditions, this is a good pair of headphones.

Pros:
+Great sound quality for a bluetooth headphone
+Great sound isolation that's superior to the QC35II (I own both pairs and have tested them side by side)
+Hand over ear cup gesture actually amplifies the outside environment when you need to hear what's going on

Cons:
-Headphone can only sync to one device. So if you are currently using your phone, you have to disconnect from your phone, then connect to the laptop or vice versa for audio output.
-Phone calls are of poor quality, with the person on the other end having difficulty hearing unless you're in an absolutely quiet environment.
-Touch controls does not offer tactile feedback like buttons, so you can never be sure if the headphone didn't register your command, or if something is wrong with the headphone, or if you didn't swipe the correct way.
-Touch controls does not work in the cold. Worse yet, it starts to register phantom swipes when temperatures approach freezing such as pausing the audio, skipping several tracks forward or backward, or turning the volume all the way down or up (ear shattering and very jarring).

The dealbreaker lies in the touch control, as I live in the Northern US and use this on my daily public transportation commute. Since there's no alternative forms of control, you have no option but to turn off the headphones and turn them back on to reset. Even then, it does not solve the issue 100% of the time. I returned them for another pair, and has the exact same issue occur. Friends who purchased this headphone also have the same complaint as well.

Do note that the temperature issue is not a manufacture defect affecting a small percentage of headphones. This is something that's rooted in the touch control interface, and affects all 1000XM3 headphones.

If you can live with the cons, then this is a great pair or headphones. For me, all the negatives are absolutely deal breakers. I had to switch back to using the QC35II.

author: G1N4M4R13
title: Great for Air travel.
content: I travel often for work by plane.  I had debated for the last year on getting NC headphones. I finally caved, and now I am wondering why I hadn't sooner.  My last flight, I was seated next to two different families.  I barely heard them on the 3 hr flight while my travel companion couldn't wait to get off the plane as there was so much commotion thoughout the flight.

author: Luis

They are very comfortable, and with long battery life you’ll want to wear them all the time.  The sound is clear and crisp.  The only thing I don’t like is that if you connect to multiple devices, there is no easy switching, you have to disconnect from one and then connect to the other to get the sound.  And for some reason ambient noise is present when making phone calls, which is disappointing.  Other than that I’m extremely happy with them!!

author: Indraneel Phadke
title: FANTASTIC noise cancellation and sound quality but BAD call quality
content:
I've been looking to get a noise-canceling headphone for a while. I had been eyeing the 1000XM2 for a while but had observed several challenges such as weight, ear pad comfort, etc. I was still about to pull the trigger when I read somewhere that the 1000XM3 was imminent, and held off.

After the big reveal, I ordered then here the day they were available for pre-order, and received them last week! So far the headphones have performed BEYOND my expectations. Except for one tiny little thing, which nevertheless turned out to be a major problem.

LIKE:
Phenomenal noise cancellation. I travel a lot and between time in cabs, at the airport and in flights accounts for 8-12 hours per week. Having these headphones have made those hours infinitely more bearable and am convinced that in the long run my hearing and ears will thank me! The engine roar is completely suppressed. Conversations are largely muffled. Close announcements are still clear but muffled. Crowd noise is completely suppressed.

Fantastic sound quality: Decent base, good amount of EQ. Not yet played a whole lot with the DAC. I will compare the DAC in the headphone wth the one in my V30 which I LOVE!

Ergonomics: Absolutely NO fatigue from wearing it for 4-5 hours at a stretch. No hot, red and sweaty ears, no hurting head due to too much clamping pressure. Just perfect.

HATE:
Sony engineers claimed that they dramatically improved the sound quality of calls. Well, not. They may have actually introduced a bug. Here's what I mean, and I really hope this is just a firmware bug and not a design defect. Whenever I am at the airport or cab, chances are, I will be in at least 3-4 phone calls.

On the 1000XM3, every time I receive a call over Bluetooth, the ambient mics inexplicably kick in. The caller can hear everything around my vicinity very clearly but can barely hear me. This becomes a HUGE deal since I am forced to keep my wired headset in a pocket and scramble around for it every time I'm wearing the XM3 and receive a phone call. Simply unacceptable. If there's no resolution found quickly, I'm afraid these have to go back. Will post an update here.

author: gilbert
title: Tinkering required
content:
Like for many others, my decision was between these and the Bose QC35 ii. I purchased both and entered the comparison with a slight bias in favor of the Bose, due to user reviews. I used both headphones for approximately 20 hours each, in varying environments and situations. Both are absolutely amazing headphones and to be perfectly honest, but in the end the Bose went back and the Sony's stayed. I tried the Bose first and the Sony's second. In the first 15 to 20 seconds, I had a shocked reaction and almost wanted to claw the WH1000XM3 off my head in disgust. The default sound profile was simply atrocious by comparison to the sound the QC35 ii produced. The difference was so stark that I almost sent the WH1000XM3 back on the spot, HOWEVER, I'm extremely glad that I did not do so. After playing with the equalizer and adjusting the profile, I was able to fine tune these babies to sound absolutely stellar. Bose sounded great out of the box but entirely lack an equalizer feature. The same thing can be said for various other features that have to first be enabled via the app. If you expect everything to be amazing out of the box and have an aversion to tinkering, the QC35 ii may be your better option. I for one am supremely satisfied with the WH1000XM3.

Pros:
- Equalizer and customizability
- Controls feel intuitive and are easy to get used to
- Covering the right cup with your palm temporarily negates noise canceling, if someone is trying to get your attention without forcing you to remove the headphones to engage in brief exchanges.

Cons:
- The Bose are ever so slightly more comfortable, not that these are "uncomfortable" they just lose out in the comparison.
- Bose has angled drivers, since I'll be replacing the pads on these for added comfort, both short comings can be negated with one cheap accessory purchase.

On the topic of noise cancellation:
I found that in certain environments the Bose noise cancelling performed better and in other environments the Sonys won. Bose seemed to deal better with monotone background noise, like fans, car sounds and wind. WH1000XM3 did better with voices and music as well as keyboard clicks for some unexplainable reason.

Hope this helps.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Does it what says. Lacks multi-point connection like the Bose Qc-35s. Cancelling is on point
content:
The phone connects easilly. Sound is superb and very comfortable for studying/office buuuut and this is a big issue.

Unlike the Bose, The XM3 won’t allow you to connect to two devices simultaneously.

I have calls sometimes on my phone and sometimes through Skype on the laptop. With the Bose I don’t have two do anything other than mute any audio from the other device and it just works.

Very unfortunate exclusion of a feature that should be available and is available on other sony headphones. Would have been a good 9.5 for the price and quality

author: Mexican Pancho
title: Amazing :0
content: Best headphones I’ve ever had. Beats are crap.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great performance but not friendly for using.
content: This is a good noise canceling headphones. It has great songs quality and noise canceling performance. However, it run warm when it work, which makes me sweating. Also, the material is easy to dirty, so if you like this headphone, choose the black one.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Better than my Bose
content: So much better compared to my bose... especially on the sound department... worth every penny

author: Chi-Heng W.
title: Silent tech is awesome, and sound quality is the best.
content: My second Bluetooth headphone set. My ears can not bear those which insert into your ears; hence, I purchased this type of headphone. The top part of the headphone softly touches my head, and supports the whole unit without hurting my head after several hours usage. The quiet tech is really helpful because I could not hear my wife yelling at me! The quality of sound is definitely the best. The only down side is that the heat will be accumulating between the set and my ears.

author: Emanuel Ax
title: Great sound and noise reduction- also very comfortable
content: Best I have owned-

author: Sandip
title: One of the better noise cancelling headphones
content: It takes down most of the noise if you play something while wearing it, battery life is excellent, although ears heat up a bit at the beginning but I got used to it. I am not an sound engineer but the sound is very good.

author: Josie
title: Amazing!
content: My fiancé read a zillion reviews and did his homework before deciding on these. They are absolutely the best headphones I’ve ever used. Super convenient touch controls, beautiful and easy-to-store carrying case, and sound quality is outstanding. Highly recommend!

author: jesus
title: The Best there Is
content: I was a bit skeptical about buying a 300 dollar pair of headphones without trying them on. After I tried them I am confident these are the best headphones I have ever owned. The bass is really good as well as the noise cancellation. What I like the most is you can really tune them the way you want in the app. These headphones have really made me change my mind about the headphone jack. Full Wireless from now on!

author: Aerodynas
title: Sony, You Have Outdone Yourself
content: After testing many different over-ear headphones, mainly focused on sound quality, Sony really bought my attention with this particular set. Of course the noise cancellation is top notch but the vivid, dynamic audio experience was the cream of the crop. For as long as I've been obsessed with music and sound design, I've always favored Sennheiser. Never would I have even considered Sony after some unimpressive development in the past. All it took was trying them out at my local Best Buy, and I was hooked. Well done Sony.

author: Damon
title: Absolutely worth the money
content: These are the best all around noise-cancelling headphones I have ever experienced.  I didn't think anyone would beat Bose, but Sony did. My only minor quibble is that the headband has a tendency to slide back on my head.  (Of course, that may just be my head; YMMV.) The sound quality is excellent, the noise-cancellation superb, and the bluetooth connectivity simple and strong.  Battery life is great too.  And they come in a strong fitted case with the connectivity accessories you'll need.  Worth every penny.  Stop looking around and just buy them.  You'll be glad you did.

author: Yang
title: Great overall, I just received a defective one.
content: The Sony xm3 is my first noise-canceling headphone ever. To keep it short and straight to the point, they look, feel, and sound amazing as you can see in the video that I provided, but the issue I was having is that it keeps pausing my music from time to time (you can also see that issue occurring in the video). Additionally, this next part is my fault because I should've read everyone's review first, but the headphone cannot connect to 2 devices at once. I know this might not be a big issue for some people, but it is for me because I work from my laptop and also pick up calls frequently, so it does get really annoying when I have to slide off the headphone back and forth just to talk. Also, the mic sounded muffled, so that's a big no-no for me when I'm picking up the calls for work. However, those are the problems for me and would probably have to return it and go with the Bose for my needs instead since I heard you can connect it to 2 devices, but still, I would highly recommend this headphone to others anyway because it sounds AMAZING! Not to mention, you can adjust the sounds to your likeness with the Sony Connect app as well!

author: EarlTheGray
title: Best n the market as of 02/2019.
content:
Have tried many over the ear cups for home entertainment. Senhauser takes a back seat to this headset.
Crisp and clear bluetooth communication.
Effortless setup.
Battery life is out standing.
The device is not cheap but well worth it.

author: Javier Zavaleta
title: As good as promised in the reviews, BUT!
content:
I purchased these headphones after seeing a lot of reviews online and because it was on sale. I couldn't help it. I've tested them for a couple of weeks now, and I think I can give a good review by now.

They replaced my Bose QC25 headphones that I loved but that I wished to be wireless from time to time. Since I've used those headphones for years, my review is comparison between the two brands and is probably going to be helpful for people that are deciding between these and the Bose QC35 II (please note that every other headphone in this price range is just pale compared to these). Also, I don't know much about Bose 700 since I haven't tested them extensively, but most of the things that apply for their older version is probably true for these as well.

The Negatives:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

- Not as comfortable. They are very comfortable, but not as much as Bose. After a while I can feel them in the top of my head and I do feel the headphones in my ears. Bose are almost perfect here; I can use them for hours and hours and only get hot in the ears if the day is really warm.
- A little loose. The clamping force is a little lacking. When looking down or headbanging you can feel them move around and even fall. I didn't have this issue with Bose.
- Earpiece cushions harder to replace than Bose. After over a year of use my Bose cushions started wearing down until they finally broke. After a $12 dollar replacement purchase, I easily replaced them and they were as good as new. I don't know how much it'll take for these cushions to wear down, but when they do, it's going to be much harder AND expensive to replace (I've found the replacement cushions at $50 and I've been told they are not as good affecting the noise cancelling quality).
- Single button to turn on, off and get into pairing mode. It's not a major issue, but having to press for two seconds to turn on/off and seven to get into pairing mode is not great. With Bose after a while you automate the motion of removing and turning of the headphones in one move. I've forgotten to turn these off more often than not because of that which of course impacts battery usage since they are on while they are still connected to a device. You basically waste hours of battery because of this. Pressing for two seconds might not sound awful, but it's that compared to a switch interaction of instant results.
- Bluetooth management!!!! This is were this headphones are really poor compared to Bose. They cannot connect to several devices at once, and to switch you must somehow cut the connection with the other device. So, to connect to a device you had already connected to, you need to manage at least 2 devices but most often that not 3. You need to cut the connection from the headphones to the previous device (either turn off the device's Bluetooth or press the On/Off button for 7 seconds to enter pairing mode) and then grab the other device and connect them to the headphones. Bose products have a memory of connections, once connected, the device will remember and to connect to a device you only need to single press the Bluetooth button; the headphones will announce a device name, and if you wait the headphone will connect to the device (as long as it has Bluetooth on of course). If you deal with several devices at once like phones, tablets and computers, Bose approach is unquestionably better; if you only use one device or don't mind using the cord for the others, this is no real issue. For me, if I had known, it would have probably been a deal breaker. I just thought that Bose's way was the standard. Also... Bose products connect to 2 devices simultaneously.

The Great and awesome:
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

+ Sound quality! In general very similar to the QC series, but with better base. These sound slightly better than Bose which is an impressive feat. Getting either one of these headphones spoil you and ruin every other headphone.
+ USB-C for rapid charging. It's great to know that little time of charging will allow you to use the headphones for a very decent amount of time. Probably more than necessary until there's actually time to properly charge them.
+ Touch controls for Media controls are really great. That is way more comfortable than having to double or triple press a button to do a trivial task.
+ Standard 3.5mm headphone jack!!!! It may sound stupid, but it's great to know that you are guaranteed an easy and quick replacement for the cable if needed. Cables should be able to provide even better sound quality than the best Bluetooth transmission algorithms. Weather that's noticeable with this headphones I don't know. But you can get a cord as long as you want for this headphones whereas with Bose you are basically stuck with the provided length since they use a 2.5mm jack.
+ Outstanding noise-cancelling capabilities. Probably the best I've experienced so far.
+ Outstanding Battery life! Batteries were never an issue for me with the Bose because I had 4 rechargeable batteries that I rotated fairly easily. The battery included with these headphones lasts a really long time (20 to 30 hours) so I don't usually find myself in the need of recharging them when I wanted to use them the most.
+ I'm not going to continue describing good things, because that's what the product description is for.

Hope this helps.

author: mark
title: My ears too sensitive to use this noise cancelling Tech.
content: I am a huge fan of Sony headphones, they are my go to phone for mixing. V8, V6, for decades sony has been my number 1 choice. Unfortunately these noise cancelling over bluetooth I can't even stand for more than a few hours. There is an extremely subtle constant audio pressure on my eardrums, unmistakable, due to the cancelling feature. It's like I'm in a pressure chamber for my ears. Very uncomfortable. Then there is the sound quality - many reviewers give this phone a 10 but I'd rate it no more than a 5 on sound reproduction. The uper end is totally gone, and the equalization function available on the phone doesn't help it. All clarity is lost in my opinion. Returned the set. Hope you have a different experience. :/

author: SoHaN
title: A+
content:
Sound Quality A+
Bass A+
Noise Cancellation A+

author: Alcaloide

content: I am writing this short: I have both version m2 and now the m3. I prefer the m2. It sounds better, no noise reduction distinction from the m3, the m3 hurts the top of my head after 30 minutes of usage, the build quality seems inferior and the sound quality is, for me, a little bit less pleasant. I remember listening the m2 and being impressed. This does not happened with this one. In fact, I rather listen to music with m2 than with the m3. If you can buy the m2, a new one, don't think twice.

author: mohammed M.
title: Excellent sound quality, very good noise canceling, but constant buzzing noises from left ear cup...
content:
The buzzing is now really, REALLY bad and loud. At first i could ignore it, sometimes, but now it's literally unbearable. It only happens when noise canceling/ambient sound is on, which is the main purpose of these headphones...You hear it when you listen to songs with bass (so all songs basically) and while riding buses/trains. I bought these headphones in september. What a shame.

EDIT: scratch the "only happens when noise canceling/ambient sound is on"...it happens even when both are turned off. It's really bad now, songs with good bass is a pain to listen to

author: Tony Washington
title: Great pair of headphones!
content: I love the overall quality and sound!

author: laptop user
title: Choose carefully between Sony XM3 and Bose QC 35 II
content:
The obvious question to me is whether to buy the Sony XM3 or the Bose QC 35 II.

Sound quality: Right out of the box to me the Bose QC35 II are the obvious winner for balanced reference sound quality, and this advantage is even greater because Bose apparently applies the Fletcher-Munson curve based on the volume (the lower the volume, the more bass and treble, based on well-established princples of hearing).

BUT WAIT: It's not so simple as that! The Sony's come with an app with a really nice equalizer. The Sony's right out of the box are too bass heavy for me, full stop. Nice, smooth, even, spectacular, and TOO MUCH bass. So what to do? Go into the equalizer in the app and turn down the "clear bass" by 2 to 5 units, depending on your taste and your normal listening level. Maybe tweak the 6.3 khz slider up one or two units and turn the 16 khz slider up to taste. If you know what you're doing, you can design your own sound!

Noise Cancelling: Sony XM3 wins. Read everyone else's review for details.

Comfort: It depends! If I am using the XM3s in a noisy environment (for me, the subway), they are much more comfortable. When the QC35 II's noise-cancel big-time noise they make my ears feel weird. Around home, the Bose's are more comfortable because they don't need to work so hard at noise cancelling. The Bose are lighter and leave my ears cooler. However, because the earpads of the XM3 are flush with the plastic earcups, I find the Sony much more comfortable and stable for lying down! Think about what you are going to do with these!

Controls: I was surprised to find I much preferred the touch-pad controls of the Sony to the mechanical controls of the Bose. The Bose requires more stillness and dexterity for me. When I use the Bose I really miss just tapping twice to pause the Sony's or to put my hand over the right earcup of the Sony's to instantly reduce the volume and let outside sounds in or just swiping up or down to turn the volume up or down. On the Bose side, Bose seemingly remembers all devices for pairing and connection (I’m sure there’s a limit but I haven’t hit it). Sony seems to only remember one device for connection and pairing. This makes the Bose a lot more convenient if you use more than one device as a source. These are big convenience differences.

For mom around the house I would suggest the Bose. Except for someone who wants to lie down and maybe fall asleep at home or in a hotel with headphones on I would choose the Sony. For a techie sound guy I would suggest the Sony. For a musician I would suggest the Bose. For a commuter subject to sounds like subway noise I would suggest the Sony. Overall result: TIE, both are amazing, but if you can only get one, choose carefully--there are BIG differences!

author: C. Plumley
title: The BEST
content: Comfortable to wear and great sound quality. Really cancels out the roar of jet engines.

author: Marc  Lerner
title: Very good
content: Sound quality , design ND battery. Life excellent.

author: Jeffery
title: Noise canceling 👏🏽
content: Great option for my Beats replacement. Quality is decent for the price point.  I enjoy the low key aesthetic of the design.

author: Ricky Danzanito
title: Great for office use
content:
When I first put these on, they sounded muddy and I was inclined to return them. But after a day of use, and a bit of tweaking EQ in the Sony app, I couldn't take them off. Then, I tried them in the office and there was no going back.

These headphones are real. And after a side by side comparison with the Bose, I prefer Sony XM3.
The Bose were lighter and perhaps more comfortable, but Sony has better noice cancelling, better sound and features. Plus much better style, IMO.

author: Spirit of Nader
title: Great Noise Canceling Headphones
content: Great over the ear headphones. Long battery life, quick charging, can listen while charging (cable option) and very good sound. Noise canceling effective at screening out most low level noises and muting harder sounds. Once the music starts playing you will hear nothing but that. If you get these you will soon realize how much ambient noise our ears are subjected to all the time.

author: RS99
title: Good Product
content: Great product. Only negatives were battery life shorter than advertised and controls a little over sensitive to inadvertent touch.

author: Muhammad Ibrahim Imran
title: Distortion
content: The headphone start to distort after few months.

author: Keith D.
title: awesome
content: love them!

author: WLB84
title: Just make sure they are new!
content: The headphones are great except I had to return them because Amazon sent me used ones. They were covered in oily fingerprints and white specks that I can only assume was someone’s dandruff. Thankfully best buy was down the street

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great battery life, excellent noise cancelling, good sound quality
content: I loved how this headset is so comfortable to wear for long periods of time, how easy it is to store it, and most of all, how good the noise cancellation is. I wore this headset on airplanes with screaming children and I couldn't hear them at all!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Excellent Noise Cancellation...but...
content: These are all around GREAT!!  I am having issues with the sound "skipping" and then it is out of sync with the movie/tv show.  There could be an issue with my Bluetooth connection.  I did move my computer and a few other things that might be affecting the connection...but it is still happening.  Very annoying.

author: Casey S.
title: The reviews are true. These are top tier.
content: Literally the best noise canceling on the market. I work in a call center in a non-phone position on the call floor so it's very loud for most of the day. These go on and everyone disappears. If you need a good set of headphones for noisy environments these are the only real option.

author: Amazon Customer
title: No comment
content: No comment

author: Joseph Murphy
title: Decent - Can't use in cold weather, Google Assistant broken
content:
Pros: earcups are comfortable, only drops for a split second when first connecting via Bluetooth. After that the audio is smooth sailing. App is nice for granular control of sound quality, noise-canceling and ambient sound. On par with Bose, which was my go-to for noise-canceling but their offering kept clipping out three or four times per song and I lost patience.

Cons:
--When moving from a warm indoor enviroment to a cold one (say, Boston in February) the touch controls on the right earcup become more than merely useless. They actually cause music to skip forward, backward, tracks skip all over, volume goes up and down, etc. The solution, which is a bit of a pain but has resolved it for me, is to turn off the headphones once you get outside for a minute and then turn them back on. This recalibrates the touch controls and you're set for the duration of time the headphones are outside.

-- the Google Personal Assistant configuration is impossible though I'm not sure if it is Google or Sony to blame here. I speak commands to the headphones (after saying "Hey, Google" to get the Assistant app open). My spoken commands transcribe, no problem, but nothing happens. The commands go nowhere. This brings me to my next complaint:

-- Firmware won't update. Using the iOS app, I tried updating the firmware but it never downloads. Just hangs at "0% downloading" and never either starts the download or indicates that the download has failed. Tried doing this from home and work to no avail. I've since opened a support ticket with Sony. Hopefully they can get me sorted.

It's no great shakes for me to lose the assistant function. I really just wanted a decent pair of Bluetooth noise-canceling headphones and these do the trick nicely if you are willing to tolerate the cold-weather reboots.

author: Kvo Clai
title: Seriously one device?
content:
For me these are incredible headphones with great sound, noise cancelling, and features.

They charge via USB-C, and that's an absolute must.

Something, I didn't even look into before purchasing was the ability to pair 2 devices. I was shocked to learn they could only pair to one device. It's been years since I have purchased headphones without this ability. -3 stars (huge disability)

I love the hand over earcup thing when in the office and someone says something to me, I can hear them really well.

Still debating on returning...

author: DCC
title: Excellent performance for price.
content: These headphones performed better than expected. I have used Bose QC headphones in the past and will not be switching back after using these Sonys.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Nice!
content: Very nice product, top notch noise cancelling

author: Hawaiian
title: Not for everyone
content:
The sound was good. USB type C is really good compared to Bose and the app is really good and steps ahead of bose again. Lack of physical buttons for volume is kind of annoying since the touch wont respond if you are wearing gloves and the like. I do wish there was a dedicated mute instead of double tapping to pause since i couldn't get that function to work with google music on my computer.

Speaking to computer functionality, that seems half backed and if you are using this on your computer I would consider something else. The main thing that killed this headset for me was lack of multiple device connection. I am a 70/30 computer user. I use this device on my computer 70% of the time while I code. The other 30 is for my phone and having to unpair and re-pair is really annoying. I have 4 year old jaybirds that allow multiple bluetooth connections and how this headset doesn't have that perplexes me.

In the end I could not justify the sacrifices I had to make in order to use this head set. Given the price there is no way I was happy with that. Having an app or better integration with PC on top of allowing multiple connections would have made this 5 stars. As it is now, the sacrifices don't justify the price.

author: simon
title: Great headset
content: I liked using this set, super comfortable and amazing noise cancelling and sound quality. I think the set is capable of providing better noise cancelling as the background noise is basically non existent but the conversations going on around aren’t suppressed as well as the background is. Sound quality is amazing but I don’t think it’s the best it can be. I’m not complaining about the headset, but I feel like these are good points to address in maybe a firmware update.

author: Lottie
title: Great pair of headphones. Do just what they are supposed to do!
content: These are the only headphones I have tried and bought them after reading all the reviews. I am happy with the purchase and they do a great job of blocking out noise and the sound quality is great. I expect they will make my next flight much more enjoyable. I used them at the pool and could hardly hear the screaming children. Made my day, LOL. they were easy to pair with my phone.

author: Michael
title: Expensive, but it's worth it
content:
I bought these to replace a messed up pair of AKG wireless headphones. For $300 I was hesitant since I've never used any NC headphones other than those. When I first used these I thought the NC was kind of lacking for $300, but after using it for a bot it is definitely on par or slightly better than the other headphones I've used. They're WAY more comfortable compared to the on ear NC headphones I used before, and I would say that these Sony headphones are more comfortable than most gaming headsets I've used also.  Overall it's a purchase that I don't think I will regret.

When you get these, make sure to hold the power button for a few seconds to pair with a device.

author: Adam Saunders
title: These cancel so much sound I almost forgot I’m in the world!
content: This is my first pair of active noise canceling headphones. I’m also a researcher and google tons of reviews before I buy things. I’ve read every review. I’ve watched every amateur video. I love these headphones. They’re expensive. If you can afford these, you will surely love them. They’re great on airplanes, on the bus, next to a sleeping partner.  They’re awesome headphones.

author: InkBlots
title: Product Cancels Noise
content: This product efficiently cancels noise in the environment. It was a hit with the grandson!

author: Reece
title: Aweful defect.
content:
I bought these for Flights, now after my first flight with these I sit in LAX disappointed . They completely malfunctioned on takeoff and a bit on landing. There was heavy static coming out of both ears, so bad had to remove them. It was a sharp painful sound. Happened on landing as well but not quite as bad. I haven’t been able to find anyone with similar issues yet. Not sure if I’m just unlucky or it’s going unreported.

This is super disappointing, it took me over a year to finally pull the trigger and buy what I thought was a good pair of noise cancelling headphones. Cannot recommend these at all sadly.

I noticed the noise cancelling aren’t quiet as good as my wife’s XM2’s maybe because they fit tighter, but I can hear a normal conversation easily while in noise cancelling mode, and after doing the setup.

Also had some volume issues while on iPhone 10xs, not very loud at max volume then an hour later I was able to turn them up more. Hopefully will be fixed with software.

author: Anonymous Buyer
title: Great noise cancelling headphones with good sound quality
content:
The WH1000XM3s have very good sound quality with excellent noise cancelling capabilities. The headphone is well built and lasts a long time per charge (1-2 days of heavy listening, 1 week of casual listening).

A few things that I would nit pick about:
 - Included charging cable is very short
 - Bluetooth pairing can get annoying if you want to use it with multiple devices
 - Sometimes a popping sound comes from the ear cups
 - Touch controls sometimes don't work in cold weather
 - ambient noise feature is a bit finicky

Other than that, it is a pair of very nice headphones for everyday use

author: J. Grosz
title: Best headphones I've ever owned
content: These replaced an old pair of wired Sony headphones I got about 5 years prior.  These are by far the best headphones I've ever owned.  The noise cancelation works spectacularly and the battery life has been great.  I actually received these as a give several months back and purchased this recent pair as a gift for a family member.  I would choose these over Beats or Bose for performance and accessories.  While not that important, the fact it includes the converter for two-prong airplane connections is great.

author: Iponder
title: The best....
content: Excellent, doesn't get better. Expensive but soooo worth it. Durable, sleek and excellent sound.

author: Charles A Ferrer Jr
title: Cone of silence
content: Absolutely essential for air travel to Europe. Put these on your ears and engage the cone of silence, happiness!

author: Mark
title: Do not buy.not easy use .
content: The charging and blue tooth connection are not good .Do not buy.Sound quality good but they are not practical.The software in these headphones is horrible.

author: George
title: Impressive noise cancelling and sound quality, pretty comfortable
content:
These headphones make me feel like noise cancelling has come a long way. I was impressed by its effectiveness. I'm no audiophile, but these headphones sound like a pretty serious "step up" most other headphones I own.

I'd say that wearing this set of headphones for a long period of time feels a bit uncomfortable, but I don't think it's due to the sound cancelling.

For reference, I have a few random headsets and headphones:
* Bose QC15 (bose are slightly more comfortable than the sony -- maybe it's my headshape, but after a while the sony feels like they're clamping my head just a bit tighter and the bose are just a little bit lighter... obviously the QC15 model has a cord though)
* Hyper X Cloud Flights (a bit more comfortable than those)
* Logitech G933 (lots more comfortable than those)

Most bluetooth headsets I've owned (some no-name earbuds/headphones) have also had really obscure pairing rules. I think Sony's done the best job I've seen with that. Simplest bluetooth pairing experience I've had to date.

Volume and other controls on the right side of the headphones are a bit difficult to distinguish though. There's several times I've accidentally changed volume because I touched my headphones on accident, and other times I've paused or something when I just wanted to change the volume. I think there could be some improvement there to make the touch controls a bit more discrete.

author: Customer
title: Very cool
content: This is amazing!!!!!!!!!!!! Super cool love this

author: Maryem Menad
title: This headphone’s noise cancellation is amazing
content: Great product

author: Gaston Medina
title: Great Headphones
content: I just Love them... Very usefull for airplane travellers

author: Kevin N.
title: Best noise cancelling headphones hands down.
content: So I've tried all of the top of the line wireless noise cancelling headphones and these are absolutely the best. On top of that they have even extra functionality like the touch to change stuff on the sides. Excellent headphones as far as quality and being used as communication device through smart phones as well.

author: Regular Shopper
title: Like, not love, these Headphones !
content: The updated Sony noise canceling headphones are nice and much lighter. I, however, prefer the previous headphone. While it was definitely heavier, for me the music was better.

author: SS
title: Wonderful sound and excellent noise isolation.
content: Great beautiful sound. Advanced features. Super Comfortable. And noise isolation is great too. Don’t think I have enjoyed my music library so much ever before. Very Highly recommend. Must buy!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Awesome headphones that allow me to focus at work when the office gets too noisy
content: It's easy to get distracted at work when trying to concentrate, but with these headphones the ambient noise disappears.  As a bonus, the sound is amazing, I never realized how much detail there was in my MP3 music that I was missing.  And these are so comfortable you can wear them all day.

author: Kevin Kessler
title: Bluetooth headphones with excellent sound quality...
content: I am very happy with these headphones. I thought I would post a review because I read a few reviews where folks were not happy with the call capabilities and bluetooth connection. I was looking for a bluetooth headset that focused on sound quality over connection quality. I listen to a lot of lossless music and was planing on using them primarily with the cord with the option to use Bluetooth. I discovered that the bluetooth sounds much better than I thought and I am using bluetooth almost all of the time. I keep my phone close to me in my pocket and I have never had any connection issues. I was also very happy to find the call quality is much better than I expected. Callers can hear me clearly even when I am on the train. I have had them for only about a month and I only charged two times. I am looking forward to trying them on my next flight.

author: Name
title: Bluetooth Pairing is miserable
content: The bluetooth pairing doesn't work right out of the box, rough start for a 300 dollar pair of headphones. The battery level is also flipping between 60 and 100 percent in the first 5 minutes out of the box. I've never worked with more finnicky audio equipment and I worked in AV in college.

author: AlexCascadia
title: I'm a basshead. In a loud house.
content: I love the nose cancellation! The sheer amount of bass coming from this is like nothing I've experienced before! I've not once has it go below 50% battery while listening for hours. The microphone sucks, but everything else is amazing! Sidenote: the case is good, but the included USB-C charger cable is cheap and short.

author: luke
title: Great headphones. Don't expect to use the touch controls.
content: Touch Controls suck, completely unusable. Other than that the headphones are literally perfect.

author: Gideon
title: Definitely the pinnacle of noise cancelling!
content: I've been using Bose noise cancelling ear buds for the past 3+ years.  They're a good product and worked well.  As a business traveler, being able to drown out airplane engines and other noises made flights far more productive and more relaxing.  I started to see cracking of the rubber guard around where the cable entered and exited the little battery pack so I decided to look for a new solution.  I did a lot of research comparing the top of the line Sony to the top of the line Bose and decided to go with Sony.  Many reviews gave the node to Sony for it's noise cancelling properties.  I also like how long the battery lasts and how much of a charge you get with just a little charging time.  And I LOVE the feature where you can place your hand over the right ear piece and the noise cancelling and music shuts off so you can hear an announcement or someone talking to you.  Remove your hand and everything is back on in an instant.  They're comfortable and I wear glasses so I wondered how'd they'd feel but they're great.  I find myself wearing them in the airport waiting on flights; with or without music playing just to feel more peaceful.  I've used them for phone calls and asked several people how the call sounds on their line and everyone has said it's good.  I like that they come with cables if you want to skip the blue tooth and that they also include the adapter needed to use with the airline entertainment centers on overseas trips.  Sound quality is great; a tip is to use the EQ function with the music app on iPhones!  They're expensive but if you travel as much as I do for work, they really make all of that travel more bearable and more productive!

author: Eric Ruston
title: Great for cancelling noise/help you to focus
content:
I did not know what to expect when I put these headphones for the first time and they connected via bluetooth... it was nothing short of amazing.  I have the WH1000XM3's (black).  It's as if you go straight into a sound chamber and outside noise is drastically reduced.  I know you may be saying 'well of course.. that's what noise cancelling means!'  However, knowing something and then experiencing it are two different things.  To be honest, I think my mind is trying to figure these headphones out still... I get some ringing in my ears and I learned that that can be from the mind compensating for a perceived hearing loss.  I think some part of my auditory perception is thinking there is something missing in these environments where I would normally hear a certain degree of noise!

Again, I risk sounding obvious but you really have to try these to understand what i mean.  I have a great workplace to test the efficacy of these headphones out: a coworker in the next cubicle who noisely eats/gulps/drinks/munches and crunches on food and snacks  incessantly throughout the day (was driving me nucking futs) and right now we have an A/C issue in the office that requires us to have some kind of industrial swamp cooler contraption as a substitute and it sounds similar to that droning noise that can be heard during air travel from the engines.  I know... but I gotta pay the bills!

When I put on the WH1000XM3's, both of those noises are substantially reduced which is a godsend to me.  Then I add in some low volume classical or dub techno and I am in my own little world!  I can focus, relax.. well to the extent that that is possible at work... and the great feature of being able to cup my hand over the right ear cup is fantastic.  It seems to not only cut out the noise cancelling so I can hear a legitimate request from my coworkers, but there seems to be a bit of enhancement.. maybe I am just imagining that though.

I have also tested these out and about, walking and such...there are so many opportunities for me to experience noise pollution in the city I live in!  I can say that I have finally been able to hear a very soft-spoken pod-caster for the first time without having to increase the volume whenever he spoke during his interviews on his podcasts.  Even while walking by noisy traffic/people/construction ....and does anyone else notice the higher volume and pitch of ambulances and other emergency vehicles these days?  Those noises were countered very effectively, although some bangs and loud noises seemed to make the noise cancellation compensate a bit too much, still I would rather not hear the offending noises and so the slight interruption to my listening experience during those brief moments is tolerable.

They also adjust to less noisy environments too: in the early hours of the day, when its almost completely quiet in the environments I'm in at that time, the cancelling drops off and I can hear my car door closing behind me/alarms for forgetting to take the key with me/leaving the headlights on, etc.

The battery life is also another pleasant surprise.  I have doubted manufacturer's claims on battery life, but these really did hold up for close to 30 hours, I have to qualify this by saying that I mostly listen to low-volume classical/techno dub/e-courses/podcasts and the like.

Comfort and wearability are quite high.  I can stand to have these on for three to four hour stretches at a time and probably go longer if I am on a long flight and desperate to get some sleep.  I did try a 45 minute nap with white noise playing and it worked wonderfully.  I have tried wearing the headphones upside down, and they hold on just fine, especially helpful for keeping a lower profile at work, not so obviously 'tuning you jerks out.'  In the heat of the day, out walking, the ear-cups can feel warm (70-80 degree temps) but not too bad.

Ok, now the cons: there were a few glitchy moments with the swiping feature on the right ear-cup and one time where the volume control from the swiping did seem delayed or slow, however I must say that was when I was transitioning from sitting for an extended time at work and then going out for a walk on a break, no excuses, but it was not show stopper, it just took a minute or two for the headphones to 'figure it out.'  There was also a moment where I was sure that I was swiping the volume down but the skip track forward feature triggered instead.

Overall though, I would highly recommend these headphones, especially if you were like me and trying to listen to instructional videos/podcasts for any length of time and you need to focus better.  I think they are far healthier for my hearing as well: the noise cancelling allows me to play background music at super low volume whereas the in-ear earbuds are just terrible (as I now realize in comparison).

author: JC
title: Excellent product, but heats up the ears
content: Great product!! The only flaw is that after only a few minutes of use your ears get warm, it's like you've been in a sauna.  We also bought the Bose corresponding model, which are lighter and have less options, and we had no problems with the ears getting warm.... At the end we kept the Sony, mainly because of all the cool sound options.

author: Cillian
title: Top notch
content: Best headphones around. Excellent sound quality, noise cancelling and bluetooth capabilities....

author: Abanoub Lotfy
title: Excellent great I would recommend buying it
content: Excellent great I would recommend buying it

author: Techwiz
title: Good noice cancellation bad call quality
content: I really like this headphones very much and it cuts the sound in an airplane. However, I am very surprised about the call quality. The moment i get a phone call The noise cancellation stops and whats more I can hear my echo. I thought I could use these on my skype meeting etc but it useless for that. I am thinking of returning.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Touchpad is a HUGE mistake
content:
I've owned the first edition of these (MDR-1000X) for a long time and used them daily.  I decided it was time to upgrade, but these WH1000XM3 aren't the upgrade I was looking for.  I had to return them.

First, the good:  Good sound, excellent noise canceling.  App finally provides a control to turn off the annoying voice assist that is constantly telling you what button you just pushed.

Now the bad:  Build quality is way down from the older versions.  The earcups and touchpad are plastic, not nice leather anymore.  The touchpad itself is frequently non-responsive; not a problem I had with the previous version.  I found myself punching my own ear just to try to get it to register a tap.  And that was indoors - but take them out in the cold and it's as bad as everyone says.  They are unusable in the cold and will freak out and act crazy.  Sony's official stance on this is "they're not meant to work in sub-freezing temperatures" but a) they break down way before it's that cold and b) the old ones - and literally any other headphone you can buy - work fine well below freezing.  Also, they have fewer buttons and less ability to control the headphones without needing to use the companion app, which is annoying to have to dig out a phone and long load times just to perform basic functions.  The old ones had a button of noise canceling, a button for audio pass-though, and you could long-press the touchpad for Google assistance.  The new ones, you can choose one of those three things to assign to the sole button, and the rest you can't do.

So yeah.  I returned them and bought the B&W PX headphones instead.  The sound is better.  The noise canceling is worse, but I can give that up for all the benefits they provide -- like controls that actually work.

author: Bernard
title: No Real Point of Comparison
content:
Take that title how you want. On the one hand, I don't have a point of comparison. These are my first legit over-the-ear, intended-for-real-listening headphones that didn't cost $20 or less. So, in that case, it's an incredible listening experience. You know that expression, "Mind Blown"? Yeah, that. These sound amazing.

On the other hand, is there really a point to compare? The reviews have said it all. Top in class active noise cancellation. Great sounding headphones. Support for aptX-HD for CD-level clarity. What's not to like about a set of cans like this? And yet, I've already encountered a couple of issues -- nit-picks really:

1) I have already wanted to use it with another Bluetooth device, but hesitated because I know that it can't be paired with more than one device at a time. I know that the Bose QC II do that. These don't. Is it a deal-breaker? Not really. Just a mild inconvenience.

2) The HD quality sound is great. However, if you want to alter the sound stage. Change a setting on the equalizer. Change the surround. You can't opt for the headphones to prioritize sound quality. Did that make sense? Let me say it again: "You can't prioritize sound quality AND change the sound stage." Some might say that they are mutually exclusive. You choose one or the other. While others might want to have audio quality AND adjust the audio to their own sound palette.

3) Coding the Hard Button is odd. Why give one button three options? What if I want Google Assistant/Alexa AND ANC control?

4) Touch controls are great, but not consistent. The worst offender here is the palm mute. What has been described as a simple cupping of the headphone will allow ambient sounds come through, but the palm has to physically be on the whole of the touch pad. Again, not a deal-breaker, but not as magical as it is described.

5) It's plasticky and feels plasticky. I don't know how else to describe it.

Some qualifiable things:

a) No perceived latency with videos that I can tell. Lips are in sync with audio. I know some people have said there are issues. For what it's worth, I'm running this through a OnePlus 6T which supports aptX;

b) listening comfort is good. These fit my ears great, but I know that won't be true for everyone. My ears did get a bit warm, but that's to be expected I suppose.

Other than that, other non-qualitative factors, like range, it's good. I can have my phone in the basement of my house and walk all around the home, including to the top floor, opposite end of the house, and still have crystal clear audio.

After all that's written here, do I regret this purchase? Absolutely not. There's a wealth of great videos out there comparing these with others by those who've used its competitors. I don't doubt anything that they've said. So, I am sure that I have either the best or second-best headphones on the market. After using them, I don't have any reason to doubt those claims. You won't be disappointed that's for sure!

author: Chicken Broth
title: Best ANC, but overall not for me
content: They're great if you want the best ANC in the market, but they fit loosely on my small head, not grippy enough. And the touch controls are not ideal, need to second guess the play and pause control all the time. Cupping the right earcup to activate speak through is purely a gimmick, and so are many of the app features which you wouldn't use in everyday usage

author: Ashton
title: Great sound. Horrible microphone.
content: These are fantastic noise canceling headphones. However, they may have the worst microphone in existence. Buy these if you want strict good quality headphones. Do not expect to be able to take a call with them or your friends will hate you. Also, the touch controls are a bit wonky. It tends to take 2 or 3 tries to get it to do what you want.

author: ShawDental
title: Makes mowing the grass fun
content: I love these headphones.  I bought them to use while mowing. I have a big 72" Gravely mower with a 32hp Kawasaki engine. These headphones dramatically reduce the engine noise.  I turn on Netflix, Pandora, a Professional seminar, or even a ball game on my iPhone.  I keep the volume on my phone at half volume is plenty to hear the show over the mower. (Pretty good for someone with hearing loss). These headphones make mowing so much more enjoyable.

author: NBG
title: Great headphones
content: Adults and kids like these equally well...the challenge of course is that at this price point, I am not running out to buy a pair for every family member. Great for travelers, even if they do take up their space: they are A LOT more comfortable that the in-ear Bose noise-cancelling earphones, specially for the longer flights.

author: Audrey3
title: Very good headphones!
content:
These are my first noise-cancelling headphones, so I can't compare with other models, but I can say I am very pleased with my new headphones. The noise-cancelling is great for the plane, not only I felt less tired after the flight from the constant loud noise, but also it was very nice not to have to pump up the volume of the movie so that I could hear over the plane noise.  Battery life is very impressive.

The one downside I would say is the touch controls ever the right ear, in the first few weeks I frequently skipped or paused a song involuntarily because I touched the headphones by mistake. It happens less and less often as I get used to it, but I still would prefer 'pressable' buttons to touch controls.

author: Ryan B.
title: 30hrs of A+ build quality and listening experience
content: Perfect... make sure you pair them correctly with your PC as “hands free” may be selected by default which will inturn degrade the sound quality and overall listening experience  — Top tier, purchasing an extra pair for my dad.. happy Father’s Day!

author: Anna Umstead
title: No sound from Right side
content: Right side has no sound.

author: RJM
title: Chose the Sony WH-1000XM3 over the Bose QC35 MII
content:
Similar to many reviews I also experienced the strange ear pressure from the ANC function on the Bose QC 35 M II (which concerned me).  It was never painful, but at first a bit annoying.  Also like many other reviews, after using them for about a week it seemed to be less apparent less often.  I would probably have been fine keeping Bose QC 35 M II (maybe) - they were a gift and are quite nice.  However, I decided to try the Sony's in order to make a more informed choice.

1) I found the Sony's to be a bit less comfortable around and on the ear, because the cushions are not as thick as the Bose and the foam of the inner part of headphone rests on your ears.  The Bose by contrast had thick pads that held the inner part of the earphones completely off your ear.  I would compare it to wearing a cozy pair of slippers (Sony's), v.s. a light-weight loose fitting soft cotton shirt (Bose).  I preferred the Bose on this point.
2) I did find the clamping pressure of the Sony's to be a bit too much, and preferred the Bose for comfort on this level as well.
3) I also liked that the Bose had an on/off switch where as the Sony had a button that did not physically change position based on whether the unit was on or off.  The Sony swipe controls may also take a little more getting used to but in the end may be more convenient.
4) On the ANC, I found the noise cancelling on the Sony's to be superior.  I work in an office with very loud ventilation and the Sony's were noticeably quieter (confirmed by a co-worker).  I haven't tried them on a plane yet, but I'm going to assume they will be better there as well - and if not they should be plenty adequate.  With the Sony's I did notice some initial moments where there was a higher pitch background noise that would come on and off a few times, then it went away - perhaps the system needed a little time to get straightened out.  I also did not notice the pressure on the eardrums that I observed with the Bose.
5) I'm not an audiophile, so they both sounded good to me.  Perhaps the Sony's were better, as I did feel a little bit more immersed in what I would describe as a richer sound with the Sony's.

In summary, Bose were more comfortable on the ear surface and on the head.  Sony's had better noise cancelling, and did not create the pressure on the eardrum that I experienced with the Bose.  Sound I tip my hat to Sony.  Both very nice, and if you have a ton of money, or fly A LOT, or someone gifts them to you, (and you are ok with the eardrum pressure of the Bose) then you will likely be happy with either.

Update:  5/3/2019 - Still happy with my decision to go with the Sony's over the Bose, but the Bluetooth connectivity is annoying.  The Bose allowed you to be simultaneously connected to more than one device over Bluetooth.  The Sony's do not, and furthermore to get the Sony's to pair with a new device, you have to physically turn the Bluetooth on the currently connect device off.  Bose is definitely superior on the ease of Bluetooth connectivity.  I would imagine Sony's issues can be solved with firmware, as opposed to requiring different hardware (I could be wrong).  If that is the case, Sony needs to pay attention to this and step their game up.  In my opinion this improvement would put them clearly in the lead against Bose in the wireless ANC headphones race.

author: Ria
title: Awesome
content: Got this for my brothers Christmas present. He LOVED it! He’s always complaining that the families too loud so now he’s on cloud nine with these. It sounds like your ears are clogged when you wear them in my opinion.

author: NAME_NOT_RETURNED
title: Good
content: I could still here through the noise canceling

author: Amazon Customer
title: Holy crap these are life changing.
content: I can’t believe I hadn’t bought these sooner! A little pricey, but SO WORTH IT! Comes in a handy case, and can fold. Noise cancelling and ambient sound abilities are top notch. So it. Buy it. You won’t regret it.

author: Victor De La Fuente
title: Simply the best Headphones!!!!
content: Superb audio, AC like no other... I have others headphones but this is teh best by far!!!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Pros and Cons
content: In terms of high quality, these do sound great but you do need the app to use them fully. I would have them set at noise cancellation and they would randomly beep when they heard noise. I couldn't find a setting for this. The ability to adjust track and volume only works with Bluetooth and they are substantially louder when plugged in. My biggest issue was the random beeping. Ambient noise is kinda neat if you want to not be bothered but still listen to what's around you. Noise cancelling was a great otherwise

author: The Dude
title: READ: before you buy...
content:
So I purchased this headphone because it was on sale on Amazon and because I read a lot of good reviews and articles about it.

First off, it supports several bluetooth codecs such as SBC, AAC, aptX, aptX HD and LDAC. From what I read, you get a (supposedly) superior sound quality (over bluetooth) if you configured your Sony WH-1000XM3 to use LDAC.  LDAC is an audio coding technology developed by Sony that enables the transmission of High-Resolution (Hi-Res) Audio content, even over a Bluetooth connection. LDAC sound quality is supposed to be better than CD quality but to be honest, from my experience I cannot tell any sound quality difference between SBC codec (which is the basic coding standard for most Bluetooth devices and is present in almost in every device by default) and LDAC codec. In any case I opted to configure the headphone to use LDAC (just because) and tweak my smartphone to get the sound quality that I want.

So how does one do that? I installed the Sony Headphones Connect app for Android and set the following parameters.
"Sound Position Control" = OFF.
"Surround (VPT)" = OFF.
"Equalizer" = OFF.
"Sound Quality Mode" = PRIORITY ON SOUND QUALITY.
"DSEE HX" = OFF.

Then from my smartphone (Galaxy S7) and set  the following parameters:
System EQ to "flat".
Go to Developer Options> set Bluetooth Audio Codec Streaming = LDAC.
Go to Developer Options> set Bluetooth Audio Sample Rate = 96.0 kHz.  I played some music from my Amazon Prime Music and the audio quality was flat (eventhough Sony claims LDAC was better). TO GET THE SOUND QUALITY I WANT FROM MY MUSIC, I have to adjust my smartphone system EQ (not the Sony app EQ since that can't be change when using LDAC or AptX).  Or use SBC and adjust the Sony EQ until you achieved the sound quality to your liking.

Bottom line: By default the Sony WH-1000XM3 sound is a bit flat with a little bit of bass. Now you can change that by selecting a desired bluetooth codec and adjusting either your smartphone system EQ or the Sony app EQ. Which is really moot because one can argue that you can buy a less expensive headphone and tweak your smartphone to get the same result.

ALSO... if you ever use the headphone and pair it with your PC or any bluetooth devices, the EQ settings you configured to get that sound you like, is not saved in the headphone unless you use SBC codec.

The noise canceling is fantastic. It does not totally eliminates the noise but you can tell the difference, and you can drown out all the noise if you adjust your music up a little. I have not tested the audio call quality since I didn't buy the headphone for that purpose and I don't really talk  on the phone that much.

Hope this helps.

author: Ryan
title: Great for flights!
content: Great for flying. It silences the extremely loud background noises that would normally require you to turn your headphones up to max volume just to barely hear the dialogue of a movie.

author: C. Mallon
title: Great headphones
content: They are light weight, comfortable and have great sound.

author: J. Martin
title: Get them.
content: My first review about these was awful.  I did not like them AT ALL.  Then, I actually tried them, everyday, for a week, and now won't go to work without them.  I work in a very noisy environment that would probably, eventually, cause hearing problems.  I put these on and don't even think about the noise now.  Bluetooth is playing, at various levels of loudness, and I can place a call, and people can actually hear me and understand what I'm saying.  I don't care much for the "invisible" controls, and if you order a pair, better order one of those new USB type cables, because the 9ne they give you is ridiculous; less than a foot long.  I can wear these for a long time and forget that I'm even wearing them.  They cost ALOT, and for me, worth every dime.

author: Chuck
title: Great headphones with one flaw
content: Great headphones, but not being able to connect to multiple devices is a bit of a flaw. I switch between my laptop and phone pretty often, so needing to disconnect the headphones from each device rather than the headphones being able to connect by itself is annoying.

author: Sroyall
title: Five star product - One star service. Sony doesn't support Military APO/DPO addresses
content: Great headphones, echoing everything else folks say on here. I use them regularly for calls in crowded coffee shops and they are fine for audio quality. Absolutely fantastic for air travel. Unfortunately they started crashing and shutting down and I had to warranty them out. The service department kept insisting I factory reset my headphones, even when I indicated I had already tried that multiple times. Third time contacting support they finally agreed to a warranty replacement. The support tech couldn't enter in a DPO address into the system, so now I have to ship them to my parents and wait over a month for a replacement. Not particularly happy with Sony right now.

author: Amazonaholic
title: If you weren’t satisfied with the competing Bose, you’ll like these!
content:
I did an unbiased A/B comparison of these with the Bose QuietComfort II, which my wife has.
Pros:
Variety of options in the app
If the ANC on the Bose makes you queasy, in all probability you will like these (and vice versa)
Controls are pretty good
Cons:
Slightly uncomfortable when put around the neck, but actually more comfortable than the Bose at this (for my neck)
The “silver” color is actually more of a bronze/gold
Bass response was tangibly lesser than the Bose, but overall these sound more balanced.

author: WSY
title: Must read: I used the touch controls exactly as directed and damaged my headset.
content: I got these as a gift on Christmas day. The box, the website, and the videos specifically say that cupping your hand on your ear is how you mute the sound. Well, I cupped my ear and heard a crackling noise in my ear. Now the sound coming out of that side cracks at certain frequencies. BE VERY CAREFUL. It didn't take very much force at all to cause this problem.

author: Brett
title: Buy, better than Bose (by far IMO), comfy, sound quality is great, ANR is incredible.
content:
Okay, I've held off doing this review for a couple of weeks.  I downloaded the android app - definitely do that if you're using android. Wow, how cool.  Adapts to sounds around you instantly, controls the pressure in your ears, can be adjusted say mid flight.  Sound quality with ANR is fantastic.  I paired this with my Note8 and with the adaptive sound in the Samsung music app, it will test your hearing, amplify what you can't hear well.  THEN pair that with these.  Oh My GOD.  I was listening to Bohemian Rhapsody and I heard a voice sort of to my left rear singing a whole other track that I'd barely ever noticed before.
ANR:  WOW.  I just flew over the weekend in a crowded 737 with kids.  I put these things on and POOF!  The plane, the people, the intercom EVERYTHING just becomes a quiet background noise at best.  Turn on the music and you cannot hear ANYTHING else.  LOVE LOVE LOVE these!!!!  Anxiety dropped by a factor of 10 by just drowning out the noise.  Best ANR on the market.  I tested these against the Bose Q3 or whatever because they were in the airport.  I put their ANR on max and mine on max.  I could still hear everything, though quieter with the Bose.  Mine?  POOF! gone.  Buy the best the first time and only cry ONCE.

author: Edwin
title: Terrible headphones, constant disconnects and squeaking sound
content:
I’ve gone through three of these headphones and each one has had some problems but none as terrible as the one I’m currently experiencing.
